questions.text: Which of the subsequent diseases demonstrate autosomal recessive inheritance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Albinism:

  • Albinism: Albinism is a genetic condition characterized by a lack of pigmentation in the hair, skin, and eyes. It is caused by various mutations in genes involved in the production of melanin. Albinism follows an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. Individuals with one copy of the mutated gene are carriers but typically do not show symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - G6PD deficiency: G6PD deficiency follows an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance.

Option C - Marfan's syndrome: Marfan's syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.

Option D - Lesch-Nyhan syndrome: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome follows an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance, primarily affecting males. Females can be carriers of the condition.

questions.text: The movements at the _______ joint permit a person to look to the right and left
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Atlanto-axial joint:

The Atlanto-axial joint is formed between the atlas (C1 vertebra) and the axis (C2 vertebra) in the spine. This joint is responsible for rotational movements of the head. The axis (C2) has a peg-like structure called the dens or odontoid process, which fits into the atlas (C1), allowing for rotation. Therefore, the Atlanto-axial joint permits the specific movements required for looking to the right and left.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Atlanto-occipital joint

The Atlanto-occipital joint permits flexion and extension movements of the head, like nodding. It's mainly for tilting the head forward and backward, rather than side-to-side rotation.

 Option C - C2-C3 intervertebral joint

The C2-C3 intervertebral joint permits flexion, extension, lateral bending, and some degree of rotation, but sideways rotation is mainly handled by the Atlanto-axial joint, not C2-C3.

Option D - C3-C4 intervertebral joint

The C3-C4 joint, similar to C2-C3, allows neck movements like flexion, extension, lateral bending, and some degree of rotation. However, it's not directly involved in sideways rotational movements.

questions.text: Which of the following deficiencies leads to an elevation of glutamine levels in the bloodstream?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ornithine transcarbamoylase:

  • Ornithine transcarbamoylase: Deficiency of ornithine transcarbamoylase (OTC) leads to ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency, which is an X-linked disorder affecting the urea cycle. It results in the accumulation of ammonia in the blood and increased levels of glutamine.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Arginosuccinate lyase: Deficiency of arginosuccinate lyase leads to argininosuccinic aciduria, which is characterized by the accumulation of argininosuccinic acid in the blood and urine. It does not directly cause increased glutamine levels.

Option B - Alpha-galactosidase-A: Deficiency of alpha-galactosidase-A leads to Fabry disease, which is a lysosomal storage disorder. It results in the buildup of globotriaosylceramide (GL-3) in various organs, but it does not cause increased glutamine levels.

Option D - Arginase: Deficiency of arginase leads to argininemia, which is a rare autosomal recessive disorder. It causes the accumulation of arginine in the blood and does not directly cause increased glutamine levels.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the right coronary artery?

choices.text: It’s diameter is less than left coronary artery
It arises from the right aortic sinus
It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch
Right conal artery is it’s first branch

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - It gives rise to the circumflex coronary branch.

This statement is false. The right coronary artery does not typically give rise to the circumflex coronary branch. The circumflex branch is a branch of the left coronary artery. It wraps around the left side of the heart and supplies blood to the left atrium and portions of the left ventricle.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Its diameter is less than the left coronary artery.

This statement is generally true.Left coronary artery (LCA) typically has a slightly larger diameter than the the right coronary artery (RCA)

Option B - It arises from the anterior aortic sinus.

This statement is true. The right coronary artery originates from the right aortic sinus, which is one of the three aortic sinuses located at the base of the aorta.

Option D - Right conal artery is its first branch.

This statement is true. The right conal artery is indeed the first branch of the right coronary artery.

questions.text: Which amino acid is essential for the conversion of nor-epinephrine to epinephrine among the following options?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Methionine:

  • Methionine: Methionine is an essential amino acid that plays a crucial role in the synthesis of epinephrine. It is converted to S-adenosylmethionine (SAM), which serves as a methyl donor in the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Tyrosine: Tyrosine is the precursor for the synthesis of norepinephrine and dopamine, but it is not directly involved in the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine.

Option B - Tryptophan: Tryptophan is an essential amino acid that is used in the synthesis of serotonin, melatonin, and niacin, but it is not involved in the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine.

Option C - Phenylalanine: Phenylalanine is an essential amino acid that is converted to tyrosine in the body. While tyrosine is involved in the synthesis of norepinephrine and epinephrine, phenylalanine itself is not directly involved in this conversion.

questions.text: What is the basis for the formation of omphaloceles?

choices.text: Physiological hernia failing to go back

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Physiological hernia failing to go back:

Omphalocele is believed to result from a physiological herniation of abdominal organs into the base of the umbilical cord during early fetal development. Normally, the abdominal contents herniate into the umbilical cord at around 6 weeks of gestation but then return back into the abdominal cavity. However, in the case of omphalocele, this physiological herniation fails to go back, resulting in the persistence of the herniated organs outside the abdominal cavity.

Incorrect Options :

Option A) Excessive length of the intestine:

Omphalocele occurs due to a defect in abdominal muscle development, leading to organ herniation through the umbilical ring, not because of excessive intestinal length..

Option C) Herniation of liver:

Omphalocele involves abdominal organs, like the liver, herniating through the umbilical ring. However, it's not only about liver herniation; other abdominal organs are also involved.

Option D) Herniation of umbilicus:

Omphalocele does not involve the herniation of the umbilicus itself but rather the herniation of abdominal organs through the umbilical ring.

questions.text: Which fibre is marked by the arrow in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Projection:

The region marked in the image is the genu of the internal capsule. The internal capsule is composed of projection fibers passing to and from the brainstem and the cerebral cortex. It consists of 3 parts: an anterior limb, a posterior limb, and a genu.

Projection fibers are neural fibers that transmit signals between the cerebral cortex and lower brain regions or the spinal cord. They carry sensory information from the peripheral nervous system to the brain (ascending pathways) and motor commands from the brain to the peripheral nervous system (descending pathways).  

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Short association: Short association fibers are neural connections that link different areas within the same cerebral hemisphere. In the internal capsule image, they wouldn't stand out prominently as it's primarily composed of projection fibers.

Option B - Long association: Long association fibers connect different cortical areas within the same hemisphere and allow for communication and integration between distant regions. They would not be expected to be specifically marked in the image of the internal capsule.

Option D - Commissural: Commissural fibers are neural fibers that connect corresponding areas in the two cerebral hemispheres, allowing for communication and integration between the left and right hemispheres.

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not form the boundaries of the Calot triangle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option-D: Gallbladder:

  • The gallbladder is not considered one of the boundaries of the Calot triangle.
  • The Calot triangle is an anatomical space located between the cystic duct, common hepatic duct, and cystic artery.
     

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Common hepatic duct: The common hepatic duct is one of the boundaries of the Calot triangle. It carries bile from the liver and joins with the cystic duct to form the common bile duct.

Option B: Cystic duct: The cystic duct is another boundary of the Calot triangle. It connects the gallbladder to the common hepatic duct and forms the neck of the gallbladder.

Option C: Cystic artery: The cystic artery is also part of the Calot triangle. It arises from the right hepatic artery or its branches and supplies blood to the gallbladder.

questions.text: Area marked in the given image supplied by dermatome number?
questions.solution:
Correct Option-C: T10: The area marked in the given image corresponds to the T10 dermatome. Each dermatome represents a specific segment of spinal nerve innervation. The T10 dermatome covers the region at the level of the tenth thoracic vertebra, which is consistent with the location shown in the image.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A:T8: The T8 dermatome, positioned slightly higher on the trunk than the marked level in the image, provides sensory innervation to the skin at the eighth thoracic vertebra level.

Option B:T9: The T9 dermatome, situated slightly above the marked level in the image, provides sensory innervation to the skin at the ninth thoracic vertebra level.

Option D: T11: The T11 dermatome, found slightly below the marked level in the image, provides sensory innervation to the skin at the level of the eleventh thoracic vertebra.

questions.text: The arrow in the image denotes which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Extensor carpi radialis: The image shows the extensor carpi radialis muscle, which is indicated by the arrow. This muscle is located in the forearm and plays a role in extending and abducting the wrist.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Brachioradialis: The arrow in the image doesn't point to the brachioradialis muscle, which is located in the forearm but positioned more laterally compared to the extensor carpi radialis.

Option C: Supinator: The arrow in the image doesn't point to the supinator muscle, situated in the forearm, assisting in forearm supination by rotating the palm upward.

Option D: Flexor carpi radialis brevis: The arrow in the image doesn't indicate the flexor carpi radialis, a muscle responsible for wrist flexion.radialis brevis." The correct name for the muscle associated with flexing the wrist is the flexor carpi radialis, but it is not indicated by the arrow in the image.

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: Median nerve: The median nerve is the correct answer. It provides motor innervation to the lumbrical muscles of the hand, including the 2nd lumbrical. The lumbrical muscles are responsible for flexing the metacarpophalangeal joints and extending the interphalangeal joints of the fingers.

Incorrect Options :

Option A: Posterior interosseous nerve: The posterior interosseous nerve primarily supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm. It does not supply the structure marked in the image, which is the 2nd lumbrical.

Option C: Anterior interosseous nerve: The anterior interosseous nerve supplies the deep flexor muscles of the forearm, but it does not directly innervate the lumbrical muscles.

Option D: Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve innervates the muscles of the hypothenar eminence, interosseous muscles, and intrinsic muscles of the hand. It does not directly supply the 2nd lumbrical muscle.

questions.text: Nerve supply of the area marked by arrow in the image is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option :

Option A: Radial nerve: The radial nerve supplies the area marked by the arrow in the image, which corresponds to the anatomical snuff box. The anatomical snuff box is located on the dorsum (back) of the hand and is formed by tendons of the extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis muscles. The radial nerve provides sensory innervation to this area.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Posterior interosseous nerve: The posterior interosseous nerve is a branch of the radial nerve that supplies the deep extensor muscles of the forearm. It does not directly innervate the area marked in the image.

Option C: Median nerve: The median nerve primarily supplies the palmar aspect of the hand, including the thenar muscles and lateral 3 and a half digits. It does not directly supply the area marked in the image.

Option D: Ulnar nerve: The ulnar nerve primarily innervates the medial aspect of the hand, including the hypothenar muscles and the ulnar side of the palm. It does not directly supply the area marked in the image.

questions.text: Which of the following was separated by the cholecysto-vena caval line?

choices.text: Porta hepatis and inferior vena cava
Right and left lobe of liver

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: Right and left lobe of liver: The cholecysto-vena caval line is an imaginary line drawn on the visceral surface of the liver. It separates the right lobe of the liver from the left lobe of the liver. The right lobe is larger and encompasses most of the liver's volume, while the left lobe is smaller.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Gallbladder and inferior vena cava: The cholecysto-vena caval line doesn't separate the gallbladder and the inferior vena cava. The gallbladder is in the right lobe of the liver, while the inferior vena cava runs alongside the liver.

Option B: Porta hepatis and inferior vena cava: The cholecysto-vena caval line doesn't separate the porta hepatis and the inferior vena cava. The porta hepatis is where the hepatic artery, portal vein, and bile ducts connect with the liver.

Option C: Caudate lobe and quadrangular lobe: The cholecysto-vena caval line doesn't divide the caudate lobe and quadrangular lobe. The caudate lobe is posterior on the liver, while the quadrangular lobe is in the left lobe.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about skin?

choices.text: Skin accounts for 15% of total body weight
Dermis is made up of type 1 and type 3 collagen

questions.solution:
Correct Option - A: Dermis is derived from ectoderm: This statement is false. The dermis is not derived from ectoderm but rather from mesoderm. During embryonic development, the dermis is formed from mesodermal cells that migrate into the developing skin.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option B - Skin accounts for 15% of total body weight: Skin weight varies based on age, sex, and body composition, usually constituting around 7% to 15% of total body weight in adults.

Option C - Epidermis is derived from ectoderm: The epidermis, which is the outermost layer of the skin, is derived from the ectodermal germ layer during embryonic development.

Option D - Dermis is made up of type 1 and type 3 collagen: The dermis contains collagen fibers, primarily type 1 and type 3, providing strength, support, and elasticity to the skin.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not derived from the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Linea semilunaris: The linea semilunaris, also known as the semilunar line, is a curved, fibrous line on the lateral abdominal wall that represents the transition zone between the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle and the rectus sheath.

Incorrect Options :

Option A - Pectineal ligament:

  • The pectineal ligament, or Cooper's ligament, arises from the external oblique's aponeurosis and provides support to the inguinal region.

Option B - Inguinal ligament:

  • The inguinal ligament, also known as Poupart's ligament, is derived from the lower border of the aponeurosis of the external oblique muscle.

Option C - Lacunar ligament:

  • The lacunar ligament, known as Gimbernat's ligament, is derived from the lower border of the external oblique muscle's aponeurosis and contributes to the formation of the femoral ring and the inguinal ligament.

questions.text: Which lobe of the prostate is responsible for the formation of the uvula vesicae?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: Median lobe: The median lobe of the prostate is the correct answer. It is a small, middle portion of the prostate that projects into the bladder and forms the uvula vesicae. The uvula vesicae is a smooth, rounded elevation located in the internal base of the bladder.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option A: Anterior lobe: The anterior lobe of the prostate does not specifically form the uvula vesicae. The anterior lobe is a small part of the prostate that lies in front of the urethra, but it does not contribute to the formation of the uvula vesicae.

Option B: Posterior lobe: The posterior lobe of the prostate also does not form the uvula vesicae. The posterior lobe is the largest part of the prostate and it surrounds the ejaculatory ducts, but it is not directly involved in the formation of the uvula vesicae.

Option D: Lateral lobes: The lateral lobes of the prostate do not form the uvula vesicae. They are the largest and most prominent parts of the prostate gland that are located on either side of the urethra, but they do not contribute to the formation of the uvula vesicae.

questions.text: Foot drop is caused by damage to:
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Common peroneal nerve:

Foot drop is commonly caused by damage to the common peroneal nerve, also known as the common fibular nerve. The common peroneal nerve innervates the muscles responsible for ankle dorsiflexion and foot eversion. Damage to this nerve can occur due to various factors such as trauma, compression, nerve entrapment, or underlying medical conditions.
 

Incorrect Option:

Option B: Femoral nerve:

The femoral nerve primarily innervates the muscles of the anterior thigh, including the quadriceps femoris muscle group. It is not directly responsible for ankle dorsiflexion or foot drop.

Option C: Tibial nerve:

The tibial nerve innervates the muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg, including the calf muscles that are involved in ankle plantar flexion. Damage to the tibial nerve may result in difficulty with plantar flexion but is not a common cause of foot drop.

Option D: Sciatic nerve:

The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body and consists of two components: the tibial nerve and the common peroneal nerve. While damage to the sciatic nerve can potentially cause foot drop, it is more specifically attributed to damage to the common peroneal nerve, which is a branch of the sciatic nerve.

questions.text: Which of the statements below accurately describes De Quervain's tenosynovitis?

choices.text: Fingers are held in mild extension
Most common involvement is index finger

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: It affects APL and EPB: This statement is correct. De Quervain's tenosynovitis specifically affects the tendons of the abductor pollicis longus (APL) and extensor pollicis brevis (EPB). These tendons run along the thumb side of the wrist and are responsible for thumb movement

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Fingers are held in mild extension: This is incorrect. In De Quervain's tenosynovitis, the affected fingers are typically flexed, not extended.

Option C: Most common involvement is index finger: This is incorrect. De Quervain's tenosynovitis mainly affects the thumb side of the wrist, involving the tendons of APL and EPB, and doesn't usually involve the index finger.

Option D: Treatment is surgery: This is incorrect. Surgery isn't usually the first treatment for De Quervain's tenosynovitis. Initially, conservative measures like rest, splinting, anti-inflammatory medication, and physical therapy are attempted.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked B in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Fornix

The fornix is a bundle of nerve fibers that plays a crucial role in the limbic system and is involved in memory and spatial navigation. It connects various parts of the brain, including the hippocampus and mammillary bodies. This is the structure marked as B in the image.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Pineal gland

The pineal gland is a small endocrine gland located near the center of the brain, but it is not the structure marked in the image.

Option B - Falx cerebri

The falx cerebri is a fold of dura mater that separates the two cerebral hemispheres. It is not the structure marked in the image.

Option D - Pituitary gland

The pituitary gland is an endocrine gland located at the base of the brain, but it is not the structure marked in the image.

questions.text: 1st pharyngeal arch gives rise to all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Levator veli palatini:

This structure is not derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch. The levator veli palatini muscle is actually derived from the 4th pharyngeal arch. It forms part of the soft palate and helps elevate the soft palate during swallowing.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Medial pterygoids: The medial pterygoid muscles, from the 1st pharyngeal arch, aid in jaw movement during chewing, situated in the back of the oral cavity.

Option C - Lateral pterygoids: The lateral pterygoid muscles, from the 1st pharyngeal arch, assist in jaw movement, mainly in opening the mouth, situated in the oral cavity's lateral walls.

Option D - Tensor veli palatini: The tensor veli palatini muscle, from the 1st pharyngeal arch, is in the soft palate, helping control the Eustachian tube during swallowing and yawning.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of the curare group of muscle relaxants?

choices.text: Competitively blocking the binding of ACh to its receptors
Repetitive stimulation of ACh receptors on muscle endplate
Inhibiting the calcium channels on presynaptic membrane

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Competitively blocking the binding of ACh to its receptors:

  • These drugs competitively bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, preventing the binding of acetylcholine (ACh) and thereby inhibiting muscle contraction.

Incorrect Options: Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following intravenous anesthetics does not result in myocardial depression?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Etomidate

 Etomidate: · No effect on BP Cardiac output or coronary perfusion

Incorrect Options:

Options B,  C and D are incorrect. 

 Propofol,  Thiopentone, Ketamine are known to cause myocardial depression to varying degrees as part of their pharmacological effects. (all 3 act on GABA receptors)

Option B - Propofol: Propofol has a dose-dependent depressant effect on myocardial contractility and can also cause peripheral vasodilation, leading to decreased preload and afterload on the heart. Additionally, propofol can directly inhibit cardiac contractility by affecting intracellular calcium handling and reducing calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. 

Option C - Thiopentone: Thiopentone decreases systemic vascular resistance, which can lead to reduced preload and afterload on the heart. Additionally, it can directly depress myocardial contractility by reducing the sensitivity of cardiac myofilaments to calcium, impairing excitation-contraction coupling.

Option D-  Ketamine: ↑HR, ↑BP, ↑CO, Myocardial O2 Consumption

questions.text: Which of the following is not used for induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Desflurane:

  • Desflurane is not commonly used for the induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients.
  • It is mainly used for the maintenance of anesthesia due to its pungent odor and potential airway irritation during induction.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are used for the induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients.

questions.text: Which of the following agents does not elicit pain on injection?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ketamine

  • Ketamine is known for its unique pharmacological properties, including its analgesic effects. It has a less painful injection compared to other intravenous agents.

 

Option B: Propofol

  • Propofol is associated with pain on injection. It can cause a burning or stinging sensation at the injection site. To mitigate this, propofol is often mixed with lidocaine or administered through a larger vein or with the use of a local anesthetic block.

Option C: Etomidate

  • Etomidate is also associated with pain on injection. It can cause discomfort and burning at the injection site. Similar to propofol, methods like dilution, premedication with lidocaine, or administration through larger veins can reduce the pain.

Option D: Thiopentone

  • Thiopentone can cause pain on injection. It is a barbiturate anesthetic and may lead to a burning or stinging sensation at the injection site. Techniques such as dilution or premedication with lidocaine may be employed to minimize the pain.

questions.text: Which among the following is most commonly used to monitor the depth of anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Bispectral index (BIS):

  • The BIS is a monitoring tool that combines various parameters, including EEG activity, to provide a numerical value that correlates with the depth of anesthesia.
  • It is widely used in clinical practice to guide the administration of anesthesia and ensure the patient remains at an appropriate level of unconsciousness.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - EEG (Electroencephalogram):

  • EEG measures brain electrical activity and can gauge anesthesia depth, but it's not the primary method for monitoring anesthesia depth.

Option B - Provoked lower esophageal contractility:

  • Monitoring lower esophageal contractility isn't commonly used to assess anesthesia depth, although it might be relevant in certain situations.

Option C - Entropy:

  • Entropy monitoring analyzes brainwave activity to indicate anesthesia depth, but it's less common compared to the Bispectral index (BIS).

questions.text: Which of the following is measured by the device shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Oxygen saturation:

  • The device shown in the image is a pulse oximeter, which is used to measure the oxygen saturation level in the blood. It provides a numerical value, typically expressed as a percentage, indicating the percentage of hemoglobin in the blood that is saturated with oxygen.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Oxygen content of the blood:

  • The pulse oximeter measures oxygen saturation, not the actual oxygen content in the blood.

Option C - Partial pressure of oxygen:

  • The pulse oximeter measures oxygen saturation, not the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2).

Option D - Amount of inspired oxygen:

  • The pulse oximeter only measures blood oxygen saturation, not the amount or concentration of inspired oxygen.

questions.text: During pregnancy, during which trimester is acute fatty liver most commonly observed?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C:Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) is a rare but serious condition that can occur during pregnancy. It typically manifests most commonly in the third trimester, although it can occur in the second trimester as well. The condition is characterized by the accumulation of fat in the liver, leading to liver dysfunction and potential complications for both the mother and the baby.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A: First trimester: AFLP is not commonly seen in the first trimester of pregnancy. While liver-related complications can occur during pregnancy, AFLP specifically tends to manifest most commonly in the later stages of pregnancy, particularly the third trimester.

Option B: Second trimester: Although AFLP is less common in the second trimester compared to the third trimester, it can still occur during this period. However, the third trimester is the time when AFLP is most commonly observed. The second trimester is generally considered a relatively low-risk period for AFLP compared to the later stages of pregnancy.

Option D: Both a and b: This option suggests that acute fatty liver (AFLP) can manifest most commonly during both the first and second trimesters of pregnancy. However, this is not accurate.

questions.text: What is correct regarding alterations in the vagina during a typical pregnancy?

choices.text: Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B) Increased glycogen metabolism in the epithelium:

This statement is true. The hormonal changes during pregnancy, particularly the increased levels of estrogen, promote glycogen production in the vaginal epithelial cells. Glycogen serves as a source of nutrients for Lactobacilli, helping them to maintain a healthy vaginal environment.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A) Decreased number of Lactobacilli: This statement is incorrect. Lactobacilli are the dominant bacteria found in a healthy vagina, and they play a crucial role in maintaining a slightly acidic pH and preventing the overgrowth of harmful bacteria. During pregnancy, the number of Lactobacilli tends to remain stable or may even increase.

Option C) pH > 6.8: This statement is incorrect. In a normal pregnancy, the vaginal pH remains acidic, typically below 4.5, rather than becoming alkaline or having a pH greater than 6.8. The presence of Lactobacilli, which produces lactic acid, helps maintain the acidic pH of the vagina and provides a protective barrier against potential infections.

Option D) Epithelial thinning: This statement is incorrect. In a normal pregnancy, the vaginal epithelium undergoes certain changes to adapt to hormonal fluctuations, but it does not thin out. The increased estrogen levels during pregnancy can cause the vaginal epithelium to become thicker, more pliable, and better vascularized.

questions.text: During a routine ultrasound scan at 16 weeks, you identify indications of cardiac malformation in a fetus. At what fasting blood sugar level would you begin to suspect overt diabetes?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B: 126 mg/dL: A fasting blood sugar level of 126 mg/dL or higher is the generally accepted threshold for suspecting overt diabetes. If a person's fasting blood sugar level consistently meets or exceeds this value on two separate occasions, it may indicate the presence of diabetes.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A) 106 mg/dL: A fasting blood sugar level of 106 mg/dL is not typically considered the minimum level at which overt diabetes can be suspected. The diagnostic threshold for diabetes is generally set at 126 mg/dL or higher, as mentioned earlier.

Option C) 116 mg/dL: A fasting blood sugar level of 116 mg/dL is not commonly used as the threshold for suspecting overt diabetes. The diagnostic criterion typically requires a level of 126 mg/dL or higher.

Option D) 130 mg/dL: A fasting blood sugar level of 130 mg/dL is also not typically used as the minimum level at which overt diabetes can be suspected. The diagnostic threshold is generally set at 126 mg/dL or higher.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 45-year-old woman who has a lower abdominal mass and discomfort, with an examination revealing a uniformly enlarged uterus and free adnexa, and an MRI showing the presence of a myometrial cyst?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Adenomyosis:

  • Adenomyosis is a condition characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue within the muscular wall of the uterus (myometrium). It can lead to a uniformly enlarged uterus and is associated with symptoms such as lower abdominal discomfort, heavy menstrual bleeding, and menstrual cramps. The presence of a myometrial cyst, as seen on the MRI, is consistent with adenomyosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Endometriosis: Endometriosis refers to the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, commonly involving the pelvic organs and peritoneal cavity.

Option C - Leiomyoma: Leiomyomastypically present as well-defined, solid masses within the uterus, rather than myometrial cysts as described in the case.

Option D - Endometrial hyperplasia:Endometrial hyperplasia can cause abnormal uterine bleeding but is not typically associated with a lower abdominal mass or the presence of myometrial cysts.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options experiences a decrease during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option C: Functional residual capacity:.Functional residual capacity (FRC), decreases during pregnancy. As the uterus expands, it elevates the diaphragm, leading to reduced lung expansion and decreased FRC. This reduction in FRC is primarily due to the displacement of the diaphragm by the growing uterus.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A) Respiratory rate:.Respiratory rate,typically remains unchanged or may slightly increase during pregnancy.

Option B) Vital capacity: Vital capacity, which represents the maximum amount of air a person can exhale after a maximal inhalation, generally increases during pregnancy. The growing uterus pushes upward, which allows for greater expansion of the chest and lungs, resulting in increased vital capacity.
Option D) Inspiratory capacity: Inspiratory capacity, representing the maximum volume of air a person can inhale after a normal exhalation, typically increases during pregnancy. The increased chest and lung expansion allows for greater inspiratory capacity.

questions.text: Which of the following does not pose a contraindication for the initiation of labor?

choices.text: History of lower transverse cesarean section in last two pregnancies

questions.solution:
Correct Option :

Option C) Intrauterine Growth Restriction : Intrauterine Growth Restriction is not a contraindication for the induction of labor. However, it is important to consider the specific type and severity of Intrauterine Growth Restriction, as well as the overall health status of the mother. In some cases, certain heart conditions may require special monitoring and management during labor and delivery.
​​​​​​​

Incorrect options :

Option A) Pelvic tumor: A pelvic tumor can be a contraindication for the induction of labor, depending on the size, location, and nature of the tumor. The presence of a large pelvic tumor may obstruct the birth canal and make a vaginal delivery difficult or impossible. In such cases, a cesarean section may be recommended.

Option B) Herpes infection: Active genital herpes infection, particularly during labor, can pose a risk of transmitting the virus to the newborn. In such cases, if there are active lesions or symptoms of herpes, a cesarean section may be recommended to reduce the risk of transmission.


Option D) History of lower transverse cesarean section in the last two pregnancies: A history of lower transverse cesarean section in previous pregnancies does not necessarily contraindicate the induction of labor. The decision to induce labor in subsequent pregnancies after a previous cesarean section would depend on various factors, such as the reason for the previous cesarean, the presence of any complications or risks, and the overall health of the mother and baby.

questions.text: What is the grade of placenta previa depicted in the provided image?
questions.solution:
Correct option : 

Option B: The given image shows grade 3 placenta previa. Grade 3 placenta previa is characterized by the placenta partially covering the opening of theInternal os. It means that the edge of the placenta reaches but does not completely cover theInternal os.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A) Option A: IV (Grade 4) - Grade 4 placenta previa is characterized by complete coverage of the opening of the internal os by the placenta.

Option C) Option C: II (Grade 2) - Grade 2 placenta previa is characterized by the placenta reaching the Internal os but not covering the opening.


Option D) Option D: I (Grade 1) - Grade 1 placenta previa indicates that the placenta is located in the lower part of the uterus but does not reach or cover the internal os.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a normal physiological change during pregnancy?

choices.text: Mild ST changes in inferior leads

questions.solution:
Correct option: 

Option D) Pansystolic murmur: Pansystolic murmur is not a normal physiological change in pregnancy. A pansystolic murmur, also known as a holosystolic murmur, is typically indicative of abnormal blood flow or structural abnormalities in the heart valves, such as mitral regurgitation or tricuspid regurgitation.

 

Incorrect options :

Option A) Left axis deviation: Left axis deviation can be a normal physiological change in pregnancy due to the upward displacement of the diaphragm caused by the growing uterus. However, it is essential to rule out any underlying cardiac conditions if left axis deviation is present.

Option B) Mild ST changes in inferior leads: Mild ST changes, such as slight ST segment depression or T-wave inversion, can be normal findings in the inferior leads of the electrocardiogram (ECG) during pregnancy. These changes are believed to be related to hemodynamic and hormonal alterations in pregnancy.
Option C) Atrial and ventricular premature contractions: Atrial and ventricular premature contractions, which represent irregular heartbeats originating from the atria or ventricles, can be normal physiological changes in pregnancy. These premature contractions are often associated with the increased blood volume and hormonal changes during pregnancy. However, it is important to differentiate them from more significant or frequent premature contractions that may indicate an underlying cardiac condition.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a pregnant woman at 28 weeks of gestation, who has a fibroid uterus and is experiencing intense abdominal pain, but no fever, with a WBC count of 8000 cells/ul?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for a pregnant woman at 28 weeks of gestation, experiencing intense abdominal pain, with a fibroid uterus, but no fever and a normal WBC count, could be:

Option A. Red degeneration of fibroid

Explanation:

Option A. Red degeneration of fibroid: Correct. Red degeneration of a fibroid occurs due to inadequate blood supply, leading to hemorrhage and necrosis within the fibroid tissue. It can cause severe abdominal pain, especially during pregnancy when fibroids may undergo changes due to increased vascularity. This condition does not typically cause fever or elevated white blood cell count.

Option B. Preterm labor: Less likely. Preterm labor can cause abdominal pain during pregnancy, but it is not directly related to the presence of a fibroid. Preterm labor can be associated with uterine contractions, back pain, and a change in vaginal discharge.

Option C. Torsion of fibroid: Less likely. Torsion of a fibroid, where the fibroid twists on its pedicle, can cause severe pain. However, this is a relatively rare event. Torsion of a fibroid can lead to ischemia and necrosis, causing intense pain. It may or may not be associated with fever, depending on the presence of infection.

Option D. None of the above: Red degeneration of fibroid is a possible diagnosis based on the symptoms described.

questions.text: In the management of mastitis in a breastfeeding mother, what is the initial treatment approach?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A) Dicloxacillin: Dicloxacillin, a penicillinase-resistant penicillin, is a commonly used first-line antibiotic for the treatment of mastitis in lactating mothers. It is effective against Staphylococcus aureus, including methicillin-resistant strains (MRSA), which are the most common causative organisms of mastitis.

 

Incorrect options:

Option B) Cefazolin: Cefazolin is a cephalosporin antibiotic that may have activity against the bacteria involved in mastitis, including Staphylococcus aureus. However, penicillinase-resistant penicillins, such as dicloxacillin, are generally preferred as the first-line treatment for mastitis.

 

Option C) Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is another cephalosporin antibiotic that may have activity against the bacteria involved in mastitis. However, it is not typically recommended as the first-line treatment for mastitis in lactating mothers. Penicillinase-resistant penicillins, such as dicloxacillin, are generally preferred.


OptionD) Ampicillin: Ampicillin is a broad-spectrum penicillin antibiotic. While it may have some activity against the bacteria involved in mastitis, it is not specifically indicated as the first-line treatment. Penicillinase-resistant penicillins, such as dicloxacillin, are generally preferred due to their efficacy against Staphylococcus aureus and MRSA strains commonly associated with mastitis.

questions.text: What is the primary source of amniotic fluid after 20 weeks of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option A) Fetal urine:

After 20 weeks of gestation, the major contributor to the amniotic fluid volume is fetal urine. The fetus produces urine as a byproduct of its metabolic processes. The urine is then excreted into the amniotic sac, contributing to the overall volume of amniotic fluid.

 

Incorrect options:

 

Option B) Fetal skin: While fetal skin does contribute to the production of amniotic fluid through the shedding of cells, it is not the major contributor post 20 weeks. Fetal urine is the primary source of amniotic fluid at this stage.

 

Option C) Fetal lung fluid: Fetal lung fluid, also known as pulmonary fluid or lung secretions, is produced by the fetal lungs. It is present in the amniotic sac before the 20th week of gestation and plays a crucial role in lung development. However, after 20 weeks, fetal urine becomes the primary source of amniotic fluid.


OptionD) Maternal plasma: Maternal plasma refers to the fluid component of the mother's blood. While maternal plasma can contribute to the amniotic fluid volume to some extent, it is not the major contributor post 20 weeks. Fetal urine surpasses the contribution of maternal plasma in maintaining amniotic fluid levels.

questions.text: In low ovarian reserve, what would be the level of the anti-Mullerian hormone?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A) <1:

  • Anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) is a hormone produced by the ovarian follicles, and it is often used as a marker of ovarian reserve. Ovarian reserve refers to the number and quality of remaining eggs in the ovaries. A low ovarian reserve indicates a diminished number of eggs available for ovulation.
  • In cases of low ovarian reserve, the level of anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) is typically less than 1 ng/mL.

 

Incorrect options:

Option B) 1-4: This range is not indicative of low ovarian reserve. AMH levels within this range suggest a moderate to normal ovarian reserve.

Option C) >7: AMH levels greater than 7 ng/mL are not consistent with low ovarian reserve. Higher levels typically indicate a good ovarian reserve.

Option D) >10: AMH levels greater than 10 ng/mL are also not indicative of low ovarian reserve. Such levels are considered high and suggest a good ovarian reserve.

questions.text: What is the highest dosage of PGF2 alpha recommended for treating postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B) 2 mg

Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) is a significant cause of maternal morbidity and mortality. Prostaglandin F2 alpha (PGF2 alpha) is one of the medications used to manage PPH by promoting uterine contraction and reducing bleeding.

The maximum recommended dose of PGF2 alpha for postpartum hemorrhage is 2 mg. This dose is typically administered either intramuscularly or intravenously, depending on the clinical situation.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A) 0.25 mg: This dose is much lower than the maximum recommended dose for PGF2 alpha in postpartum hemorrhage. It may not provide the desired therapeutic effect in managing significant bleeding.

 

Option C) 20 mg: This dose is excessively high and exceeds the maximum recommended dose for PGF2 alpha in postpartum hemorrhage. Such a high dose can lead to adverse effects and complications.


OptionD) 200 mg: Similarly, this dose is extremely high and far beyond the maximum recommended dose for PGF2 alpha in postpartum hemorrhage. Administering such a high dose can be dangerous and increase the risk of adverse reactions.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not considered a gestational trophoblastic neoplasm?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Partial Mole: 

Partial Mole: partial mole is not a type of Gestational trophoblastic neoplasm.

Malignant form of Gestational trophoblastic neoplasm include:

  1. Invasive mole
  2. choriocarcinoma
  3. placental site trophoblastic tumor
  4. epithelioid trophoblastic tumor

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Choriocarcinoma: Choriocarcinoma is a type of gestational trophoblastic neoplasm. It is an aggressive and malignant tumor that develops from trophoblastic cells.

Option C - Placental site trophoblastic tumor: Placental site trophoblastic tumor is another type of gestational trophoblastic neoplasm. It arises from trophoblastic cells at the implantation site of the placenta.
Option D - Invasive mole : Invasive mole is also a type of gestational trophoblastic neoplasm. It is characterized by the invasion of trophoblastic cells into the uterine wall.

questions.text: What is the condition of the mother if the baby's appearance indicates that it was born at 34 weeks of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct option :

Option A) Gestational diabetes:

Gestational diabetes is a condition characterized by high blood sugar levels that develop during pregnancy. It occurs when the body is unable to produce enough insulin to meet the increased demands of pregnancy. If gestational diabetes is not well controlled, it can result in the baby growing larger than expected for their gestational age, a condition known as macrosomia.

 

Incorrect options:

Option B) Rubella: Rubella, also known as German measles, is a viral infection that can cause various birth defects if a pregnant woman becomes infected during pregnancy. However, the appearance of the baby alone cannot definitively indicate that the mother has rubella.

 

Option C) Hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism refers to an underactive thyroid gland, which can affect the mother's health during pregnancy. While hypothyroidism can lead to certain complications in the baby, such as low birth weight or developmental issues, it typically does not result in a baby being large for gestational age.


OptionD) Gestational hypertension: Gestational hypertension refers to high blood pressure that develops during pregnancy. While gestational hypertension can lead to complications for both the mother and the baby, it does not directly cause the baby to be large for gestational age.

questions.text: Which hormone acts on the endometrium after ovulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Progesterone:

  • After ovulation, the ruptured follicle transforms into a structure called the corpus luteum.
  • The corpus luteum produces progesterone, which is the hormone primarily responsible for preparing and maintaining the endometrium (the lining of the uterus) for potential implantation of a fertilized egg.
  • Progesterone helps to thicken the endometrium, increase its blood supply, and create a favorable environment for implantation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Luteinizing hormone (LH): LH plays a crucial role in triggering ovulation, which occurs around day 14 of the menstrual cycle. LH surge stimulates the release of the mature egg from the follicle.  

Option B - Follicular stimulating hormone (FSH): FSH stimulates the growth and development of ovarian follicles during the early phase of the menstrual cycle. It helps to promote the maturation of the egg within the follicle.

OptionD - Estrogen: Estrogen is mainly involved in the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle, preceding ovulation. It helps to rebuild and thicken the endometrium.

questions.text: What is an absolute contraindication to the use of oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Thromboembolism:

  • Thromboembolism includes conditions like deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE). OCPs containing estrogen have been associated with an increased risk of blood clot formation, and individuals with a history of thromboembolism are at higher risk for recurrence if they use OCPs.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A - Chronic renal disease: Chronic renal disease, or chronic kidney disease, is not an absolute contraindication to OCP use. However, caution may be required, and the use of OCPs should be done, considering factors like the severity of renal disease, the presence of complications, and individual patient characteristics.

Options C - History of amenorrhea: Amenorrhea refers to the absence of menstrual periods. While it may indicate an underlying hormonal imbalance or reproductive issue, it is not a contraindication to OCP use. In fact, OCPs are sometimes prescribed to regulate menstrual cycles and manage certain hormonal conditions causing amenorrhea.

Options D - Diabetes mellitus: Diabetes mellitus is not an absolute contraindication to OCP use. However, it is important to consider the individual's overall health status, any associated complications, and the potential impact of OCPs on blood sugar control. Close monitoring and adjustment of diabetes management may be necessary in individuals with diabetes who use OCPs.

questions.text: What is the specific chromosome count observed in a partial hydatidiform mole?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 69 XXY:

  • A partial hydatidiform mole, also known as a partial molar pregnancy, is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease characterized by abnormal development of the placenta.
  • The chromosome number of a partial hydatidiform mole is typically 69, with two sets of paternal chromosomes (from the father) and one set of maternal chromosomes (from the mother).
  • Karyotype can be 69XXX, 69XXY, 69XYY, but never 69YYY

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 46 XX: A normal karyotype for a female individual is 46 XX, which represents two sets of chromosomes (one set from each parent) and indicates a typical female chromosomal configuration.  

Option B - 45 XY: A 45 XY karyotype is indicative of Turner syndrome, a genetic disorder characterized by the complete or partial absence of one X chromosome in individuals assigned male at birth.

OptionC - 69 XY: A 69 XY karyotype represents a triploid condition with two sets of paternal chromosomes and one set of maternal chromosomes. However, this chromosomal configuration is not specific to a partial hydatidiform mole.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment for a 55-year-old woman who is experiencing third-degree uterine prolapse?

choices.text: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Vaginal Hysterectomy with Pelvic Floor Repair:

  • A third-degree uterine prolapse occurs when the uterus has descended to or beyond the vaginal opening. In a 55-year-old postmenopausal woman who is experiencing this degree of prolapse, vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair is the most appropriate treatment.

  • Vaginal hysterectomy is the removal of the uterus through the vaginal route, which is commonly recommended in cases of uterine prolapse, especially when future childbearing is not a concern (e.g., in postmenopausal women).
  • Pelvic floor repair (also called pelvic reconstructive surgery) involves repairing the weakened pelvic tissues that caused the prolapse. This may include procedures like anterior and posterior colporrhaphy (repair of the vaginal walls) and perineorrhaphy (repair of the perineum) to restore pelvic support.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fothergill Repair:

  • This procedure is used for uterine prolapse but is typically performed in younger women who wish to preserve their uterus and maintain fertility.
  • The cervix is amputated, and the uterosacral ligaments are attached to the cervical stump to provide support.
  • In a 55-year-old woman, especially postmenopausal, fertility is not a concern, and uterine preservation is unnecessary. Therefore, vaginal hysterectomy is the more appropriate treatment.

Option B - Sling Operation:

  • A sling operation is also primarily used for stress urinary incontinence and involves the placement of a supportive sling around the urethra to improve urinary control. It is not the best management option for uterine prolapse alone.

Option D - Shirodkar Procedure:

  • The Shirodkar procedure is a surgical technique used for cervical incompetence and involves the placement of a permanent suture around the cervix to strengthen it and prevent premature opening. It is not indicated for uterine prolapse management.

questions.text: In emergency contraception, what is the recommended dosage of Ulipristal?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 30 mg:

  • Ulipristal acetate is a medication used for emergency contraception. The recommended dose for emergency contraception is a single oral dose of 30 mg. This dose has been shown to be effective in inhibiting or delaying ovulation when taken within 72 hrs (upto 120 hrs)after unprotected intercourse.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D: These options are incorrect

questions.text: When is the optimal period to assess nuchal translucency?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option B: 11-14 weeks : Nuchal translucency (NT) evaluation is a prenatal screening test used to assess the risk of certain chromosomal abnormalities, particularly Down syndrome (trisomy 21). The ideal time for NT evaluation is between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation.

 

During this time, the fetus is at a specific stage of development where the nuchal translucency, which is the fluid-filled space at the back of the fetal neck, can be accurately measured. This measurement, along with other factors like maternal age and blood test results, is used to calculate the risk of chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A: 6-8 weeks: It is too early for accurate NT evaluation as the fetal structures necessary for the measurement are not fully developed.

Option C: 14-16 weeks : It is beyond the optimal time frame for NT evaluation. While some additional ultrasound assessments can be performed during this period, the NT measurement is typically done earlier.
Option D: 16-20 weeks: It is outside the recommended time frame for NT evaluation. At this stage, other ultrasound assessments, such as the detailed anatomy scan, are performed, but NT evaluation is not typically included.

questions.text: Magnesium sulphate has no role in which of the following ?

choices.text: Prevention of seizures in severe pre-eclampsia
Prevention of recurrent seizures in eclampsia

questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Prevention of RDS (Respiratory Distress Syndrome) in premature babies :

  • Magnesium sulfate does not have a direct role in preventing or treating RDS in premature infants.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Prevention of seizures in severe pre-eclampsia: Magnesium sulfate is commonly used as a first-line treatment for preventing seizures in pregnant women with severe pre-eclampsia.

Option B- Prevention of recurrent seizures in eclampsia: Magnesium sulfate is also used for the prevention of recurrent seizures in women who have already experienced eclampsia. It helps control and prevent further seizures, improving the safety and well-being of both the mother and the baby.

Option D- Reducing contractility of the uterus: Magnesium sulfate is also used as a tocolytic agent to reduce the contractility of the uterus. It is sometimes administered to pregnant women experiencing preterm labor to delay delivery and allow for the administration of corticosteroids to improve fetal lung maturity.

questions.text: In the vertex presentation with complete flexion attitude of the head, which of the following is observed?
questions.solution:
Correct option: Option A: Suboccipito-bregmatic diameter: In a vertex presentation with complete flexion of the head, the fetal head is in a position where the chin is touching or close to the chest. This position allows for the smallest diameter of the fetal head, known as the suboccipito-bregmatic diameter, to be presented at the maternal pelvic inlet.

 

Incorrect options:

Option B. Suboccipito-frontal diameter: This diameter refers to the distance between the suboccipital point (back of the head) and the forehead. It is not specifically associated with the complete flexion of the head seen in vertex presentations.

 

Option C. Occipito-frontal diameter: This diameter measures the distance between the occiput (back of the head) and the forehead. It is larger than the suboccipito-bregmatic diameter and is not specifically associated with complete flexion of the head.


Option  D. Occipito-posterior position: This term refers to a fetal position in which the back of the head (occiput) is facing the mother's back, which is also known as the "sunny side up" position. It is not directly related to the flexion attitude of the head.

questions.text: What is the most suitable treatment option for a pregnant woman who has a history of multiple miscarriages and has been recently diagnosed with antiphospholipid antibody syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct option B: Aspirin + Heparin

This combination is the recommended treatment for pregnant women with antiphospholipid syndrome and a history of recurrent abortions. Aspirin helps prevent platelet aggregation and improve blood flow, while heparin, specifically low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), has anticoagulant effects and helps prevent blood clots. Together, aspirin and heparin have been shown to reduce the risk of recurrent abortions and improve pregnancy outcomes in women with antiphospholipid syndrome.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A. Aspirin only: Aspirin alone is not sufficient for the treatment of antiphospholipid syndrome in pregnancy. While aspirin has antiplatelet effects and can help improve blood flow, it is not enough to prevent the complications associated with antiphospholipid syndrome.

 

Option C. Heparin + Steroids: Steroids are usually reserved for specific situations where there is a high risk of complications, such as severe placental insufficiency or intrauterine growth restriction. But Aspirin helps prevent platelet aggregation and improve blood flow.


OptionD. Aspirin + Steroids: Similar to the previous option, the combination of aspirin and steroids alone is not considered the best mode of treatment for antiphospholipid syndrome in pregnancy. Steroids may have a role in certain high-risk cases, but they are not the primary treatment modality.

questions.text: What should be the subsequent approach to treat a pregnant woman, aged 22, who continues to have a fever despite being prescribed antibiotics, and is later diagnosed with septic pelvic thrombophlebitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Antibiotics + Heparin:

  • The standard management for septic pelvic thrombophlebitis involves a combination of broad-spectrum antibiotics to treat the underlying infection and anticoagulation therapy (usually with heparin) to prevent the extension of thrombosis and reduce the risk of complications.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Stop antibiotics and start heparin - This option is not appropriate because septic pelvic thrombophlebitis is a severe infection that requires both antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy. Stopping antibiotics would not address the underlying infection.

Option C - Surgical embolectomy - Surgical embolectomy is not the first-line treatment for septic pelvic thrombophlebitis. It may be considered in cases of severe sepsis or if there is no response to medical therapy, but it is not typically the initial course of treatment.

Option D - Hysterectomy - Hysterectomy is not the primary treatment for septic pelvic thrombophlebitis. It may be considered in cases of severe infection or if there are specific indications for hysterectomy, such as uncontrolled bleeding or uterine pathology, but it is not the first-line treatment for septic pelvic thrombophlebitis.

questions.text: For a woman experiencing itching due to atrophic vaginitis, which treatment option is preferred?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Topical estrogen:

  • Atrophic vaginitis is a condition characterized by inflammation and thinning of the vaginal tissues due to decreased estrogen levels, commonly seen in postmenopausal women. The mainstay of treatment for atrophic vaginitis is topical estrogen therapy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Steroids are not the treatment of choice for atrophic vaginitis. While steroids may have anti-inflammatory properties and can provide temporary relief from itching, they do not address the underlying cause of atrophic vaginitis.

Option C - Antihistamines are primarily used to relieve allergic symptoms and are not the appropriate treatment for atrophic vaginitis. While antihistamines may help alleviate itching, they do not address the underlying hormonal changes.

Option D - "None of the above" is incorrect because topical estrogen therapy, represented by option B, is indeed the treatment of choice for atrophic vaginitis.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with itchy lesions on her arm as shown. Her family history is positive for asthma. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Atopic dermatitis:

  • Atopic dermatitis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by itchy, red, and inflamed skin lesions. It commonly affects individuals with a family history of asthma, allergic rhinitis, or atopic dermatitis .

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Seborrheic dermatitis: Seborrheic dermatitis primarily affects areas rich in sebaceous glands, such as the scalp, face, and chest. It typically presents with greasy, yellowish scales.

Option C - Allergic contact dermatitis: Allergic contact dermatitis occurs when the skin comes into direct contact with an allergen, leading to an allergic reaction.

Option D - Erysipelas: Erysipelas is a bacterial skin infection characterized by a raised, red, and tender rash. It is typically caused by Streptococcus pyogenes and presents with well-defined borders.

questions.text: Bindi Leucoderma is caused by which chemical?

choices.text: Crocein Scarlet MOO and Solvent Yellow 3

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Para Tertiary butylphenol (PTBP):

  • Bindi leukoderma, also known as "sticker dermatitis," is caused by the adhesive used in bindis, particularly the chemical PTBP.
  • PTBP is a sensitizing agent that can induce an allergic reaction in some individuals, leading to depigmentation or leucoderma in the area where bindis are applied.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mono-benzyl ether of Hydroquinone (MBH): MBH is not directly associated with bindi leukoderma. While hydroquinone and its derivatives have been implicated in some cases of depigmentation.

Option B - Crocein Scarlet MOO and Solvent Yellow 3: They are commonly used in industries such as textiles and not directly linked to the depigmentation seen in bindi leukoderma.

Option C - P-phenylenediamine (PPD): PPD is a chemical found in hair dyes and is known to cause allergic reactions and contact dermatitis

questions.text: What is the most frequently encountered cause of the condition shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Infection:

  • In the case of erythema multiforme, the most common triggering factor is infection.
  • Erythema multiforme is a skin condition characterized by target-like lesions, typically affecting the extremities, mucous membranes, and sometimes the trunk.
  • It is believed to be an immune-mediated reaction triggered by various factors, with infection being the most common cause.
  • Infection, especially viral infections like herpes simplex virus, is the most common triggering factor for erythema multiforme.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vaccination: It is not a common triggering factor..

Option B - Malignancy: It is not a primary triggering factor for erythema multiforme.

Option C - Drugs: Drugs can indeed trigger erythema multiforme in some cases, particularly certain medications like nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), antibiotics (such as sulfonamides and penicillins), and antiepileptic drugs. However, infection remains the most common triggering factor.

questions.text: A young female presented with vaginal itching and green frothy genital discharge. Strawberry vagina is seen on examination. What will be the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Metronidazole :

  • Metronidazole is the drug of choice for the treatment of trichomoniasis. It is an antibiotic with specific activity against anaerobic organisms, including Trichomonas vaginalis.
  • Treatment with metronidazole is administered as a 2 gm single oral dose.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Doxycycline: Doxycycline is more often used to treat sexually transmitted infections such as chlamydia or certain types of bacterial vaginosis.

Option B - Oral fluconazole: Oral fluconazole is an antifungal medication used to treat fungal infections, including vaginal yeast infections.

Option D - Azithromycin: Azithromycin is not the recommended first-line treatment for the specific condition described in the scenario.

questions.text: What is the accurate statement regarding the diagnosis made from the provided image?

choices.text: Trigeminal dermatome is most commonly affected
Anterior nerve roots are more commonly involved
Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved:

  • Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved: In herpes zoster, the involvement of mucous membranes within the affected dermatome is possible.
  • If the dermatome affected by herpes zoster includes mucous membranes, such as the oral or genital mucosa, these areas can develop characteristic vesicles and ulcers

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The lesions are not infectious: The presence of painful grouped vesicles in a single dermatome, as seen in the image, is highly suggestive of herpes zoster, which is an infectious viral condition..

Option B - Trigeminal dermatome is most commonly affected: Herpes zoster can affect dermatomes in decreasing order of frequency thoracic > cervical > Trigeminal > lumbosacral.

Option C - Anterior nerve roots are more commonly involved: In herpes zoster, it is the posterior nerve roots or ganglia that are typically affected by the reactivated varicella-zoster virus.

questions.text: What will be the diagnosis of the image provided below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Candidal intertrigo:

  • Candidal intertrigo: This condition refers to a fungal infection that occurs in moist skin folds, such as between the toes, groin, or fingers.
  • It is characterized by redness, itching, and maceration of the affected area. The image shows candidal intertrigo between the small finger of the foot, which matches the clinical presentation.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Candidal paronychia: This condition refers to a fungal infection that affects the nail folds and surrounding tissues

Option B - Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome: This is a bacterial infection caused by certain strains of Staphylococcus aureus. It typically presents with widespread redness, blistering, and peeling of the skin.

Option D - Diabetic foot ulcer: This term refers to a non-healing ulcer that develops in individuals with diabetes, typically on the feet. It is often associated with poor circulation and neuropathy.

questions.text: What is the common association with the condition depicted below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Pitting of nails:

  • Pitting of nails is a classic finding in alopecia areata. It refers to the presence of small, shallow depressions or indentations on the nail surface. Pitting is thought to result from the localized inflammation affecting the nail matrix in alopecia areata.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Oil drop sign: The oil drop sign is a characteristic finding in psoriasis, not in alopecia areata..

Option B - Leukonychia striata: Leukonychia striata is commonly associated with trauma, nutritional deficiencies, or certain systemic conditions, but not specifically with alopecia areata.

Option C - Pterygium of nails: Pterygium refers to the abnormal overgrowth of the proximal nail fold onto the nail plate.t it is not typically associated with alopecia areata.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Acanthosis nigrican:

  • Acanthosis nigricans is a skin condition characterized by dark, thickened, and velvety patches of skin. It commonly affects areas such as the neck, armpits, groin, and skin folds.
  • It is characterized by thickened, gray brown velvety plaques seen over flexure areas( back of neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist,groin).

Incorrect Options:

Option a - Dermatomyositis: Dermatomyositis is a rare autoimmune disease characterized by muscle weakness and skin rash. The skin rash in dermatomyositis typically appears as a heliotrope rash on the upper eyelids and a Gottron's papules rash on the knuckles, elbows, or knees. It is not represented by the image given.

Option c - Pityriasis rotunda: Pityriasis rotunda is a rare skin disorder characterized by round, scaly patches on the skin. These patches are typically lighter or darker than the surrounding skin and may appear on the trunk, arms, or legs. It is not represented by the image given.

Option d - Melasma: Melasma is a common skin condition characterized by the development of brown or gray-brown patches on the face, particularly on areas exposed to the sun, such as the cheeks, forehead, and upper lip. It is not represented by the image given.

questions.text: In cerebrohepatorenal syndrome, an infant exhibits symptoms of hypotonia and seizures. The condition is characterized by the accumulation of which substance in the brain?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Long chain fatty acid:

  • Long chain fatty acid: Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome, also known as Zellweger syndrome, is a rare genetic disorder that affects the peroxisomes, which are responsible for the breakdown of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFAs). In this syndrome, there is a deficiency of peroxisomal enzymes, leading to the accumulation of VLCFAs, including in the brain.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Glucose: Glucose is the primary energy source for the brain and is not typically accumulated in the brain in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome.

Option C - Lactic acid: Elevated lactic acid levels can occur in various metabolic disorders, but it is not a characteristic feature of this syndrome.

Option D - Triglycerides: Triglycerides are a form of fat and are not specifically accumulated in the brain in cerebrohepatorenal syndrome.

questions.text: Which substrate of the Krebs cycle is diminished by an excess amount of ammonia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Alpha ketoglutarate

  • Alpha ketoglutarate: Excess ammonia can directly reduce alpha ketoglutarate, a key substrate of the Krebs cycle. Ammonia combines with alpha ketoglutarate to form glutamate in a reaction catalyzed by the enzyme glutamate dehydrogenase. This reaction helps in the removal of excess ammonia through the urea cycle.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Malate: Excess ammonia does not directly reduce malate, a substrate of the Krebs cycle. Malate is formed in the Krebs cycle and can be converted back to oxaloacetate.

Option B - Oxaloacetate: Excess ammonia does not directly reduce oxaloacetate, another substrate of the Krebs cycle. Oxaloacetate is an intermediate compound in the cycle and can be converted to malate or used for gluconeogenesis.

Option C - Fumarate: Excess ammonia does not directly reduce fumarate, which is also an intermediate compound in the Krebs cycle. Fumarate is produced from the conversion of malate and is further converted to succinate.

questions.text: Which of the following is autosomal dominant?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Achondroplasia:

  • Autosomal dominant inheritance means that a single copy of the mutated gene is sufficient to cause the disorder.
  • Achondroplasia is caused by a mutation in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3) gene and follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. A single copy of the mutated gene is sufficient to cause the characteristic features of achondroplasia, a form of dwarfism.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder.

Option B - Duchene muscular dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder.

Option C - Sickle cell anemia is also an autosomal recessive disorder.

questions.text: Which enzymes are affected in Menke's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lysyl oxidase

  • Lysyl oxidase is the enzyme affected in Menke's disease. It plays a crucial role in the cross-linking of collagen and elastin fibers, which are essential components of connective tissues.
  • In Menke's disease, the defective copper transport system impairs the delivery of copper to lysyl oxidase, leading to decreased activity of the enzyme. This results in abnormal connective tissue formation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lysyl hydroxylase

  • Lysyl hydroxylase is an enzyme involved in the hydroxylation of lysine residues in collagen molecules. It plays a role in collagen maturation. However, it is not directly affected by Menke's disease.

Option C - Prolyl oxidase

  • Prolyl oxidase is not directly involved in the copper transport system or collagen and elastin cross-linking. Prolyl oxidase catalyzes the oxidation of proline residues in collagen, contributing to collagen stability and structure.

Option D - Prolyl hydroxylase

  • Prolyl hydroxylase is an enzyme involved in the hydroxylation of proline residues in collagen molecules. It is responsible for collagen stability and proper folding.

questions.text: What is the shared precursor amino acid for urea, creatinine, and nitric oxide?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Arginine:

  • Urea: Arginine is a precursor for urea synthesis in the urea cycle. It undergoes a series of enzymatic reactions, eventually leading to the production of urea.
  • Creatinine: Creatinine is derived from creatine phosphate, which is synthesized from arginine in a two-step process. Creatine is first converted to creatine phosphate in the presence of arginine and glycine, and then creatine phosphate spontaneously converts to creatinine.
  • Nitric oxide: Nitric oxide (NO) is synthesized from arginine by the enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS). Arginine serves as the substrate for NOS, which catalyzes the production of NO.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Glycine: Glycine is not a precursor for urea, creatinine, or nitric oxide synthesis.

Option C - Aspartate: Aspartate is involved in the urea cycle as a substrate, but it is not the precursor amino acid for urea, creatinine, or nitric oxide.

Option D - Alanine: Alanine is not directly involved in the synthesis of urea, creatinine, or nitric oxide.

questions.text: True regarding mitochondrial genome:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Maternal inheritance:

  • Maternal inheritance: Mitochondrial DNA is primarily inherited from the mother. During fertilization, the mitochondria from the sperm are typically not passed on to the offspring, while the mitochondria from the mother’s egg are inherited by the child. This results in maternal inheritance of mitochondrial DNA.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Low rate of mutation: Mitochondrial DNA has a higher mutation rate compared to nuclear DNA. This is because mitochondria lack certain DNA repair mechanisms present in the nucleus. The higher mutation rate contributes to genetic diversity and can lead to mitochondrial diseases.

Option C - Single stranded DNA: Mitochondrial DNA is double-stranded, not single-stranded. It contains both coding and non-coding regions necessary for the production of mitochondrial proteins.

Option D - Paternal inheritance: While the paternal mitochondrial DNA is typically not passed on to the offspring, there have been rare cases where paternal transmission of mitochondrial DNA has been observed.

questions.text: After consuming a fatty meal, what is elevated in individuals with lipoprotein lipase deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Chylomicron

  • Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency results in impaired triglyceride breakdown in chylomicrons and VLDL, leading to elevated blood levels of these lipoproteins after a fatty meal.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - LDL metabolism is not directly impacted by LPL deficiency, as LDL primarily transports cholesterol from the liver to peripheral tissues.

Option C - HDL metabolism is not directly affected by LPL deficiency; HDL participates in reverse cholesterol transport.

Option D - Apo A levels are not directly influenced by LPL deficiency; Apo A is a component of HDL involved in its structure and function.

questions.text: Which of the following is reduced in urine in a patient with Wilson's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 3-methylhistidine:

  • Wilson's disease, or hepatolenticular degeneration, is a genetic disorder marked by impaired copper metabolism, causing copper accumulation in tissues like the liver, brain, and cornea.
  • The defect in copper transport into bile leads to its release into the bloodstream and deposition in organs, causing damage and diverse symptoms.
  • 3-methylhistidine levels decrease in urine in Wilson's disease due to impaired copper-dependent lysyl oxidase activity, affecting collagen cross-linking and muscle breakdown.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tyrosine is not specifically related to Wilson's disease, and its levels in urine are not typically affected.

Option B - Phosphorus is not directly associated with Wilson's disease, and its levels in urine are not typically altered.

Option C - Serine is not specifically linked to Wilson's disease, and its levels in urine are not typically affected

questions.text: NADPH is used in which of the following process?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Fatty acid synthesis:

  • NADPH is primarily involved in anabolic processes, including fatty acid synthesis. During fatty acid synthesis, NADPH acts as a reducing agent, providing the necessary reducing equivalents for the synthesis of fatty acids from acetyl-CoA. NADPH is required for the production of malonyl-CoA, the building block of fatty acids, through the action of the enzyme fatty acid synthase.
