Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ketone synthesis: Ketone synthesis occurs primarily in the liver mitochondria and doesn't directly rely on NADPH.

Option C - Gluconeogenesis: Gluconeogenesis synthesizes glucose from non-carbohydrate sources. Though NADPH indirectly affects it through other reactions, it's not directly used.

Option D - Glycolysis: Glycolysis breaks down glucose for energy production. NAD+ is mainly involved in glycolysis's redox reactions, not NADPH.

questions.text: Which of the following does not characterize tubercular otitis media?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ear ache:

  • Tubercular otitis media is a rare form of middle ear infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis Tubercular otitis media often presents with atypical symptoms compared to typical bacterial or viral otitis media.
  • Earache is not a typical feature of tubercular otitis media. In fact, one of the distinguishing characteristics of tubercular otitis media is that it is usually painless. Patients may not experience significant ear pain or discomfort.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Multiple perforations: Multiple perforations of the tympanic membrane (eardrum) are commonly seen in tubercular otitis media. These perforations may appear irregular and may not heal easily.

Option C - Pale granulation: Pale granulation is a characteristic finding in tubercular otitis media. Granulation tissue may be seen in the middle ear, and it tends to have a pale appearance rather than the usual pink or red color associated with inflammation.

Option D - Foul smelling ear discharge: Foul smelling ear discharge, known as otorrhea, is commonly observed in tubercular otitis media. The discharge can be thick, cheesy, and have an unpleasant odor. This is due to the necrotic debris associated with the infection.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is accurate regarding keratosis obturans?

choices.text: Failure of migration of desquamated epithelium along posterior meatal wall
Widening of meatus and facial nerve palsy might be seen

questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) All of the above

Explanation:

  • Keratosis obturans is a rare condition characterized by the accumulation of desquamated epithelium within the external auditory canal.
  • All of the above statements are true about keratosis obturans. It involves the failure of migration of desquamated epithelium along the posterior meatal wall, can lead to widening of the meatus and facial nerve palsy, and in some cases, may be associated with bronchiectasis and sinusitis.

Incorrect Options:

(Option A) Failure of migration of desquamated epithelium along the posterior meatal wall:. In keratosis obturans, there is a failure of the normal migration of desquamated epithelial cells along the posterior meatal wall. As a result, the accumulated debris forms a hard plug or mass in the external auditory canal.

(Option B) Widening of meatus and facial nerve palsy might be seen: In some cases of keratosis obturans, the accumulation of debris and subsequent inflammation can lead to the widening of the external auditory meatus. Additionally, facial nerve palsy may occur due to compression or inflammation of the facial nerve as a result of the mass effect.

(Option C) Associated bronchiectasis and sinusitis: Although less common, there have been reported cases of an association between keratosis obturans and bronchiectasis as well as sinusitis.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes Pott’s puffy tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Subperiosteal abscess of frontal bone:

  • Pott's puffy tumor is a subperiosteal abscess of the frontal bone.
  • Pott's puffy tumor is a rare complication of frontal sinusitis that involves the spread of infection from the frontal sinus to the overlying frontal bone. Pott's puffy tumor refers to a subperiosteal abscess that develops on the frontal bone as a result of the spread of infection from the frontal sinus. It is characterized by localized swelling, erythema, and tenderness of the forehead.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are incorrect and the correct option is explained above.

questions.text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Correct option D. Laryngeal papilloma.

  • The image shows grape-like projections in the anterior part of the larynx, which is a characteristic appearance of laryngeal papilloma. Laryngeal papillomas are benign growths caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.

  • Clinical Features

    Management Options

    Benign growth

    Regular monitoring of growth and symptoms

    Surgical removal of papillomas

    Adjuvant therapies such as laser treatment or cryotherapy

    Caused by HPV infection

    Vaccination against HPV (for prevention)

    Wart-like or grape-like projections

    Voice therapy and vocal cord exercises

    Hoarseness

    Voice therapy and vocal cord exercises

    Surgical removal of papillomas

     

    Stridor

    Breathing difficulties

    Airway management and emergency intervention

Incorrect options:

Option A. Reinke's edema: Reinke's edema refers to a swelling or fluid accumulation within the superficial layer of the vocal cords. It typically results from long-term exposure to irritants, such as smoking or vocal abuse.

Option B. Malignancy: Malignancy refers to the presence of cancerous cells. While cancer can affect the vocal cords, the image does not suggest a malignant lesion. Laryngeal cancer typically presents with different features, such as irregular or ulcerated masses, not grape-like projections.

Option C. Tracheomalacia: Tracheomalacia refers to the weakness or collapse of the tracheal cartilage, which leads to breathing difficulties.

questions.text: What type of lesions are associated with the presence of inspiratory stridor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A. Inspiratory stridor is commonly found in supraglottic lesions.

  • Inspiratory stridor refers to a high-pitched, wheezing sound heard during inspiration. It is caused by the partial obstruction of the upper airway, which disrupts the normal airflow.
  • Supraglottic lesions involve structures above the level of the vocal cords, such as the epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, and false vocal cords. When these structures are affected or swollen, they can cause partial obstruction of the airway during inspiration, resulting in inspiratory stridor.

 

Incorrect options:

Option B. Subglottic: Subglottic lesions refer to abnormalities or obstructions in the area below the vocal cords but above the trachea. While subglottic lesions can cause airway obstruction, they typically result in both inspiratory and expiratory stridor, as they affect airflow in both directions.

Option C. Tracheal: Tracheal lesions specifically involve the trachea, which is the tube connecting the larynx (voice box) to the bronchi. Tracheal lesions can cause a range of respiratory symptoms, but inspiratory stridor is less commonly associated with isolated tracheal lesions.

Option D. Bronchus: Bronchial lesions primarily affect the bronchi, which are the branching tubes that carry air to the lungs. Bronchial lesions are not typically associated with inspiratory stridor as they are located further down the respiratory tract.

questions.text: BCYE medium is used to culture:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Legionella:

  • BCYE (Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract) medium is a specialized culture medium that supports the growth of Legionella bacteria. Legionella is a pathogenic bacterium responsible for causing a severe respiratory illness known as Legionnaires' disease.
  • BCYE medium contains yeast extract, which provides essential growth factors, and activated charcoal, which helps to absorb and neutralize inhibitory substances, buffered salts maintain the appropriate pH. Legionellae grow slowly; visible colonies are usually present after 3 days of incubation. Colonies are round or flat with entire edges. They vary in color from colorless to iridescent pink or blue and are translucent or speckled.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Leptospira: Leptospira is a spirochete bacterium that causes an infectious disease known as leptospirosis. It is typically cultured using specific media such as the Ellinghausen-McCullough-Johnson-Harris (EMJH) medium.

Option B - Bacillus cereus: Bacillus cereus is a gram-positive bacterium that can cause food poisoning. It is cultured on mannitol egg yolk phenol red polymyxin (MYPA) agar.

Option C - Campylobacter: Campylobacter is a genus of bacteria that includes species responsible for gastrointestinal infections, such as Campylobacter jejuni. Campylobacter is commonly cultured using selective media like Skirrow's, Butzlers, or Campy BAP selective medium.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival injection, and hematuria for 15 days. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Microscopic Agglutination Test:

  • The patient's presentation of fever, jaundice, conjunctival injection, and hematuria are classic symptoms of leptospirosis, aka hepatorenal syndrome, aka Weil's disease, caused by leptospira interrogans.
  • Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT) is the specific and most commonly used serological test for diagnosing Leptospirosis. It detects the presence of antibodies against Leptospira bacteria in the patient's serum. The test involves agglutination reactions between the patient's serum and a panel of different Leptospira serovars. A positive result indicates the presence of specific antibodies and confirms the diagnosis of Leptospirosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Widal test: It is primarily used for diagnosing typhoid fever caused by Salmonella typhi and Salmonella paratyphi.

Option C - Weil-Felix reaction: The Weil-Felix reaction is a serological test that uses cross-reacting antigens from different Proteus strains to detect antibodies against rickettsial infections.

Option D - Paul-Bunnell test: The Paul-Bunnell test, also known as the Monospot test, is used for the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).

questions.text: A patient presents with gastrointestinal problems including abdominal pain and distension, bloody and mucus-filled diarrhea, and tenesmus, with rectal prolapse. A stool examination reveals the presence of typical barrel-shaped eggs. What is the possible causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Trichuris Trichiura:

  • Trichuris trichiura also known as whipworm, is a parasitic roundworm that infects the large intestine of humans. The characteristic symptoms of a Trichuris trichiura infection include abdominal pain, distension, bloody and mucus-filled diarrhea (dysentery), tenesmus (the feeling of incomplete evacuation), and rectal prolapse (in severe cases).
  • The presence of typical barrel-shaped eggs in the stool examination is a key diagnostic feature of Trichuris trichiura infection and can be identified microscopically in the feces of infected individuals. These eggs are bile stained, and mucous plugs at both ends that are non-bile stained.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Giardia Lamblia: Giardia lamblia is a protozoan parasite that causes a diarrheal illness known as giardiasis. However, the characteristic symptom of giardiasis is watery diarrhea, not bloody and mucus-filled diarrhea.

Option C - Ascaris Lumbricoides: Ascaris lumbricoides is a large parasitic roundworm that primarily infects the small intestine and manifests as protein-energy malnutrition, vitamin A deficiency, urticaria, angioneurotic edema and may cause mechanical obstruction. 

Option D - Ancylostoma Duodenale: Ancylostoma duodenale is a hookworm that infects humans by penetrating the skin, usually through the feet. Hookworm infections can cause ground itch, creeping eruptions, respiratory symptoms like pneumonitis, and bronchitis, vomiting, and diarrhea. Eggs are oval or elliptical, colorless, not bile stained, and surrounded by a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane. When passed in feces, the egg contains a segmented ovum, usually with four or eight blastomeres.

questions.text: Viral infection mimicking erythroblastosis fetalis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Parvovirus B19: 

Parvovirus B19 infection is known to cause a condition called “fifth disease” or erythema infectiosum. In some cases, Parvovirus B19 can lead to a transient aplastic crisis in a patient with an underlying hemolytic condition and hydrops fetalis, which mimics erythroblastosis fetalis. The virus infects erythroid progenitor cells, leading to temporary suppression of red blood cell production. Parvovirus B19 is, therefore, a viral infection that mimics erythroblastosis fetalis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - HSV (Herpes Simplex Virus): HSV infection is primarily associated with oral or genital ulcers, and it does not typically mimic erythroblastosis fetalis.

Option B - Epstein-Barr Virus: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is the causative agent of infectious mononucleosis. Although EBV can cause abnormal liver function and anemia, it does not specifically mimic erythroblastosis fetalis.

Option C - Picornavirus: Picornaviruses are a large family of viruses that include common viruses such as rhinoviruses and enteroviruses. While certain picornaviruses can cause mild respiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms, they do not mimic erythroblastosis fetalis.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for an 11-year-old boy who presented at the pediatric outpatient department with multiple abscesses on his face, chest, and back, along with a history of frequent respiratory infections. Uponexamination, the child showed signs of atopic excoriating skin and multiple cold abscesses on his back.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hyper IgE syndrome:

  • Hyper-IgE syndrome aka Job’s syndrome is a rare primary immunodeficiency disease characterized by eczema, recurrent staphylococcal skin abscesses, recurrent lung infections (pneumatocele), eosinophilia, and high serum levels of IgE.
  • The underlying mechanism is a defect in neutrophil chemotaxis due to mutations in either STAT3 or DOCK8 genes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hyper IgM syndrome: Hyper-IgM syndrome is an X-linked disorder characterized by increased recurrent sinopulmonary infections and diarrhea (reduced IgG), autoimmune hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, or neutropenia due to Increased IgM levels.

Option B - Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is a rare X-linked immunodeficiency disorder characterized by eczema, recurrent infections, and thrombocytopenia (low platelet count).

Option D - Carcinoid syndrome: Carcinoid syndrome is a set of symptoms caused by carcinoid tumors, which are neuroendocrine tumors that produce excessive serotonin. The symptoms include flushing, diarrhea, bronchoconstriction, and cardiac abnormalities.

questions.text: Cowdry Type A inclusions are seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Herpes simplex:

Inclusion Bodies and Viruses Producing Them

Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies

  • Negri bodies – rabies virus
  • Paschen body – variola virus
  • Guamieri bodies – vaccinia virus
  • Bollinger bodies – fowlpox virus
  • Molluscum bodies – molluscum contagiosum virus
  • Perinuclear cytoplasmic body – reovirus

Intranuclear Inclusion Bodies

Cowdry type A inclusions

  • Torres body – yellow fever virus
  • Lipschutz body – herpes simplex virus

Cowdry type B inclusions

  • Poliovirus
  • Adenovirus

Intracytoplasmic and Intranuclear Inclusion Bodies

  • Owl’s eye appearance – cytomegalovirus
  • Measles virus

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: What is the technique shown in the provided image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Trotter’s method:

  • The image depicts Trotter's method. This is the first step to control epistaxis.
  • This method involves the application of digital pressure over Kisselbach's plexus and bends forward for at least 15-20 minutes 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Epley's maneuver: Epley's maneuver is a therapeutic technique used to treat benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). It involves a series of head and body movements to reposition displaced otoconia (calcium crystals) within the inner ear, specifically the posterior semicircular canal.

Option C - McGovern's technique: McGovern's technique is used in choanal atresia. feeding a nipple with a large hole helps in the oral airway and provides good oral airways

Option D - Valsalva maneuver: The Valsalva maneuver is a physiological maneuver that involves forced expiration against a closed airway. It is commonly used to assess and evaluate the function of the middle ear and Eustachian tube, as well as to induce or relieve pressure in the ears.

questions.text: What would be the recommended treatment for simple myopic astigmatism among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct option B: -1.00 DC × 180 Degree:

  • Simple myopic astigmatism refers to a condition where there is myopia (nearsightedness) along with astigmatism in one eye and normal other eye.
  • This prescription that indicates a correction for myopic astigmatism is -1.00 DC × 180 Degree..
    • The -1.00 DC (D- dioptre and C - cylindrical) represents the cylindrical power, which addresses astigmatism. A negative cylindrical power indicates that the astigmatism is in the myopic (nearsighted) direction.
    • The "× 180 Degree" denotes the axis of astigmatism. In this case, the astigmatism is at 180 degrees, meaning that the irregular curvature of the cornea or lens causing the astigmatism is aligned vertically.
    • By prescribing -1.00 DC × 180 Degree, the correction aims to address both the nearsightedness (myopia) and the astigmatism in the correct axis. This combination is appropriate for a patient with simple myopic astigmatism.

Incorrect options

Option A: +1.00 DS

  • This option indicates a simple hyperopic (farsighted) correction, which is not suitable for myopic astigmatism.

Option C: -1.00 DS

  • This option represents a simple myopic correction without addressing astigmatism. It only corrects for nearsightedness and does not address the irregular curvature of the cornea or lens that causes astigmatism.

Option D: -1.00 DS – 1.00 DC × 180 Degree

  • This option includes both a myopic correction (-1.00 DS) and an astigmatic correction (-1.00 DC × 180 Degree).

questions.text: What is the appropriate treatment for ptosis resulting from Horner's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Fasanella-Servat operation:

  • Horner syndrome is characterized by classic triad of:
    • Mild ptosis due to paralysis of Muller's muscle.
    • Miosis due to paralysis of dilator pupillae.
    • Ipsilateral anhydrosis.
  • The treatment of choice for mild ptosis due to Muller’s muscle paralysis is Fasanella-Servat operation, aka Tarso-conjunctiva muller ectomy, which involves resection of Muller’s muscle, providing strength.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A and D - Blaskowic’s and Everbusch’s operation is done for moderate ptosis (3 mm), it involves resection of LPS muscle.

Option B - Frontalis Sling operation: Frontalis Sling operation is performed for severe ptosis (4 mm), it involves resection of frontalis muscle.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about retinitis pigmentosa?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - ERG - normal:

  • The electroretinogram (ERG) is a sensitive diagnostic test for retinitis pigmentosa, it is characterized by decreased amplitude of both ‘a’ and ‘b’ waves.
  • Classic examination findings associated with retinitis pigmentosa are:
    • Pale waxy disc.
    • Attenuation of arteries, and
    • Retinal pigmentation disturbance in the form of bony spicules

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed eye manifestation in this disease in a 45-year-old patient who presents with progressive weakness throughout the day and is found to possess antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ptosis:

  • The clinical presentation of progressive fatigue worsening at the end of the day, along with the presence of antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, suggests the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.
  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue, particularly in the muscles controlled by voluntary movements.
  • Ocular features of myasthenia gravis are ptosis (bilateral), diplopia, and nystagmus in extreme gazes.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.text: What would be your diagnosis for a patient who has a previous trauma history and is currently experiencing diplopia and following findings on CT?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Blowout Fracture:

  • The clinical presentation and CT showing Teardrop sign is suggestive of blowout fracture. A blowout fracture typically occurs when there is blunt trauma to the orbit resulting in fracture of the thin bones surrounding the orbit leading to teardrop sign due to prolapse of the soft tissue content into maxillary antrum.
  • It is characterized by ecchymosis, enophthalmos, and diplopia due to entrapment of inferior rectus and inferior oblique muscle in the fracture.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Teardrop sign is not seen in these conditions.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis from the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pterygium:

  • The given image reveals fleshy growth extending onto the cornea.
  • Pterygium is a subconjunctival fibrovascular tissue encroaching the cornea.It appears as a triangular or wedge-shaped fleshy growth on the inner or outer side of the eye, usually starting from the conjunctiva near the nasal or temporal side (nasal more common).

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pinguecula: A pinguecula is a yellowish, elevated growth on the conjunctiva, but it does not extend onto the cornea..

Option B - Concretions: Concretions refer to tiny calcium or protein deposits that can form on the conjunctiva.

Option D - Bitot's Spots: Bitot's spots are a specific manifestation of vitamin A deficiency. They appear as small, foamy, irregularly shaped white or grayish patches on the conjunctiva, typically located on the temporal side of the eye.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true in relation to accommodative esotropia?

choices.text: It is the most common type of squint
Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio
It is associated with high myopia
Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - It is associated with high myopia:

  • This statement is false. Accommodative esotropia is not associated with high myopia, but rather with high hypermetropia. In accommodative esotropia, the excessive effort to focus on near objects leads to an inward deviation of the eyes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - "It is the most common type of squint": This statement is true. Accommodative esotropia is indeed the most common type of strabismus, particularly in children.

Option B - "Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio": This statement is also true. Miotics, such as eye drops containing medications like pilocarpine or echothiophate iodide, can be used in cases where there is a high AC/A ratio (accommodative convergence/accommodation ratio).

Option D - "Refractive type can be fully corrected by the use of spectacles": This statement is true. The corrective lenses help to correct the underlying hypermetropia, allowing for improved alignment of the eyes and reducing or eliminating the esotropia.

questions.text: What is the commonly used chemotherapy regimen for the treatment of retinoblastoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide:

  • Chemotherapy is the mainstay treatment in most of the cases of retinoblastoma. It involves carboplatin, etoposide and vin­cristine (CEV) are given in three–six cycles according to the grade of retinoblastoma.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.text: What is the name of the device as shown in the image, used for the management of the glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ex-PressTM implant:

  • The Ex-PressTM (mini shunt) implant is a small stainless steel device that is used in glaucoma surgery to facilitate drainage and lower intraocular pressure (IOP).
  • It is implanted under the partial-thickness scleral flap as a modification of trabeculectomy. It provides a more favorable safety and postoperative recovery profile than standard trabeculectomy.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ahmed glaucoma valve: It consists of a small tube connected to a plate that is implanted in the eye to facilitate drainage.

Option C - Molteno implant: It involves the placement of a silicone tube with a plate to facilitate drainage.

Option D - Baerveldt implant: It consists of a tube connected to a silicone plate that is implanted in the eye to facilitate drainage.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Maddox rod:

  • The instrument shown in the image is a Maddox rod. It is a diagnostic tool used in ophthalmology to assess eye alignment and evaluate for ocular deviations or muscle imbalances. The Maddox rod consists of a cylindrical lens with parallel lines running along its length.
  • The Maddox rod is typically used in the evaluation of horizontal strabismus (ocular misalignment) and is particularly useful in detecting and measuring the presence of a phoria (latent misalignment) or atropia (manifest misalignment).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Maddox wing: The Maddox wing consists of two slits , the right sees the vertical white and horizontal red arrows and the left eye sees a vertical and horizontal line of numbers used for detecting the amount of phoria.

Option B - Stenopic slit: It is useful to determine the site of iridectomy and helps in detecting the axis of astigmatism.

Option D - Phoropter: A phoropter is a refractive instrument used during an eye examination to determine a patient's refractive error and prescribe corrective lenses. It contains a variety of lenses that can be adjusted to assess and refine a person's vision.

questions.text: Identify the test being shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct Choice C. Cover uncover test: The image provided corresponds to the Cover uncover test. The Cover uncover test is a simple and commonly used test to evaluate eye alignment and detect strabismus (ocular misalignment) or phorias (latent misalignment) in both children and adults.

  • During the Cover uncover test, the one eye is covered with an occluder and the person is asked to focus on a specific target with the uncovered eye. Then, the occluder is quickly removed, and the movement of the previously covered eye is observed.
  • By observing the eye movement during the test, any misalignment or deviation of the eyes can be detected. If the previously covered eye moves to fixate on the target, it indicates the presence of a latent misalignment or phoria. If the previously covered eye makes a corrective movement to align with the target, it suggests the presence of manifest misalignment or tropia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Obscure test:The image given in the question suggests a cover uncover test . Therefore, option A is incorrect.

Option B: Prism test: The Prism test is a different diagnostic test used to measure the amount and direction of ocular misalignment. It involves using prismatic lenses to neutralize the misalignment and determine the prism correction required to align the eyes.

Option D. Maddox rod test: The Maddox rod test involves using a cylindrical lens with parallel lines to assess eye alignment and detect muscle imbalances or deviations. It is not the test shown in the image.

questions.text: All of the following are features of fragile X syndrome, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Microorchidism:

  • Fragile X syndrome is not associated with microorchidism.
  • However, it is associated with macroorchidism.
  • Macroorchidism becomes more evident during puberty and is a characteristic finding in males with fragile X syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Trinucleotide mutation in FMR-1 gene:

  • Fragile X syndrome is caused by an expansion of CGG trinucleotide repeats in the FMR-1 gene.
  • This expansion leads to a decreased production of fragile X mental retardation protein (FMRP), resulting in the characteristic features of the syndrome.

Option B - Mental retardation:

  • Intellectual disability is a hallmark feature of fragile X syndrome.
  • It can range from mild to severe and is often associated with learning difficulties, speech and language delays, and behavioural challenges.

Option D - Large everted ears:

  • Individuals with fragile X syndrome commonly exhibit large, prominent ears that are described as everted.

questions.text: Predominantly osteoblastic secondaries are seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Prostate carcinoma:

  • Predominantly osteoblastic secondaries refer to the presence of bone metastases in which there is an excessive production of bone by osteoblasts, leading to increased bone density.
  • Prostate carcinoma commonly metastasizes to bone, and the resulting bone metastases are typically osteoblastic in nature.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Breast carcinoma: Breast carcinoma can also metastasize to bone, but the bone lesions are often mixed with areas of osteolytic and osteoblastic activity.

Option C - Stomach carcinoma: Stomach carcinoma rarely metastasizes to bone, and when it does, the bone lesions are usually osteolytic rather than predominantly osteoblastic.

Option D - Bone carcinoma: Bone metastases can arise from various primary cancers, but the osteoblastic or osteolytic nature of the bone lesions depends on the primary tumor type.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is found to have hepatomegaly on physical examination. He also complains of a dark tan despite avoiding sun exposure. His liver microscopy is given on the slide below. This patient most likely suffers from which condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Hemochromatosis:

  • Hemochromatosis is a genetic disorder characterized by excessive iron absorption and accumulation in various organs, including the liver.
  • Hepatomegaly is a common finding in hemochromatosis due to iron deposition in hepatocytes.
  • The liver microscopy image showing hepatocellular iron staining supports the diagnosis of hemochromatosis in this patient.
  • Darkening of the skin, known as bronze diabetes or dark tan, is another characteristic feature of hemochromatosis resulting from iron deposition in the skin.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Wilson's disease:

  • Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder characterized by impaired copper transport, leading to copper accumulation in various organs, including the liver and brain.
  • It typically presents with hepatic and neurological symptoms, such as hepatomegaly, jaundice, and neurologic manifestations.

Option B - Autoimmune hepatitis:

  • Autoimmune hepatitis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by immune-mediated inflammation of the liver.
  • It can present with hepatomegaly, jaundice, and elevated liver enzymes.

Option C - Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency:

  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is a genetic disorder that predisposes individuals to liver and lung diseases.
  • Liver involvement in alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency typically presents as neonatal cholestasis or later-onset liver disease.

questions.text: Punched-out ulcers in the esophagus are caused by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Herpes simplex virus:

  • Punched-out ulcers in the esophagus can be caused by a herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.
  • HSV esophagitis typically presents with shallow, well-demarcated ulcers with a punched-out appearance.
  • The infection is commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS or undergoing immunosuppressive therapy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cytomegalovirus: CMV esophagitis typically presents with linear or linearly arranged shallow ulcers in the esophagus.

Option C - Candida: Candida esophagitis can cause raised, white plaques or pseudomembranes in the esophagus.

Option D - Gastric acid: Acid reflux or gastroesophageal reflux disease can cause esophagitis, but it typically results in erosions or linear ulcers.

questions.text: Alpha-1 antitrypsin is the major inhibitor of which enzyme?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Elastase:

  • Elastase is an enzyme that breaks down elastin, a protein found in elastic tissues such as the lungs and blood vessels.
  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin is a potent inhibitor of elastase, preventing its excessive activity and protecting tissues from damage.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: All is true about the Barrett oesophagus, except?

choices.text: Seen in 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD
Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Increases the risk of squamous cell carcinoma:

  • Barrett esophagus increases the risk of developing adenocarcinoma of the esophagus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Complication of chronic GERD:

  • Barrett esophagus is considered a complication of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
  • Prolonged exposure to stomach acid can cause changes in the lining of the esophagus, leading to the development of Barrett's esophagus.

Option B - Seen in 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD:

  • Barrett esophagus is estimated to occur in about 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD.

Option D - Intestinal metaplasia:

  • Barrett esophagus is characterized by the presence of intestinal metaplasia, where the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus is replaced by columnar epithelium resembling the lining of the intestine.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is most commonly associated with Down syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Alzheimer disease:

  • Alzheimer disease is the most commonly observed in individuals with Down syndrome.
  • The accumulation of beta-amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles in the brain, characteristic of Alzheimer disease, occurs at an earlier age and progresses more rapidly in individuals with Down syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the modified Duke’s criteria?

choices.text: Single positive blood culture for HACEK group is a major criterion
Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetti is a major criterion
Documentation of four minor criteria allows a clinical diagnosis

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetti is a major criterion:

  • A single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii is a major criterion in the modified Duke's criteria for infective endocarditis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Single positive blood culture for HACEK group is a major criterion: A single positive blood culture for HACEK group organisms (Haemophilus species, Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, Cardiobacterium hominis, Eikenella corrodens, and Kingella) is not considered a major criterion in the modified Duke's criteria.

Option C - Complete dehiscence of prosthetic valve: Complete dehiscence of a prosthetic valve is not a criterion in the modified Duke's criteria.

Option D - Documentation of four minor criteria allows a clinical diagnosis: A definitive diagnosis of endocarditis can be made in patients with two major criteria, one major and three minor criteria, or five minor criteria.

questions.text: IL-1 is activated by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Caspase-1:

  • Caspase-1 is an enzyme involved in the activation of interleukin-1 (IL-1) in the innate immune response.
  • It cleaves the inactive precursor form of IL-1 into its active form, allowing it to exert its pro-inflammatory effects.
  • IL-1 plays a crucial role in the initiation and regulation of inflammatory responses.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not involved in the activation of IL-1.

questions.text: Flask shaped ulcers in the colon are caused by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Entamoeba Histolytica:

  • Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite that can cause intestinal infections, specifically amoebic dysentery.
  • One of the characteristic features of amoebic dysentery is the presence of flask-shaped ulcers in the colon. 
  • The trophozoites of E. histolytica damage the mucosa and submucosa but cannot damage the muscular as it is difficult to break. Thus, it starts breaking the submucosa on the sides, resulting in a flask-shaped ulcer.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D do not cause flask-shaped ulcers in the colon.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about fever?

choices.text: Aspirin increases fever by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis
PGD2 is responsible for resetting the temperature to a higher level
Fever occurs during inflammation due to release of histamine

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - IL-1 is an endogenous pyrogen:

  • IL-1 is released by immune cells in response to infection or inflammation and acts on the hypothalamus to raise the body's temperature set-point, leading to fever.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aspirin increases fever by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis: Aspirin reduces fever by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis.

Option B - PGD2 is responsible for resetting the temperature to a higher level: PGD2 is involved in sleep regulation and inflammation but is not responsible for resetting the temperature to a higher level during fever.

Option D - Fever occurs during inflammation due to release of histamine: Histamine release can contribute to the symptoms of inflammation, but it is not the primary cause of fever.

questions.text: Identify the anti-apoptotic factor among the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bcl-2:

  • Bcl-2 (B-cell lymphoma 2) is an anti-apoptotic protein that plays a key role in regulating cell survival.
  • It functions by inhibiting apoptosis.
  • Bcl-2 prevents the release of cytochrome c from the mitochondria, which is a crucial step in the initiation of apoptosis.
  • By inhibiting cytochrome c release, Bcl-2 helps to maintain cell survival and prevent apoptosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - p53:

  • p53 is an apoptotic factor.
  • p53 is a tumor suppressor protein that plays a role in promoting apoptosis in response to DNA damage or other cellular stresses.

Option B - KRAS:

  • KRAS is an oncogene that is involved in promoting cell proliferation and survival.

Option D - BAK:

  • BAK is a pro-apoptotic factor belonging to the Bcl-2 family.
  • BAK promotes apoptosis by inducing mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization, leading to cytochrome c release and activation of the apoptotic cascade.

questions.text: What is the type of necrosis seen in the vessel wall of a patient with polyarteritis nodosa?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Fibrinoid necrosis:

  • Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in the vessel wall of a patient with polyarteritis nodosa.
  • In this condition, immune complexes and inflammatory cells infiltrate the vessel walls, causing damage and necrosis.
  • The deposition of fibrin-like proteinaceous material leads to thickening and an eosinophilic appearance of the vessel walls.
  • Fibrinoid necrosis is a characteristic finding in autoimmune diseases affecting blood vessels.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Gangrenous necrosis:

  • Gangrenous necrosis typically occurs in ischemic or infected tissues.
  • It is characterized by dry or wet gangrene, depending on the presence of bacterial infection and tissue liquefaction.

Option C - Fat necrosis:

  • Fat necrosis occurs in adipose tissue and is often associated with conditions like acute pancreatitis or trauma.
  • It involves the breakdown of fat cells by pancreatic enzymes, leading to the release of fatty acids and the formation of necrotic areas.

Option D - Caseous necrosis:

  • Caseous necrosis is commonly associated with tuberculosis and other granulomatous infections.
  • It is characterized by the formation of a granular, cheese-like necrotic material within the affected tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Apo E4:

  • The ApoE4 variant of the Apo E gene is considered a risk factor for Alzheimer's disease.
  • The presence of ApoE4 is associated with a higher likelihood of developing Alzheimer's disease and contribute to an earlier onset of the condition.

Incorrect Options: 

Options A, B, and C are not a risk factor for Alzheimer’s disease.

questions.text: Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with the development of which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Dilated cardiomyopathy:

  • Alcohol abuse has been strongly associated with the development of dilated cardiomyopathy.
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy is a condition characterized by the enlargement and weakening of the heart's left ventricle, leading to reduced pumping ability and potential heart failure.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are not associated with alcohol abuse.

questions.text: Which lymphoma is strongly associated with overexpression of Bcl-2?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Follicular lymphoma:

  • Follicular lymphoma is strongly associated with the overexpression of Bcl-2.
  • In follicular lymphoma, there is a genetic translocation [most commonly t(14;18)] that leads to the overexpression of the Bcl-2 protein.
  • This overexpression of Bcl-2 helps the cancer cells evade apoptosis, contributing to their uncontrolled growth and survival.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not associated with overexpression of Bcl-2.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the provided X-ray image, along with normal clinical examination, hematological, and urinary test results, in a 65-year-old male patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option B. Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is a rare disorder characterized by the proliferation and accumulation of Langerhans cells, a type of immune cell, in various tissues. LCH can affect multiple organs, including the bone, skin, and lymph nodes. In the context of the given X-ray showing a punched-out lytic lesion in the cranium, LCH becomes a probable diagnosis.

Incorrect options:

Option A . Multiple myeloma: Multiple myeloma is a type of blood cancer that involves the abnormal proliferation of plasma cells, a type of white blood cell, in the bone marrow. Multiple myeloma is usually associated with abnormal hematological and urinary test results, which were reported as normal in this case.

Option C . Metastasis: Metastatic lesions can be seen in various organs, including the bone. However, the X-ray findings alone cannot definitively indicate metastasis. A detailed clinical history and further investigations, such as imaging studies and biopsy, are necessary to identify the primary tumor and confirm metastasis.

Option D . Hyperparathyroidism: Hyperparathyroidism is a condition characterized by excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by the parathyroid glands, leading to high levels of calcium in the blood. While hyperparathyroidism can cause bone changes, such as osteopenia or osteoporosis, the typical X-ray appearance associated with hyperparathyroidism is not a punched-out lytic lesion.

questions.text: A 47-year-old female patient with a long-standing history of rheumatic heart disease was admitted to the hospital due to severe breathlessness. She died on the third day following admission. The mitral valve shows the following findings on autopsy. What is the cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Calcification and fibrosis:

  • The autopsy finding on the mitral valve shows the fish mouth or buttonhole appearance, indicating calcification and fibrosis, which is a characteristic feature of rheumatic heart disease.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following myocardial infarcts causes aneurysm as a post-MI complication?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Anterior transmural:

  • An aneurysm is a potential post-MI complication characterized by the formation of a localized, abnormal dilation or bulge in the weakened area of the myocardium.
  • It occurs as a result of the loss of contractile function and the thinning of the infarcted myocardial wall.
  • Anterior transmural myocardial infarction is the most likely to cause an aneurysm.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D do not cause aneurysm as a post-MI complication.

questions.text: Which drug listed below is utilized as an agent for smoking cessation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Varenicline:

  • Varenicline is a medication used as an antismoking agent. It works by targeting nicotine receptors in the brain, reducing the pleasurable effects of smoking and decreasing nicotine withdrawal symptoms. Varenicline is commonly prescribed to individuals who want to quit smoking or tobacco use.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Busulfan: Busulfan is not used as an antismoking agent. It is a chemotherapy medication primarily used in the treatment of certain types of cancer, such as leukemia.

Option B - Acamprosate: Acamprosate is a medication used in the treatment of alcohol dependence. It helps individuals who have quit drinking alcohol to maintain abstinence by reducing cravings and withdrawal symptoms.

Option D - Gabapentin: Gabapentin is primarily used as an antiepileptic medication, but it can also be prescribed for certain types of chronic pain or neuropathic conditions.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about somnambulism is incorrect?

choices.text: Usually, terminates in awakening followed by confusion
There may be neurological condition associated

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Person will have full consciousness:

  • Somnambulism, also known as sleepwalking, is a parasomnia disorder characterized by complex motor behaviors and actions during sleep. During an episode of somnambulism, individuals are in a state of partial arousal from sleep, and their consciousness is typically impaired or altered.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Disorder of sleep arousal: Somnambulism is classified as a disorder of sleep arousal because it involves partial awakenings from sleep with the occurrence of complex behaviors.

Option C - Usually terminates in awakening followed by confusion: Somnambulism episodes often end with the sleepwalker waking up, and upon awakening, they may experience confusion and disorientation about their surroundings or actions during the episode.

Option B - There may be a neurological condition associated: While somnambulism can occur in otherwise healthy individuals, there can also be underlying neurological conditions or factors that contribute to its occurrence. These may include conditions such as epilepsy, sleep disorders, or certain medications.

questions.text: Which one of the options does not contribute as a risk factor for delusional disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D. Young age.

  • Delusional disorder is a psychiatric condition characterized by the presence of persistent delusions without significant impairment in other cognitive functions. Delusions are fixed, false beliefs that are maintained despite evidence to the contrary. While various factors can contribute to the development of delusional disorder, young age is not considered a significant risk factor.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Recent immigration: Recent immigration can be a risk factor for delusional disorder. The stressors and challenges associated with adapting to a new environment, cultural differences, and social isolation can potentially contribute to the development of delusions.

Option B. Social isolation: Social isolation or lack of social support is considered a risk factor for delusional disorder. It can lead to feelings of loneliness, exacerbate existing delusions, and contribute to the persistence of abnormal beliefs.

Option C. Family history: Family history of psychiatric disorders, including delusional disorder, is considered a risk factor. There may be a genetic predisposition or shared environmental factors within families that contribute to the development of delusions.

questions.text: Premature ejaculation is a disorder of which phase of the normal sexual cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Orgasm:

  • Premature ejaculation is a disorder that occurs during the orgasm phase of the normal sexual cycle. It is characterized by the persistent or recurrent ejaculation that happens before or shortly after the initiation of sexual activity, often with minimal stimulation. This results in an inability to delay ejaculation and causes distress or interpersonal difficulties.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Desire: The desire phase refers to the initial stage of sexual response where an individual experiences sexual interest or desire.

Option B - Arousal: The arousal phase involves physical and psychological changes that prepare the body for sexual activity, such as increased heart rate, genital vasocongestion, and subjective sexual arousal.

Option D - Pain: The pain phase refers to the presence of pain or discomfort during sexual activity, which can be caused by various factors such as medical conditions or psychological issues.

questions.text: Confusion assessment test is used in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Delirium: 

  • Confusion Assessment Test (CAM) is primarily used for the assessment and diagnosis of delirium. Delirium is a state of acute confusion and changes in cognition that often occurs in older adults, particularly those who are hospitalized or have underlying medical conditions. The CAM is a validated screening tool that helps healthcare professionals identify the presence of delirium and distinguish it from other cognitive disorders or psychiatric conditions.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Dementia: While both delirium and dementia involve changes in cognition, they are distinct conditions. Dementia is a chronic and progressive disorder characterized by a decline in memory, thinking, and reasoning skills. The CAM is not typically used for diagnosing dementia.

Option C - Schizophrenia: Schizophrenia is a psychiatric disorder characterized by disturbances in perception, thought processes, and emotions. It does not typically present with acute confusion or cognitive impairment, which are hallmarks of delirium. The CAM is not used for assessing schizophrenia.

Option D - Depression: Depression is a mood disorder that primarily affects a person's emotional state, such as persistent sadness, loss of interest, and changes in appetite or sleep patterns. While depression can sometimes lead to cognitive impairments, the CAM is not specifically designed for assessing depression or its cognitive symptoms.

questions.text: In OCD, which of the options below is associated with an unfavorable outcome when treated with exposure and response prevention?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C  - Hoarding:

  • Hoarding refers to the excessive accumulation of items and difficulty discarding them, often resulting in cluttered living spaces and significant distress.
  • Hoarding behaviors are typically resistant to change and can be more challenging to treat with ERP compared to other OCD symptoms.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pathological doubt: Pathological doubt refers to excessive and irrational doubts that individuals with OCD experience, often leading them to seek reassurance repeatedly. While pathological doubt can be challenging to treat, it generally responds well to ERP and has a more favorable prognosis compared to hoarding.

Option B - Magical thinking: Magical thinking involves beliefs that one's thoughts or actions can influence events in unrealistic or supernatural ways. While it can be a symptom of OCD, it doesn't necessarily indicate a poor prognosis with ERP. The effectiveness of ERP treatment depends on the individual and the specific nature of their OCD symptoms.

Option D - Contamination obsession: Contamination obsessions involve an intense fear of contamination or germs and often result in excessive cleaning or avoidance behaviors. Contamination obsessions tend to respond well to ERP treatment, and individuals with this symptom subtype generally have a better prognosis compared to hoarding.

questions.text: What is the fear of heights known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Acrophobia:

  • Acrophobia is the fear of heights, which is a specific phobia characterized by an intense and irrational fear or anxiety response when exposed to heights or situations involving heights. People with acrophobia may experience symptoms such as dizziness, rapid heartbeat, shortness of breath, sweating, and a strong desire to avoid heights or high places.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acarophobia: Acarophobia refers to the fear of mites or small insects.

Option B - Algophobia: Algophobia is the fear of pain. It is not directly related to the fear of heights, as it specifically focuses on the fear of experiencing physical pain.

Option C - Agoraphobia: Agoraphobia is a fear or anxiety about being in situations or places where escape might be difficult or embarrassing, or where help may not be available in the event of a panic attack or other distressing symptoms. Agoraphobia is typically associated with fears of being in open spaces, crowded areas, using public transportation, or being outside the home alone.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding MHC molecules?

choices.text: MHC class II presents peptide antigen to CD4 T cells
The action of MHC II occurs via endocytic pathway
MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens
MHC II is present on antigen presenting cells

questions.solution:
Correct option C - MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens:

Differences between MHC Class I and MHC Class II Molecules

 

MHC Class I

MHC Class II

Present on

All nucleated cells (except sperms) and platelets

Antigen-presenting cells (APCs)

Peptide antigen is

Presented to CD8 T cells

Presented to CD4 T cells

Nature of peptide antigen

Endogenous or intracellular (viral/tumor antigen)

Exogenous

Peptide antigen (size)

8-10 amino acid long

13-18 amino acid long

Antigen presentation pathways

Cytosolic pathway

Endocytic pathway

Peptide-binding site

alpha1/alpha2 groove

alpha1/beta1 groove

CD4 or CD 8 binding site

alpha 3 binds to CD8 molecules on Tc cells

beta 2 binds to CD4 on TH cells

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations does not involve the use of antibody labeling?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Hemagglutination Test:

  • The hemagglutination test is a technique used to detect certain viral or bacterial infections by observing the agglutination (clumping) of red blood cells (RBCs). In this test, the antigen of interest (usually a virus or bacteria) is mixed with RBCs (containing antibodies). If the antigen interacts with the antibodies in RBCs, it can cause them to clump together or agglutinate.
  • The hemagglutination test does not involve the use of labeled antibodies. Instead, it relies on the interaction between the antigen and the RBCs.
  • Examples of hemagglutination test are: Paul bunnel test (for EBV), Coomb’s test, and cold agglutination test for mycoplasma.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. These tests require labeled antibody to detect the presence of antigens.

questions.text: In the case of a 3-year-old child with a history of recurrent sinopulmonary infections caused by encapsulated organisms, which of the following is the most probable deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - IgG2:

  • IgG2 deficiency is associated with an increased susceptibility to infections caused by encapsulated bacteria. IgG2 plays a crucial role in opsonization, which is the process of tagging pathogens for destruction by phagocytes. It facilitates the phagocytosis of encapsulated bacteria by immune cells, leading to their elimination.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - IgG1: IgG1 is important for opsonization and immune response against protein antigens. While a deficiency in IgG1 can increase susceptibility to certain infections, it is not specifically associated with an increased susceptibility to encapsulated bacterial infections.

Option C - IgG3: IgG3 is an important antibody subclass involved in complement activation and immune response against certain bacterial pathogens.

Option D - IgG4: IgG4 is involved in immune tolerance and is associated with allergic responses and autoimmune conditions.

questions.text: A veterinarian developed an ulcer with a central black eschar over the forearm, as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bacillus Anthracis:

  • The image shows an ulcer with a central black eschar on the forearm, and the occupation of the patient is highly suggestive of cutaneous anthrax, which is caused by the bacterium Bacillus anthracis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pseudomonas Aeruginosa: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common cause of various hospital-acquired infections like meningitis, endocarditis, and infection of burns.

Option B - Yersinia Pestis: Yersinia pestis is the causative organism of plague, which typically presents with symptoms such as fever, lymphadenopathy, respiratory symptoms, and shock.

Option D - Francisella Tularensis: Francisella tularensis is the bacterium responsible for tularemia, also known as rabbit fever. It primarily causes ulceroglandular tularemia, which presents with skin ulcers and swollen lymph nodes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as an immediate test in the screening of urinary tract infections (UTI)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pour Plate Culture:

  • Pour plate culture is not used as an immediate test in the screening of urinary tract infections (UTIs). Pour plate culture is a quantitative method used for bacterial culture and enumeration, it is not a screening test for UTI.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Griess Nitrite Test: The Griess Nitrite test is a rapid screening test used to detect the presence of nitrites in the urine. Nitrites are produced by certain bacteria, such as Escherichia coli, commonly associated with UTIs. The presence of nitrites indicates the possibility of a UTI.

Option C - Leukocyte Esterase Test: The leukocyte esterase test is a rapid screening test used to detect the leukocyte esterase secreted by pus cells in the urine. The presence of leukocyte esterase suggests inflammation and a possible UTI.

Option D - Wet Mount Examination: The wet mount examination is a microscopic examination of urine sediment, which is used for the detection of pus cells in urine. Pyuria of more than 8 pus cells/mm3 is taken as significant for UTI.

questions.text: In which of the following is the disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing is applied?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Kirby-Bauer Method:

  • The disc diffusion method is applied in the Kirby-Bauer method, a widely used technique for antibiotic susceptibility testing. It is applied to determine the susceptibility or resistance of bacteria to different antibiotics.
  • It involves placing antibiotic discs on an agar plate that has been uniformly inoculated with the test organism, this establishes a gradient with concentration being highest near the site of the disc and decreasing with distance. After incubation, the zone of inhibition around each disc is measured, indicating the bacteria's susceptibility or resistance to the antibiotics.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Agar Dilution Method: The agar dilution method employs a dilution method where drugs are prepared and inoculated with the test bacterium into the agar.

Option C - Broth Dilution Method: Broth dilution uses a dilution method; in this, serial dilutions of antibiotics are prepared in liquid broth, against the suspension of the bacterium.

Option D - PCR-Based Assay: PCR-based assays are molecular techniques used for the detection of specific genetic material, such as DNA or RNA, of pathogens. They are not used for antibiotic susceptibility testing but rather for identifying the presence or absence of specific genetic markers or genes associated with antibiotic resistance.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for neurosyphilis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) Test:

  • Neurosyphilis is a form of syphilis that affects the central nervous system. The VDRL test is the most preferred screening test for syphilis, including neurosyphilis.
  • The VDRL test is a non-specific test that detects reagin antibodies in the serum or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of individuals with syphilis by using cardiolipin antigen extracted from beef heart. Positive VDRL results indicate the presence of antibodies, suggesting an active infection.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - FTA-ABS-Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption Test: The FTA-ABS test is a specific test for syphilis. It detects antibodies specifically against Treponema pallidum, the bacterium that causes syphilis. It is highly sensitive and specific for syphilis diagnosis, including neurosyphilis. However, the FTA-ABS test is not the investigation of choice specifically for neurosyphilis.

Option C - RPR – Rapid Plasma Reagin Test: The RPR test is another non-specific test used for the screening and diagnosis of syphilis. It detects antibodies against cardiolipin, a substance found in the plasma. It is more expensive than VDRL.

Option D - TPI – Treponema Pallidum Immobilization Test: The TPI test is a specific test used to detect antibodies against Treponema pallidum. It involves mixing patient serum with live Treponema pallidum organisms and observing for immobilization.

questions.text: Contact based isolation is employed for which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - MRSA:

  • Contact-based isolation precautions are employed for MRSA (Methicillin Resistance Staphylococcus Aureus). These precautions prevent the transmission of the bacteria from an infected or colonized individual to others.
  • It includes hand washing, isolation of patients with open staphylococcal lesions, and detection of staphylococcal lesions among surgeons.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Diphtheria: It requires droplet precautions because it is primarily transmitted through respiratory droplets. Droplet precautions involve wearing a mask and other appropriate measures to prevent the spread of infectious droplets.

Option C - Mumps: It is also transmitted through respiratory droplets, and droplet precautions are necessary to prevent its transmission.

Option D -Asthma: It is a chronic respiratory condition and not an infectious disease. It does not require isolation precautions since it is not transmissible from person to person.

questions.text: An 18 year old female presents with a severe headache and high fever of 101°F. On examination, papilloedema and nuchal rigidity was present. Gram staining of the CSF is shown below. Causative organism is
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Neisseria Meningitidis:

  • The clinical presentation of the patient is suggestive of meningitis.
  • The most common bacterium responsible for meningitis are Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, H. influenzae, Listeria, streptococcus agalactiae, and E. coli.
  • Gram staining of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) showing gram-negative diplococci suggests the diagnosis of Neisseria meningitidis.

Incorrect Options :

Option A - Haemophilus Influenzae Type B: While Haemophilus influenzae can cause meningitis, it is a gram-negative present as clusters of coccobacillus and would not appear as gram-positive diplococci on Gram staining.

Option C - Streptococcus Pneumoniae: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram-positive bacterium that can cause bacterial meningitis, but it appears as gram-positive diplococci, giving a lanceolate shape.
Option D - Listeria Monocytogenes: Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacterium associated with meningitis, but it is characterized by its rod-shaped and exhibits differential motility.

questions.text: What is the stain used for identifying Cryptococcus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Mucicarmine Stain:

  • Cryptococcus can be identified using a special stain called mucicarmine stain. This stain specifically targets the polysaccharide capsule of Cryptococcus and stains it pink.

  • Other stains used to demonstrate cryptococcus neoformans are:
    • Masson-Fontana stain 
    • Alcian blue stain 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Giemsa Stain: Giemsa stain is commonly used for demonstrating Yersinia pestis, Borrelia duttoni, and rickettsia infections.

Option B - Ziehl-Nielsen Stain: Ziehl-Nielsen stain is used for acid-fast staining to detect acid-fast bacteria like Mycobacterium tuberculosis, coccidian parasites, and M. leprae.

Option C - Gram Staining: Gram staining is a commonly used staining method to differentiate bacteria into Gram-positive and Gram-negative based on their cell wall properties

questions.text: Which of the following organisms follow a bird-arthropod–human transmission route?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Japanese Encephalitis:

  • Japanese encephalitis is a viral infection caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), which is transmitted through a bird-arthropod-human transmission route. The primary transmission cycle involves mosquito Culex as the arthropod vector and ardeid birds as the reservoir hosts. Mosquitoes acquire the virus by feeding on infected birds and then transmit it to humans through their bites. Humans are accidental hosts, and pigs are amplifiers.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Malaria: Malaria is transmitted through the bite of infected female Anopheles mosquitoes that acquire the causative organism plasmodium by feeding on infected individual.

Option C - Plague: Plague is primarily transmitted through the bites of infected fleas that acquire the causative organism Yersinia by feeding on wild rodents.

Option D - Paragonimiasis: Paragonimiasis is a parasitic infection caused by lung flukes of the genus Paragonimus. It is acquired by consuming raw or undercooked freshwater crustaceans, such as crabs and crayfish.

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient with a history of travel to China and the consumption of pickled crab now presents with complains of rusty sputum and cough. What is the most likely causative organisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Paragonimus Westermani:

  • Paragonimus westermani is a lung fluke that causes paragonimiasis, a parasitic infection characterized by chronic cough and rusty or bloody sputum containing eggs. The infection is commonly acquired by consuming raw or undercooked freshwater crustaceans, such as crabs and crayfish, which serve as second intermediate hosts for the parasite. The patient's history of travel to China and consumption of pickled crab aligns with the potential exposure to Paragonimus westermani.
  • Humans are the definitive hosts, and snails act as the first intermediate hosts.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fasciola Buski: Fasciola buski is a trematode that causes a parasitic infection of the intestine characterized by diarrhea, abdominal pain, and malabsorption. It is acquired by consuming contaminated water plants, such as watercress, which are the second intermediate hosts. Humans and sheep are the definitive hosts, and snails act as the first intermediate hosts.

Option B - Fasciola Hepatica: Fasciola hepatica is another trematode that causes a parasitic infection of the liver characterized by right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, pain, and bile duct obstruction. It is also acquired by consuming contaminated water plants, such as watercress, which are the second intermediate hosts.

Option D - Schistosoma Japonicum: Schistosoma japonicum is a blood fluke that causes schistosomiasis characterized by intestinal mucosa hyperplasia, hepatosplenomegaly, and portal hypertension. It is acquired by penetration of the skin by cercariae released by snails, the intermediate host contaminating the freshwater sources.

questions.text: Which type of virus is rubella?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Togavirus:

  • Rubella virus is classified as a Togavirus. Togaviruses are a family of enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA viruses. Rubella virus, also known as the German measles virus, belongs to the genus Rubivirus within the Togaviridae family.
  • Other viruses included in Togavirus are:
    • Chikungunya virus.
    • Western equine encephalitis virus.
    • Eastern equine encephalitis virus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Flavivirus: Flaviviruses are another family of RNA viruses and include viruses such as Japanese encephalitis, Yellow fever, Zika, Dengue, West Nile fever, and Hepatitis C.

Option C - Paramyxovirus: Paramyxoviruses are yet another family of RNA viruses known for causing respiratory infections such as respiratory syncytial virus measles, mumps, parainfluenza, and Nipah.

Option D. Orthomyxovirus: Orthomyxoviruses are a family of RNA viruses that include influenza viruses.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female developed pruritic papules with excoriated plaques in the interdigital web spaces. Later the lesion spread to the groin and under the surface of the breasts. The lady gives a history of intense pruritus, which is more severe at night. Given below is the organism responsible for this condition. Identify the wrong statement about the same.

choices.text: Classic scabies have a lower mite burden than crusted scabies
Male parasite burrows into the epidermis

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Male Parasite Burrows into the Epidermis:

  • The clinical presentation and image showing the causative organism Sarcoptes scabiei is characterized by a round body dorsally and a flattened body ventrally, covered with short bristles, and has two pairs of legs in front and two pairs behind are suggestive of scabies. Classic scabies typically manifest as an intensely pruritic eruption with a characteristic distribution. The sides and webs of the fingers, wrists, axillae, areolae, and genitalia are among the common sites of involvement.
  • Scabies is a parasitic infestation of the skin caused by the burrowing of female mites into the epidermis facilitated by the secretion of proteolytic enzymes that cause keratinocyte damage.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Life History has 4 Stages: The life cycle of Sarcoptes scabiei involves four stages: egg, larva, nymph, and adult.

Option B - Larvae have 4 Pairs of Legs: The larvae of Sarcoptes scabiei have four pairs of legs.

Option C - Classic Scabies have a Lower Mite Burden than Crusted Scabies: The mite burden in a patient with classic scabies is 10 to 15 mites, and for crusted scabies, the mite burden goes up to millions.

questions.text: An HIV patient presents with persistent diarrhea. Microscopic examination of the stool reveals oocyst of size 4 to 8 µm as shown below. Identify the causative organism:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cryptosporidium:

  • Coccidian parasites are responsible for causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised individual (HIV). Cryptosporidium is the most common among coccidian parasites to cause persistent diarrhea. The image showing an acid-fast oocyst round in shape confirms the causative parasite to be Cryptosporidium parvum. It is stained with modified acid-fast staining using 0.2%-1% of acid alcohol, showing a pinkish-red color.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cyclospora: Cyclospora oocysts on modified acid-fast technique, stain red to reddish-orange, 8-12 μm in size, round, variably acid-fast, contains two sporocysts each bearing sporozoites.

Option C- Microsporum: Microsporum are associated with skin and hair dermatophytoses.

Option D - Cystoisospora: Cystoisospora, formerly known as Isospora, is another protozoan parasite that can cause diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals. Oocyst of isospora are also acid-fast, but the size of the oocyst is large, i.e., 23-36 μm in size, and is oval in shape.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the hospital, with complaints of seizures and the MRI image of the brain is given below. The disease is most probably caused by?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cysticercus cellulosae:

  • The given image of the CT scan of the brain shows multiple calcified cysts of cysticercus cellulosae in the brain parenchyma and a history of seizures is suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by the larval stage (cysticercus cellulosae) of the pork tapeworm, Taenia solium.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - T. saginata: Taenia saginata is another species of tapeworm that infects humans, but it causes a different condition known as intestinal taeniasis. Taeniasis occurs when a person ingests the larval stage (cysticercus bovis) of Taenia saginata found in undercooked beef.

Option C - Cysticercus bovis: Cysticercus bovis is the larval stage of Taenia saginata found in undercooked beef and responsible for causing intestinal taeniasis.

Option D - T. asiatica: Taenia saginata asiatica is another species of tapeworm that resembles Taenia saginata, and cysticerci are located in the liver.

questions.text: Vaccine that require strain change due to evolving organism is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Influenza:

  • Influenza is caused by influenza viruses, which have the ability to undergo frequent genetic changes through antigenic drift (seen in influenza A & B, point mutation occurs) and antigenic shift (seen in Influenza A, genetic reassotment occurs) .
  • This means that the viral strains circulating in the population can change over time, making the previously developed vaccines less effective against the new strains. Therefore, annual updates and strain changes are required in the influenza vaccine to ensure its effectiveness against the evolving strains.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Diphtheria: The diphtheria vaccine is based on the toxoid produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae and does not require frequent strain changes.

Option C - Polio: The polio vaccine targets the poliovirus, and while there are different serotypes of the virus, the vaccine does not require frequent strain changes as the available vaccines offer protection against all known serotypes.

Option D - Typhoid: The typhoid vaccine is based on specific strains of Salmonella typhi bacteria and does not require frequent strain changes.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a neonate who continues to have unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia after three weeks of birth, with normal liver enzymes, PT/INR, and albumin levels, no evidence of hemolysis on a peripheral blood smear, and a decrease in bilirubin levels following treatment with phenobarbital?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Crigler-Najjar type 2:

  • Crigler-Najjar type 2 is a condition characterized by a partial deficiency of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase (UGT), which leads to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • In this type, the bilirubin levels can be reduced with the administration of drugs that induce UGT enzyme activity, such as phenobarbital.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rotor syndrome:

  • Rotor syndrome is a benign condition characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, where bilirubin is conjugated but not efficiently transported from the liver into the bile.

Option C - Dubin-Johnson syndrome:

  • Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign condition characterized by impaired bilirubin excretion into the bile.
  • It causes a buildup of conjugated bilirubin in the liver, leading to mild conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

Option D - Crigler-Najjar type 1:

  • Crigler-Najjar type 1 is a severe form of the condition characterized by a complete deficiency of UGT enzyme activity.
  • It presents early in life and results in severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • Unlike Crigler-Najjar type 2, Crigler-Najjar type 1 is not responsive to phenobarbital treatment.
  • Management options for Crigler-Najjar type 1 typically involve phototherapy or liver transplantation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of cerebral palsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Microcephaly:

  • Microcephaly is a condition in which the head is smaller than expected for age and sex.
  • It is not a characteristic feature of cerebral palsy.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are the characteristic features of cerebral palsy.  

Option A - Hypotonia:

  • Hypotonia refers to decreased muscle tone, resulting in floppy or loose muscles.

Options C - Ataxia:

  • Ataxia refers to problems with coordination and voluntary muscle movements, resulting in unsteady or shaky movements.
  • While ataxia is not present in all cases of cerebral palsy, it can occur in individuals with cerebral palsy, especially when the cerebellum is affected.

Option D - Flaccid paralysis:

  • Flaccid paralysis refers to a condition where there is a complete loss of muscle tone and voluntary movement.
  • It occurs when there is damage to the lower motor neurons or peripheral nerves, leading to a loss of muscle control.

questions.text: Which of the following is absent in a child with cystic fibrosis?

choices.text: Sweat chloride test chloride conc of 70mEq/L

questions.solution:
Correct option C - Hyperkalemia:

  • Hyperkalemia is not seen in a child with cystic fibrosis.
  • Cystic fibrosis primarily affects the exocrine glands, leading to abnormal production and secretion of thick, sticky mucus in various organs.
  • It is commonly associated with electrolyte imbalances such as hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to excessive chloride loss in sweat.

Incorrect Options - A, B, and D are present in a child with cystic fibrosis.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 9-year-old boy with knee joint swelling, non-blanching rashes (as shown in the picture), haematuria +++ and proteinuria + on urine examination, and normal platelet levels?
questions.solution:
Correct option is B

  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a type of vasculitis that primarily affects small blood vessels. It is most commonly seen in children. HSP is characterized by inflammation and damage to blood vessels, which can lead to a variety of symptoms. The key features in this case that point towards HSP are:
  1. Swelling of knee joints:
  2. Non-blanching rashes (purpura)
  3. Haematuria +++ and proteinuria
  4. Normal platelet levels

Incorrect Option
