Options A. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): SLE is an autoimmune disease that can also affect multiple organs, including joints, skin, and kidneys. However, in this case, the presence of non-blanching rashes (purpura) and normal platelet levels is more suggestive of HSP rather than SLE.

Options C. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP): ITP is a condition characterized by low platelet levels and abnormal bleeding. The presence of normal platelet levels in this case makes ITP an unlikely diagnosis.

Options D. Polyarteritis Nodosa (PAN): PAN is a systemic vasculitis that affects medium and small arteries. It typically presents with symptoms such as fever, weight loss, abdominal pain, and muscle/joint pain. The combination of non-blanching rashes (purpura) and kidney involvement is not typical of PAN.

questions.text: A child in your unit is diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). According to the WHO criteria, SAM is best defined by:

choices.text: Weight for age less than -2 SD
Weight for height less than +2 SD
Weight for age less than +3 SD
Weight for height less than -3 SD

questions.solution:
Correct option D: Weight for height less than -3 SD:

  • When assessing and classifying malnutrition in children, the World Health Organization (WHO) uses two primary indicators:
    • Weight for age
    • Weight for height
  • These indicators are expressed as standard deviation (SD) scores, also known as Z-scores, which compare a child's measurements to the reference population.
  • In the case of severe acute malnutrition (SAM), the WHO focuses on the weight for height indicator.
  • A weight for height Z-score of less than -3 SD is used to define severe acute malnutrition.

Incorrect options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect.

questions.text: What is the most frequent symptom of congenital toxoplasmosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Chorioretinitis:

  • The manifestations of congenital toxoplasmosis can vary, but chorioretinitis is the most frequently observed and significant manifestation

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D can occur in congenital toxoplasmosis but are not the most frequent symptom of congenital toxoplasmosis.

questions.text: What is the molecular defect responsible for liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - ABCC2:

  • Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by impaired bilirubin excretion into bile, resulting in a buildup of conjugated bilirubin in the liver and bloodstream.
  • This condition is caused by a molecular defect in the ABCC2 gene, which codes for a protein called multidrug resistance-associated protein 2 (MRP2).
  • ABCC2 is responsible for the transport of bilirubin glucuronides, conjugated bilirubin, and other compounds into bile.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. 

  • ATP7A and ATP7B genes code for copper transporters. Menkes disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene, Wilson's disease arises from mutations in the ATP7B gene.
  • The SERPINA1 gene encodes alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT)

questions.text: Where would you place the pulse oximeter to measure preductal oxygen saturation in an infant born 3 minutes ago?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Right upper limb

 

 

Explanation:

 

Preductal Saturation:

  • Refers to the oxygen saturation before blood passes through the ductus arteriosus.

  • The right upper limb (right hand) receives blood directly from the aorta before the ductus arteriosus, hence it reflects preductal oxygenation.

  • In contrast, the lower limbs and left upper limb may receive blood that is postductal, especially if the ductus is still patent.

Clinical Relevance:

  • Preductal SpO₂ is important during the first minutes after birth to assess the baby's transition from fetal to neonatal circulation.

  • Target preductal SpO₂ increases gradually over the first 10 minutes of life:

    • ~60–65% at 1 min

    • ~85–95% by 10 min

 

Left upper limb (Option A): This limb may receive postductal blood due to the anatomical position of the ductus arteriosus and is unreliable for preductal measurement.

Left lower limb (Option B): Postductal, as it receives blood distal to the ductus arteriosus.

Right lower limb (Option D): Also postductal; not appropriate for assessing preductal oxygenation.

questions.text: All of the following are clinical features of necrotizing enterocolitis, except?
questions.solution:
Correct option D: Metabolic alkalosis:

  • Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a serious condition that primarily affects premature infants and can lead to inflammation and necrosis of the intestines.
  • Metabolic alkalosis is not a clinical feature of necrotizing enterocolitis.
  • NEC is associated with metabolic acidosis due to tissue damage and compromised intestinal function.

Incorrect options: Options A, B, and C are clinical features of necrotizing enterocolitis.

questions.text: What is the primary reason for HIV infection in a newborn?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Perinatal transmission:

  • The most common cause of HIV infection in a newborn is through perinatal transmission, which occurs during pregnancy, childbirth, or breastfeeding.
  • Perinatal transmission accounts for the majority of pediatric HIV cases.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Breast milk:

  • Although breast milk can contain the HIV virus, the risk of transmission through breastfeeding is lower compared to perinatal transmission.
  • However, there is still a risk of HIV transmission through breast milk, especially in the absence of appropriate preventive measures.

Options C - Transplacental:

  • HIV transmission through the placenta, known as transplacental transmission, is rare.
  • However, in rare cases, such as when the mother has a high viral load, transplacental transmission can occur.

Options D - Exchange transfusion with infected blood:

  • It is an unlikely mode of transmission, as appropriate screening and testing of blood products significantly reduce the risk of transmitting HIV through transfusions.

questions.text: What is the primary factor for the closure of the ductus arteriosus after birth?

choices.text: Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2)

questions.solution:
Correct option A- Increase in partial pressure of oxygen (paO2).

  • The main factor for ductal closure postnatally is an increase in the partial pressure of oxygen in the blood.
  • When a newborn transitions from the intrauterine environment to the outside world, there is a sudden increase in the oxygen concentration due to the initiation of lung ventilation.
  • This increased oxygen tension acts as a stimulus for the closure of the ductus arteriosus.

Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are not the factors for the closure of the ductus arteriosus after birth.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiencies are associated with the presence of cardiac edema and neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Thiamine

 

Explanation:

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency leads to a condition known as beriberi, which presents in two primary clinical forms:

1. Wet Beriberi

  • Cardiac involvement is predominant

  • Features include:

    • Cardiac oedema

    • Tachycardia

    • Cardiomegaly

    • Congestive heart failure

2. Dry Beriberi

  • Neurological involvement is predominant

  • Features include:

    • Peripheral neuropathy

    • Muscle wasting

    • Numbness and weakness, especially in lower limbs

  • Therefore, thiamine deficiency is the only option that causes both cardiac oedema and neuropathy.

 

Biotin (Option A):

  • Biotin deficiency typically causes:

    • Dermatitis

    • Alopecia

    • Conjunctivitis

    • Neurological symptoms (e.g., depression, hallucinations), but not cardiac oedema or peripheral neuropathy.

Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) (Option C):

  • Pyridoxine deficiency leads to:

    • Neuropathy

    • Cheilitis

    • Glossitis

    • Irritability and seizures

    • But not cardiac oedema.

Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) (Option D):

  • Riboflavin deficiency typically results in:

    • Angular stomatitis

    • Glossitis

    • Seborrhoeic dermatitis

    • Photophobia

    • Cardiac or neurological symptoms are rare.

Vitamin Cardiac Oedema Neuropathy Other Features
Thiamine  Yes Yes Wet/dry beriberi
Biotin No Rare/mild Skin and CNS changes
Pyridoxine No Yes Seizures, cheilitis, glossitis
Riboflavin No No Skin, oral, and eye symptoms

questions.text: What is the most common reason for liver transplantation in children?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Biliary atresia:

  • Biliary atresia is the most common indication for liver transplantation in children.
  • It is a rare, progressive liver disease that affects infants, characterized by the absence or obstruction of the bile ducts, leading to bile flow impairment and subsequent liver damage.
  • Without surgical intervention, such as the Kasai procedure (hepatoportoenterostomy), biliary atresia can progress to liver failure, necessitating liver transplantation for long-term survival.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are not the most common indication for liver transplantation in children.

questions.text: While you are evaluating a baby, you show him a bright pink teddy bear that he reaches out to with both hands. What is the earliest age by which this milestone is typically achieved?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 4 months:

  • Reaching out for objects with both hands is a developmental milestone known as bilateral voluntary grasp. Typically, infants can start to achieve this milestone around 4 months of age.
  • At this stage, their hand-eye coordination and motor skills have developed enough to simultaneously reach out and grasp objects with both hands.

Incorrect Options: 

  • Options B, C, and D: These are not the correct ages at which bilateral voluntary grasp develops.

questions.text: What is the APGAR score for a newborn baby that is assessed 5 minutes after birth and found to be cyanosed with irregular gasping respiration, a heart rate of 60 beats/min, and minimal response to stimulation?
questions.solution:
Correct option D: 4:

  • The APGAR score is a quick assessment tool used to evaluate the overall condition and well-being of a newborn immediately after birth.
  • It consists of five components:
    • Appearance
    • Pulse rate
    • Grimace
    • Activity
    • Respiratory effort
  • Each component is scored from 0 to 2, with a total score ranging from 0 to 10.

In the given case:

  • Appearance: Cyanosed (score = 0)
  • Pulse rate: 60 beats/min (score = 1)
  • Grimace: Shows minimal response to stimulation (score = 1)
  • Activity: Some flexion of extremities (score = 1)
  • Respiratory effort: Irregular gasping respiration (score = 1)

Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed heart defect in congenital rubella syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - PDA:

  • Among the heart defects commonly associated with congenital rubella syndrome, the most prevalent is Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA).
  • PDA is a condition where the ductus arteriosus, a blood vessel connecting the pulmonary artery to the aorta in the fetus, remains open after birth.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D can be associated with congenital rubella syndrome but are not the most frequently observed.

questions.text: Which of the following choices best characterizes the chest X-ray picture?
questions.solution:
Correct option B - Coeur en sabot:

  • Coeur en sabot, or "boot-shaped heart," refers to a characteristic appearance of the heart on a chest X-ray.
  • It appears elongated and narrowed at the base, resembling the shape of a boot.
  • This is typically associated with congenital heart defects such as Tetralogy of Fallot.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Egg on string appearance: 

  • Egg on a string appearance is seen in a condition called Transposition of the Great Arteries.

​​​​​​​Option C: Scimitar sign:

  • The scimitar sign is seen in a condition called Scimitar syndrome, where a pulmonary vein from the right lung drains into the inferior vena cava instead of the left atrium.
  • This creates a characteristic curved appearance on the X-ray resembling a scimitar, a type of curved sword.

Option D - Snowman sign:

  • The snowman sign refers to the appearance of the pulmonary artery and its branches on a chest X-ray in certain conditions, such as pulmonary atresia with ventricular septal defect.
  • It appears as a "snowman" shape with the main pulmonary artery and its branches resembling the head and body of a snowman.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs cause carcinoma bladder?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cyclophosphamide:

  • Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating agent and an immunosuppressant that is used in the treatment of various cancers, including bladder cancer. However, long-term or high-dose use of cyclophosphamide has been associated with an increased risk of developing bladder carcinoma. It is important to note that the risk of bladder carcinoma is a potential side effect of cyclophosphamide, but not everyone who takes the drug will develop this condition.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cisplatin: Cisplatin is a chemotherapy drug commonly used to treat various types of cancer, but it is not typically associated with bladder carcinoma.

Option C - Taxane: Taxane drugs, such as paclitaxel and docetaxel, are commonly used in the treatment of breast, lung, and ovarian cancers. They are not known to be causally associated with bladder carcinoma.

Option D - Tamoxifen: Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) primarily used in the treatment of breast cancer. It is not known to be associated with bladder carcinoma.

questions.text: The most common site of branchial cyst is___.

choices.text: Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle
Junction of middle and lower third of the sternomastoid muscle
Between the two heads of the sternomastoid muscle

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Junction of upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle:

  • Branchial cysts are congenital abnormalities that occur due to incomplete closure or abnormal development of the branchial clefts, which are embryonic structures in the neck. The cysts typically develop along the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, typically at the junction of the upper and middle thirds of the Sternocleidomastoid.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C & D are incorrect; refer to the explanation of the correct answer and learning objective.

questions.text: Dohlman's procedure is for:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Dohlman's procedure, also known as pharyngoesophageal myotomy, is a surgical approach used to treat Zenker's diverticulum. It involves making a small incision or myotomy in the muscular wall between the esophagus and the diverticulum. This allows for the release of the pressure and improves the emptying of the diverticulum, relieving the associated symptoms.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Meckel's diverticulum: Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital anomaly of the small intestine.

Option C - Bochdalek hernia: Bochdalek hernia is a type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

Option D - Menetrier's disease: Menetrier's disease is a rare stomach disorder characterized by enlarged gastric folds and excessive mucus production.

questions.text: Parathyroid gland post-surgery is commonly transferred to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Brachioradialis:

  • In cases of parathyroid surgery, particularly in hyperparathyroidism caused by parathyroid hyperplasia, if a gland needs to be removed, it's common practice to transplant a portion of the remaining gland to ensure adequate parathyroid function.
  • The parathyroid tissue is typically divided into small pieces and transplanted into the brachioradialis muscle of the patient's non-dominant arm.
  • This transplantation allows the parathyroid tissue to continue its function of regulating calcium levels in the body.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and C: Triceps, Biceps & Sartorius:

  • The triceps, biceps, and sartorius are not commonly used for parathyroid gland transplantation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding rectal carcinoma?

choices.text: Hartmann's operation is done in elderly debilitated patients
Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma
Early morning spurious diarrhoea and tenesmus can occur
Growth confined to the rectal mucosa is stage A of modified Duke's staging

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Adenocarcinoma is a rare variant of rectal carcinoma:

  • Rectal carcinoma is predominantly composed of adenocarcinoma, which is the most common histological type of rectal cancer. Adenocarcinoma arises from the glandular cells lining the inner surface of the rectum. Therefore, adenocarcinoma is not a rare variant of rectal carcinoma; it is the most common type.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, C & D are correct.

questions.text: A gasless abdomen is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Acute pancreatitis:

  • In the context of the given options, acute pancreatitis is the condition associated with a gasless abdomen. In severe cases of acute pancreatitis, the inflammation and associated fluid collections can lead to a loss of normal gas patterns in the abdomen, resulting in a gasless appearance on imaging.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B & D are not the correct answer.

questions.text: Gall stone chemistry most commonly seen amongst the following is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate:

  • Gallstones can be composed of various substances, but the most common type of gallstone seen is made up of crystalline cholesterol monohydrate.
  • Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate stones are yellowish in color and make up approximately 80% of all gallstones.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Crystalline cholesterol dihydrate: Cholesterol dihydrate stones are less common and often coexist with cholesterol monohydrate stones.

Option C - Amorphous cholesterol dihydrate: Amorphous cholesterol dihydrate is a non-crystalline form of cholesterol that does not commonly contribute to the formation of gallstones.

Option D - Amorphous cholesterol monohydrate: Amorphous cholesterol monohydrate is another non-crystalline form of cholesterol that is not typically associated with the formation of gallstones.

questions.text: What does the presence of serpiginous ulcers during esophageal endoscopy in a patient indicate in terms of diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - CMV esophagitis:

  • When esophageal endoscopy reveals the presence of serpiginous ulcers, it is indicative of CMV (Cytomegalovirus) esophagitis.
  • The characteristic finding of serpiginous ulcers refers to the appearance of shallow, linear ulcers that follow a winding or serpentine pattern in the lining of the esophagus.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Candida esophagitis: It may present with white patches or plaques but not serpiginous ulcers.

Option C - Herpetic esophagitis: It can lead to small, shallow ulcers, but they are not typically described as serpiginous.

Option D - Radiation esophagitis: It can present with mucosal changes, ulcers, or strictures, but serpiginous ulcers are not a typical feature.

questions.text: Which section of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) is associated with the penalization of perjury?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Section 193 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC):

  • Section 193 of the IPC deals with the offense of giving false evidence in a judicial proceeding It specifies that whoever intentionally gives false evidence in any stage of a judicial proceeding, or fabricates false evidence intending it to be used in a judicial proceeding, shall be punished with imprisonment and/or a fine.

  • This section specifically addresses the punishment of perjury, which involves knowingly making false statements while under oath during a court proceeding.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Section 191: Section 191 of the IPC deals with the offense of giving false evidence

Option B - Section 192: Section 192 of the IPC relates to the offense of fabricating false evidence.

Option D - Section 197: Under Section 197, if a person in an official capacity knowingly issues or signs a false certificate, they can be punished with imprisonment and or a fine.

questions.text: Gastric lavage can be performed in case of which of the following poisoning?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Carbolic acid:

  • Carbolic acid, also known as phenol, is a toxic substance that can cause severe poisoning if ingested.

  • Gastric lavage, or stomach pumping, can be performed in cases of carbolic acid poisoning.

  • The procedure involves introducing a tube into the stomach to wash out the toxic substance and reduce its absorption into the body.

  • Gastric lavage is considered beneficial in removing any remaining carbolic acid from the stomach and can be an important part of the treatment protocol for carbolic acid poisoning.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sulphuric acid: Sulphuric acid is a highly corrosive and dangerous substance. In cases of sulphuric acid poisoning, gastric lavage is generally not recommended as it may cause further damage to the gastrointestinal tract. Immediate medical attention and appropriate management are crucial in cases of sulphuric acid poisoning to minimize harm and provide necessary treatment.

Option B - Strychnine: Strychnine is a highly toxic alkaloid that affects the nervous system. Gastric lavage is typically not performed in cases of strychnine poisoning. The primary focus of treatment for strychnine poisoning involves managing symptoms, such as muscle spasms and seizures, providing supportive care, and administering specific antidotes as appropriate.

Option D - Kerosene oil: Kerosene oil ingestion can lead to chemical pneumonia or aspiration pneumonia if it enters the lungs. Gastric lavage is not routinely recommended for kerosene oil poisoning. Treatment primarily involves supportive care, monitoring for any respiratory complications, and providing appropriate respiratory support if needed.

questions.text: Frotteurism is characterized as _____________:

choices.text: Obtaining sexual pleasure by wearing clothes of opposite sex
Desire to seek surgery to become member of opposite sex
Sexual gratification by rubbing his private parts against another person
Exposure of one’s genitals to an unsuspecting stranger

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sexual gratification by rubbing his private parts against another person:

  • Frotteurism refers to the sexual gratification derived from rubbing one's genitals against another person without their consent.
  • It typically occurs in crowded places or situations where the person can engage in this behavior discreetly
  • Frotteurism is considered a paraphilic disorder and is associated with non-consensual sexual behavior.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Obtaining sexual pleasure by wearing clothes of the opposite sex: This option describes cross-dressing or transvestism.

Option B - Desire to seek surgery to become a member of the opposite sex: This option refers to gender dysphoria.

Option D - Exposure of one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger: This option describes describes exhibitionism

questions.text: Identical twins have similarities in all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Fingerprint pattern:

  • Fingerprint patterns are not solely determined by genetic factors but also influenced by other developmental factors during the formation of the ridges and patterns on the fingers. As a result, even identical twins will have distinct fingerprint patterns.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Blood group: Identical twins typically have the same blood group.

Option B - DNA fingerprinting: Identical twins will have virtually identical DNA profiles as they share the same genetic information

Option D - Iris color: Identical twins often have similar iris colors as it is influenced by genetic factors. While there can be slight variations in shade or intensity, the overall color of the iris is usually similar between identical twins.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes battered baby syndrome?

choices.text: Skin lesions and bruises of various ages are seen on the body
It occurs due to the tendency of a child to fall repeatedly
The syndrome is a result of firearm injuries

questions.solution:
Correct Choice A: Battered baby syndrome refers to a pattern of injuries seen in infants and young children who have been physically abused. The correct statement states that skin lesions and bruises of various ages are seen on the body in cases of battered baby syndrome. This is an accurate description of the syndrome. Abused children often present with multiple injuries in different stages of healing, indicating repeated episodes of abuse over time. These injuries can include bruises, burns, fractures, and other signs of physical trauma.

Incorrect Options 

Option B: It occurs due to the tendency of a child to fall repeatedly (Incorrect) This statement is incorrect. Battered baby syndrome is not caused by the child's tendency to fall repeatedly. It is a result of physical abuse inflicted by a caregiver or other individuals responsible for the child's care.

Option C: Multiple stab wounds are seen (Incorrect) This statement is incorrect. Battered baby syndrome does not involve multiple stab wounds. The term "battered" refers to physical abuse, which typically involves acts such as hitting, shaking, or throwing the child, rather than stabbing.

Option D: The syndrome is a result of firearm injuries (Incorrect) This statement is incorrect. Battered baby syndrome is not specifically associated with firearm injuries. It refers to a pattern of physical abuse and injuries inflicted on an infant or young child by a caregiver or another individual.

questions.text: Which of the following tests relies on the principle that the suspect's reaction is influenced by their prior knowledge of the events or activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Brain Mapping - Brain mapping, also known as functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), is a test that is based on the principle that prior knowledge of events or activity can influence a person's brain activity and responses. By analyzing the brain's neural activity and patterns, brain mapping aims to detect deception or hidden information. It measures changes in blood flow and oxygenation in different areas of the brain to determine if specific stimuli or questions elicit different responses. This method is used in forensic investigations to assess a person's knowledge or involvement in certain events.

Incorrect Options 

Option A: Truth Serum - Truth serum refers to a drug or chemical agent administered to a person with the intention of eliciting truthful information. However, the reliability and effectiveness of truth serum in obtaining accurate information are highly debated. Its use is not widely accepted in legal or investigative settings, and it is not considered a reliable method of determining truth.

Option B: Polygraph- A polygraph, commonly known as a lie detector test, measures physiological changes in a person's body such as heart rate, blood pressure, and respiration while they are asked a series of questions. Although polygraph tests are widely used, their accuracy and reliability are controversial. The results of a polygraph test are not considered definitive evidence of deception and are often not admissible in court.

Option D: Hypnosis- Hypnosis involves inducing an altered state of consciousness in a person where they are more receptive to suggestions. While hypnosis can be used in investigative settings, its reliability and accuracy in eliciting truthful information are debated. The use of hypnosis as evidence or a definitive method for determining truth is not widely accepted.

questions.text: In alleged history of gunshot injury, there is burning, blackening, tattooing around the wound. The injury is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Close shot entry wound:

  • When a gunshot injury occurs at close range, the muzzle of the firearm is in close proximity to the body. In such cases, the burning, blackening, and tattooing of the skin around the wound are commonly observed. These characteristics are due to the presence of unburned gunpowder particles and hot gasses discharged from the firearm.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Close shot exit wound: In close shot exit wounds, the burning, blackening, and tattooing effects are usually not present. Close shot exit wounds are characterized by an irregular or stellate appearance, as the bullet exits the body and causes tissue disruption.

Option C - Distant shot entry wound: In distant shot entry wounds, there is a significant distance between the muzzle of the firearm and the body. The effects of burning, blackening, and tattooing are not typically observed in such cases. Distant shot entry wounds may appear as small, circular or oval-shaped holes without the characteristics associated with close-range shots.

Option D - Distant shot exit wound: Similar to distant shot entry wounds, distant shot exit wounds do not exhibit the effects of burning, blackening, and tattooing. These exit wounds are often characterized by a smaller size compared to close shot exit wounds.

questions.text: Rigor mortis occurs first in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Myocardium:

  • Rigor mortis refers to the stiffening of the body's muscles after death due to biochemical changes in muscle tissue.

  • It typically begins within a few hours after death and progresses gradually over the next 6 to 12 hours. 

  • Rigor mortis first appears in the heart muscle within an hour after death.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B & D - Eyelids, Intestines & Neck:

  • Among the voluntary muscles, rigor mortis usually develops sequentially and follows a descending pattern, the so-called Nysten’s law:

    • It first appears in the muscles of the eye lids (orbicularis oculi) (3–5 h), then in jaw, facial muscles (4–5 h), neck, thorax (5–7 h) upper limb (from shoulder to the hand) (7–9 h), abdomen, lower limb (from the hip to the foot) (9–11 h), and lastly in the small muscles of fingers and toes (11–12 h).

questions.text: Which of the following joint is the best predictor of age of 16 to 17 years by X-ray?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ankle:

  • For estimation of age by X-ray -  At 16 to 17 years - Ankle joint

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Knee: At 18 to 19 years - knee, shoulder and wrist joint

Option B - Elbow: At age of 16 years elbow joint

Option C - Hip: At age of 17 to 18 years

questions.text: Which of the following acts as a physiological antidote to scorpion venom?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Prazosin:

  • Prazosin is a medication classified as an alpha-1 adrenergic antagonist. It works by blocking the action of certain receptors in the body, specifically the alpha-1 adrenergic receptors.

  • In the case of scorpion envenomation, scorpion venom typically contains compounds that can stimulate the release of catecholamines, such as norepinephrine, leading to sympathetic overactivity. This can result in symptoms such as hypertension and increased heart rate.

  • By blocking the alpha-1 adrenergic receptors, prazosin helps to counteract the effects of the excessive sympathetic stimulation caused by scorpion venom. It helps to relax smooth muscles in blood vessels, reducing blood pressure and improving symptoms associated with scorpion envenomation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Physostigmine: Physostigmine is a medication that acts as an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, increasing the availability of acetylcholine in the body. While it can be used as an antidote for certain types of poisoning, such as anticholinergic toxicity, it is not typically used as a specific antidote for scorpion venom.

Option B - Norepinephrine: Norepinephrine is a naturally occurring neurotransmitter and hormone that is involved in the sympathetic nervous system response. While norepinephrine might be elevated in scorpion envenomation, it is not considered a specific physiological antidote to scorpion venom.

Option D - Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic medication that blocks the action of acetylcholine in the body. It is commonly used to counteract the effects of excessive acetylcholine stimulation. However, in the case of scorpion envenomation, the primary issue is excessive sympathetic activity rather than excessive cholinergic activity. Therefore, atropine is not the preferred physiological antidote for scorpion venom.

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly used for preservation of viscera in toxicology autopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Saturated salt solution:

  • Saturated salt solution is commonly used for the preservation of viscera in toxicology autopsy. It is a hypertonic solution that helps to prevent decomposition and maintain the integrity of the tissues for further toxicological analysis. The high salt concentration creates an osmotic environment that inhibits bacterial growth and enzymatic degradation.

  • Various methods of preserving viscera:

    1. Saturated salt solution

    2. Formalin fixation

    3. Freezing

    4. Alcohol preservation

    5. Formaldehyde solution

    6. Formalin-alcohol solution

    7. Frozen section

    8. Liquid nitrogen

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Glycerin: Glycerin is not commonly used for the preservation of viscera in toxicology autopsy. While it has some preservative properties, it is not as effective as saturated salt solution for maintaining tissue integrity and preventing decomposition.

Option B - Rectified spirit: Rectified spirit, which is a type of alcohol, is not typically used for preservation in toxicology autopsy. It may have some disinfectant properties but is not suitable for long-term tissue preservation.

Option C - Formalin: Formalin is commonly used for general tissue preservation and fixation in anatomical pathology, but it is not specifically preferred for toxicology autopsy. It may affect the results of toxicological analyses and can interfere with certain tests.

questions.text: According to myogenic hypothesis of renal autoregulation the afferent arterioles contract in response?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Calcium:

  • According to the myogenic hypothesis, it suggests that when the afferent arterioles experience an increase in blood pressure or stretch, it triggers the opening of calcium channels in the smooth muscle cells of the arterioles.
  • The influx of calcium ions leads to vasoconstriction, reducing the blood flow and preventing excessive pressure within the glomerulus. This response helps maintain a relatively constant blood flow and glomerular filtration rate despite changes in systemic blood pressure.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A and B: These are not involved in the autoregulation of GFR.

Option D - Adenosine: Adenosine is a mediator of tubuloglomerular feedback mechanism.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic of decerebrate rigidity according to the Herrington classification?

choices.text: Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron
Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
Mid Collicular lesion can lead to decerebrate rigidity

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body:

  • Decerebrate rigidity primarily affects the extensor muscles of the limbs, leading to the characteristic posture of rigid extension. It does not affect all the muscles of the body equally.
  • According to the Herrington classification, decerebrate rigidity is a form of abnormal muscle tone that occurs due to damage or dysfunction in the medulla resulting in increased activity of motoneurons that facilitate stretch reflexes.
  • Facilitation of stretch reflexes occurs due to two mechanisms:
    • Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool in general.
    • Increased rate of γ motor neuron discharge.
  • Producing a mid-collicular lesion in an experimental animal results in decerebration.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: Which of the options accurately describes decorticate rigidity?

choices.text: It is produced by the removal of cerebral cortex and basal ganglia.
Flexion of lower limbs and extension of upper limbs occurs.
It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs: 

  • Injury to the cerebral cortex results in decorticate rigidity, characterized by upper extremity flexion at the elbow and increased extension in the lower extremities.
  • The flexion of the upper extremities is explained by rubrospinal excitation of flexor muscles, while the hyperextension of the lower extremities is due to dysfunction in the medulla, resulting in increased activity of motoneurons that facilitate stretch reflexes.
  • Dysfunction in the descending pathways that control muscle tone and movement.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.text: What would be the duration for preserving red blood cells (RBCs) using Acid Citrate Dextrose (ACD) for storage, when phosphate is added alone and when adenine and phosphate are added together to ACD?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is:

Option B. 21 days and 35 days

Explanation:

  • Red Blood Cells (RBCs) Preservation using ACD (Acid Citrate Dextrose): ACD is an anticoagulant solution used for the preservation of blood. When RBCs are preserved using ACD alone, the duration of storage is approximately 21 days.

  • Addition of Adenine and Phosphate to ACD: Adenine and phosphate are often added to the ACD solution to enhance the preservation of RBCs. With the addition of adenine and phosphate to ACD, the duration of storage is extended to approximately 35 days.

These additives provide necessary nutrients and enhance the storage conditions, allowing for a longer preservation period of red blood cells.

questions.text: Functional residual capacity is:

choices.text: Volume that remains after forced expiration

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Expiratory reserve volume + residual volume: 

  • Functional residual capacity (FRC) is the volume of air that remains in the lungs after a normal tidal expiration.
  • It is calculated by adding the expiratory reserve volume (the amount of air that can still be exhaled after a normal tidal expiration) to the residual volume and is equal to the 2.3L.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Volume expired after normal inspiration: The volume expired after a normal inspiration is referred to as the tidal volume and is around 500 ml..

Option B - Volume that remains after forced expiration: The volume that remains after a forced expiration is the residual volume and is around 1.2 L.

Option D - Tidal volume + inspiratory reserve volume: The sum of the tidal volume and the inspiratory reserve volume represents inspiratory capacity and is around 3.5L.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a dietary fiber?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D-Gums :

  • Gums like guar gum, locust bean gum, and xanthan gum are hydrocolloids derived from plants and used as food additives for thickening, stabilizing, and emulsifying. While they may contribute to dietary fiber content, they lack the same health benefits as natural dietary fibers.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Cellulose: Insoluble fiber found in plant cell walls, adds bulk to stool.

Option B - Inulin: Soluble fiber found in chicory root, acts as a prebiotic.

Option C - Pectin: Soluble fiber found in fruits, used as a thickening agent, promotes satiety.

questions.text: What is the effect of a lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of the pons?

choices.text: Pain and temperature loss in the same side
Pain and temperature loss in the opposite side
Loss of tactile and proprioception on the same side
Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Loss of tactile and proprioception on the opposite side:
 

  • A lesion in the medial lemniscus at the level of the pons would lead to damage in the dorsal column pathway as the second order neurons pass from it to reach thalamus.
  • The second order neurons arise from nucleus gracilis and cuneatus of the contralateral side.. These are responsible for the transmitting the following sensations:
    • Fine touch
    • Vibration
    • Proprioception
    • Tactile localization
    • Tactile discrimination
    • Stereognosis
  • So, damage to the dorsal column pathway at medial lemniscus will result in loss of proprioception and tactile on the opposite side.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are incorrect. Refer to Option D for an explanation.

questions.text: Which specific neurotransmitter is accountable for causing dilation of the small intestine in a forward direction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - VIP (Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide):

  • Vasoactive Intestinal Peptide (VIP) is a neurotransmitter released when the cholinergic neuron from the myenteric plexus moves in the anterograde direction of the peristalsis.
  • It acts as a relaxant on smooth muscles in the proximal segment of the segment containing chyme, resulting in relaxation of the proximal segment of the chyme and movement of the content towards the rectum.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Acetylcholine: Acetylcholine is the primary neurotransmitter released by cholinergic neurons in the retrograde direction of the peristalsis and results in the contraction of the smooth muscle.

Option C - Substance P: Substance P is a neurotransmitter that is released when cholinergic neuron from the myenteric plexus moves in the retrograde direction of the peristalsis and results in the contraction of the smooth muscle.

Option D - Serotonin: Serotonin is a neurotransmitter that is secreted by the gastric epithelial cells in response to stretch due to food. It is responsible for the activation of myenteric plexus resulting in coordinated movements in peristalsis.

questions.text: Which reflex is responsible for tachycardia when the right atrium is distended?
questions.solution:
Correct option is D: Bainbridge reflex.

  • The Bainbridge reflex is responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension. When the right atrium becomes stretched or distended due to an increased volume of blood, specialized stretch receptors in the atrial wall called atrial mechanoreceptors are activated. These mechanoreceptors send signals to the cardiovascular control centers in the brain, resulting in an increase in heart rate through the Bainbridge reflex. This reflex helps to regulate cardiac output by increasing heart rate to accommodate the increased venous return to the heart.

Incorrect options:

Option A: J reflex: The J reflex is a pulmonary reflex that is involved in regulating airway resistance and breathing. It is not directly related to tachycardia during right atrial distension.

Option B: Cushing reflex: The Cushing reflex refers to a physiological response that occurs in the brain in response to increased intracranial pressure. It leads to increased blood pressure and decreased heart rate, which is the opposite of tachycardia.

Option C: Bezold-Jarisch reflex: The Bezold-Jarisch reflex is a reflex that can be triggered by stimulation of specialized sensory receptors in the heart, typically in response to excessive ventricular filling or ischemia. It leads to a decrease in heart rate, vasodilation, and hypotension.

questions.text: The primary source of testosterone production is primarily contributed by _________.
questions.solution:
Correct option is A: Leydig cells.

  • Testosterone production is primarily contributed by Leydig cells, also known as interstitial cells, which are found in the testes. Leydig cells are located in the connective tissue surrounding the seminiferous tubules in the testes.
  • Leydig cells are responsible for the synthesis and secretion of testosterone, which is the primary male sex hormone. Testosterone plays a crucial role in the development and maintenance of male reproductive organs, secondary sexual characteristics, and overall reproductive function.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Sertoli cells: Sertoli cells are located within the seminiferous tubules of the testes. They have essential functions in supporting and nourishing developing sperm cells, including providing nutrients and regulating their growth. However, Sertoli cells are not primarily responsible for testosterone production.

Option C: Seminiferous tubules: Seminiferous tubules are the structures within the testes where sperm production takes place. While the seminiferous tubules play a critical role in spermatogenesis, they are not directly involved in testosterone production.

Option D: Epididymis: The epididymis is a long, coiled tube located on the back of each testicle. It serves as a storage and maturation site for sperm cells. The epididymis does not have a primary role in testosterone production.

questions.text: What is the cause of the appearance observed in IVP?
questions.solution:
Correct Option b: Ureterococele.

Option b : Ureterococele refers to the dilation or swelling of the lower end of the ureter where it enters the bladder. In this condition, the ureter balloon-like structure fills with urine, creating a characteristic appearance on imaging called "cobra head and adder head deformity" or "spring onion sign." This appearance is caused by the ballooning of the ureter within the bladder.

 

Incorrect options

Option a: Horseshoe kidney is a congenital condition where the lower ends of the two kidneys are fused together.

Option c: Bladder tumor refers to abnormal growths or masses in the bladder. Bladder tumors can cause changes in the appearance of the bladder on imaging studies.

Option d: Posterior urethral valve is a congenital condition where there is an abnormal valve-like structure in the urethra, obstructing the flow of urine.

questions.text: What is the role of tubuloglomerular feedback?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Regulate GFR:

  • Tubuloglomerular feedback is responsible for the autoregulation of GFR.. The juxtaglomerular apparatus, which consists of macula densa cells, has an NKCC channel in the luminal membrane which absorbs Na+, K+, and 2 Cl-. The transport of Na+ across the basolateral membrane requires Na+K+ ATPase leading to increased adenosine formation.
  • The lacis cells have A1 receptor for the adenosine leading to influx of Ca2+ into lacis cells and then diffuses into smooth muscles of afferent arteriole leading to constriction and juxtaglomerular cells leading to decrease in renin release.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Decrease plasma sodium: The regulation of plasma sodium concentration primarily Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: What is the blood group determined by the agglutination test depicted below?
questions.solution:
Correct option is C:  O positive.

  • O positive: In this case, there is no agglutination in either A or B antigens, indicating the absence of ABO antigens on the red blood cells. Blood group O is known as the universal donor because individuals with blood group O do not have A or B antigens on their red blood cells.

Incorrect options:

Option A : B positive: Since there is no agglutination in the B antigen, it is not indicative of blood group B. Therefore, option a) is incorrect.

Option B: A positive: Similarly, since there is no agglutination in the A antigen, it is not indicative of blood group A. Therefore, option b) is incorrect.

Option D: AB positive: Agglutination in both A and B antigens would indicate the presence of both A and B antigens on the red blood cells, which corresponds to blood group AB. However, since no agglutination is observed in the A or B antigens in this case, blood group AB is not the correct option. Therefore, option d) is incorrect.

questions.text: During forceful expiration, which type of neurons primarily exhibit increased firing?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Caudal Ventral group of neurons:

  • Caudal ventral respiratory group neurons mainly contain the expiratory group of neurons, which is dominantly discharged during forceful expiration.
  • During forceful expiration, one takes the help of the accessory muscles of respiration, for example, the abdominal muscles and internal intercostal muscles.
  • These are all contracted during forceful expiration. This control is exerted by the caudal ventral respiratory group neurons.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dorsal group of neurons: The dorsal group of neurons, also known as the dorsal respiratory group (DRG), is responsible for integrating sensory signals from the peripherals, such as the lungs or the muscles.

Option C - Pneumotaxic center: The pneumotaxic center, also known as the pontine respiratory group, is a part of the brainstem that regulates the rate of breathing.

Option D - Apneustic center: Apneustic center is also a pontine respiratory group that regulates the depth of breathing.

questions.text: Through which aquaporin channel does ADH act?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is B - 2:

  • Vasopressin acts on Aquaporin 2 (AQP2) channels present in the collecting duct. When vasopressin binds to its V2 receptor on the basolateral membrane of the collecting duct cells, it triggers increased cAMP levels promoting the translocation and insertion of AQP2 channels into the apical membrane. This insertion allows for increased water reabsorption from the urine, leading to concentrated urine and water conservation.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C, and D are incorrect. These are ADH independent hormones.

questions.text: Which of the following options has the slowest conduction velocity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Postganglionic sympathetic fibers:

  • Postganglionic sympathetic fibers have the least conduction velocity compared to the other options as these are unmyelinated fibers. These fibers are part of the autonomic nervous system and transmit signals from the autonomic ganglia to target organs, such as smooth muscles, cardiac muscles, and glands.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. These fibers have a higher conduction velocity than postganglionic sympathetic fibers of the autonomic nervous system.

questions.text: Which part of the liver stores vitamin A?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ito cells:

  • Ito cells, also known as hepatic stellate cells, are responsible for storing vitamin A in the liver. These cells are found in the space of Disse, which is located between the hepatocytes and endothelial cells in the liver sinusoids. Ito cells store vitamin A as lipid droplets within their cytoplasm.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation

questions.text: Which of the following is not synthesized by the liver?
questions.solution:
Correct option is D: Immunoglobulin.

  • Immunoglobulins, also known as antibodies, are primarily produced by plasma cells, which are a type of white blood cell derived from B lymphocytes. While the liver is involved in immune-related functions, such as phagocytosis by Kupffer cells, it does not synthesize immunoglobulins.

Incorrect options

Option A: Albumin is a protein synthesized by the liver. It is the most abundant protein in the blood and plays a crucial role in maintaining oncotic pressure, transporting substances such as hormones and drugs, and regulating fluid balance.

Option B: Coagulation factors, such as fibrinogen, prothrombin, and factors VII, VIII, IX, X, are produced by the liver. These factors are essential for blood clotting and are involved in the coagulation cascade.

Option C: Acute phase proteins, including C-reactive protein, haptoglobin, and serum amyloid A, are synthesized by the liver. They are part of the immune response and play a role in inflammation and tissue repair.

questions.text: In peripheral oxygen sensing chemoreceptors, which ion is implicated?
questions.solution:
Correct option is A: Potassium.

  • Potassium ions (K+) are involved in peripheral oxygen-sensing chemoreceptors. These chemoreceptors, known as peripheral chemoreceptors or arterial chemoreceptors, are primarily located in the carotid bodies and aortic bodies. They detect changes in oxygen levels in the blood and play a crucial role in regulating respiratory and cardiovascular responses.

Incorrect options

Option B: Calcium ions (Ca2+) are not directly involved in peripheral oxygen-sensing chemoreceptors. However, calcium ions are important for various cellular processes and signaling pathways within the body.

Option C: Sodium ions (Na+) are not directly involved in peripheral oxygen-sensing chemoreceptors. Sodium ions play a critical role in maintaining the body's fluid balance, nerve impulse transmission, and muscle contraction.

Option D: Chlorine ions (Cl-) are not directly involved in peripheral oxygen-sensing chemoreceptors. Chlorine ions primarily function as an anion to maintain electrical neutrality and are involved in maintaining the osmotic balance and acid-base balance in the body.

questions.text: What is the defining characteristic of Brown-Séquard syndrome?

choices.text: Fine touch lost on the opposite side
Pain and temperature lost on the same side
Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side
Only pain lost on the same side

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side: 

  • Brown Sequard syndrome occurs due to the hemisection of the spinal cord.
  • It is characterized by:
    • On the side of the lesion: Loss of touch, proprioception, vibration, and tactile discrimination are lost due to damage to the dorsal column pathway.
    • On the opposite side: Pain and thermal sensations are lost due to damage to the spinothalamic tract.

 

Incorrect Option:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			A. Epidural hematoma
			
			
			i. 
			
		
		
			
			B. Subdural hematoma
			
			
			ii. 
			
		
		
			
			C. Subarchniod hemorrhage
			
			
			iii. 
			
		
		
			
			D. Intracerebral hemorrhage
			
			
			iv.
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option b. A-ii, B-iv, C-i, D-iii:

Epidural hematoma (A) typically presents as a lens-shaped collection of blood between the skull and the dura mater, which is assigned to ii.

Subdural hematoma (B), a collection of blood between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater, is assigned to iv.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (C), bleeding into the subarachnoid space, is assigned to i.

Intracerebral hemorrhage (D), bleeding within the brain tissue itself, is assigned to iii.

Incorrect options

Options A, C, and D are incorrectly matched.

questions.text: What investigation is depicted in the radiograph among the following options?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: Barium meal, also known as upper gastrointestinal series or barium upper GI, involves the administration of barium contrast to visualize the stomach and upper gastrointestinal tract. The radiograph shown appears to be a study of the stomach, which aligns with a barium meal examination.

Incorrect options

Option A: Barium swallow typically involves the ingestion of barium contrast to visualize the esophagus and upper gastrointestinal tract. The radiograph shown is not specific to the esophagus alone, but rather includes the entire stomach and possibly the small intestine. Therefore, a barium swallow is not the most appropriate investigation for the radiograph.

Option C: Barium meal follow through involves the sequential imaging of the stomach and small intestine after ingestion of barium contrast. While the radiograph shown may include the stomach and possibly the upper small intestine, it does not specifically demonstrate the entire course of the small intestine. Therefore, a barium meal follow through is not the most accurate option.

Option D: Barium enema, also known as lower gastrointestinal series or barium lower GI, involves the administration of barium contrast through the rectum to visualize the large intestine. The radiograph shown does not depict the large intestine but rather focuses on the stomach. Therefore, a barium enema is not the correct option.

questions.text: Which imaging study is most effective in diagnosing cerebral infarct at the earliest stage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: Diffusion-weighted MRI is considered the best imaging study for the earliest diagnosis of cerebral infarcts. It is highly sensitive to changes in the diffusion of water molecules within brain tissue, allowing for the early detection of ischemic changes associated with infarction. Diffusion-weighted MRI can detect small, acute infarcts within minutes to hours of symptom onset, making it a valuable tool for early diagnosis.

 

Incorrect option

Option A: FLAIR MRI (Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery MRI) is a sensitive imaging technique for detecting abnormalities in the brain, such as cerebral infarcts.

Option B: Non-contrast CT (Computed Tomography) is often the initial imaging modality used in the evaluation of stroke or cerebral infarcts. It can help identify hemorrhagic strokes and large infarcts but may not be as sensitive in detecting small or early infarcts compared to diffusion-weighted MRI.

Option C: CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT) involves the use of a contrast agent to enhance the visualization of blood vessels and certain brain abnormalities.

questions.text: What is your diagnosis based on the chest X-ray of a patient during the evaluation of PUO?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Miliary tuberculosis refers to a disseminated form of tuberculosis in which tiny, widely scattered lesions appear throughout the lungs, resembling millet seeds. The chest X-ray image shown may display numerous small nodules diffusely distributed throughout the lung fields, indicating miliary tuberculosis.

 

Incorrect options

Option B: Pulmonary edema typically presents as an abnormal accumulation of fluid in the lungs. It is characterized by the presence of increased opacity or "whiteness" in the lung fields on a chest X-ray. T

Option C: Necrobiotic nodules are a manifestation of various underlying conditions, including rheumatoid arthritis, sarcoidosis, and other granulomatous diseases. These nodules appear as discrete, well-defined opacities on a chest X-ray.

Option D: Tuberculoma refers to a localized tuberculous infection within the lung that typically presents as a single or few well-circumscribed nodules.

questions.text: Please determine the anatomical structure indicated in the provided MRI scan.
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: Cerebellum is a distinct structure located at the back of the brain, beneath the occipital lobes of the cerebrum. It plays a crucial role in motor coordination, balance, and posture. The MRI scan clearly shows the cerebellum as the marked structure, making it the correct option.

 

Incorrect options

Option A: Midbrain is a part of the brainstem located above the pons and below the cerebral hemispheres. It plays a role in various functions such as motor control, visual and auditory processing. The MRI scan shown does not depict the midbrain; instead, it focuses on the posterior aspect of the brain.

Option C: Brainstem refers to the lower part of the brain that connects the cerebrum with the spinal cord. It consists of the midbrain, pons, and medulla oblongata. While the MRI scan includes a portion of the brainstem, the structure marked in the image is specifically the cerebellum, not the entire brainstem.

Option D: Cerebrum is the largest part of the brain and is responsible for various higher cognitive functions such as memory, language, perception, and conscious thought. The MRI scan does not primarily focus on the cerebrum, but rather on the posterior aspect of the brain, which includes the cerebellum.

questions.text: Which of the following is a water soluble contrast?
questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option a: Iohexol is a water-soluble contrast agent commonly used in medical imaging procedures such as CT scans and angiography. It is a radiopaque substance that can be dissolved in water, allowing for its administration intravenously or through other routes.

 

Incorrect options

Option b: Barium is not a water-soluble contrast agent. Barium sulfate is commonly used as a contrast agent for imaging the gastrointestinal tract. It is insoluble in water and is typically administered orally or rectally in the form of a suspension.

Option c: Bromium is not a commonly used contrast agent in medical imaging. It is a chemical element and is not typically employed as a water-soluble contrast agent.

Option d: Calcium is not a water-soluble contrast agent. It is an essential mineral in the body and does not serve as a contrast agent in medical imaging.

questions.text: All of the following could be the cause of the presence of free air under the diaphragm except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: Acute intestinal obstruction refers to a blockage in the intestine that prevents the passage of intestinal contents. While acute intestinal obstruction can cause distension of the bowel and the accumulation of gas and fluid, it typically does not result in free air under the diaphragm. The presence of free air under the diaphragm is more suggestive of perforation or leakage of air from a hollow organ into the peritoneal cavity. 

 

Incorrect options

Option A: Duodenal ulcer perforation refers to a complication of a duodenal ulcer in which a hole forms in the wall of the duodenum. This can result in the leakage of gastrointestinal contents into the peritoneal cavity, leading to a condition called pneumoperitoneum. Pneumoperitoneum can be visualized on an X-ray as free air under the diaphragm, indicating the presence of air in the abdominal cavity.

Option B: Post laparoscopy refers to the period following a laparoscopic surgery. During laparoscopy, carbon dioxide gas is used to inflate the abdominal cavity, creating space for the surgeon to operate. After the surgery, some residual carbon dioxide gas may remain in the abdomen. This residual gas can be visualized on an X-ray as small pockets of air or gas bubbles.

Option C: Chilaiditi syndrome is a rare condition characterized by the interposition of the colon between the liver and the diaphragm. This can lead to the trapping of gas in the colonic segments under the liver, resulting in the appearance of gas-filled spaces on an X-ray. Therefore, Chilaiditi syndrome can be a cause of the X-ray finding.

questions.text: The type of knot seen in the image is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B:

The reef knot that is commonly used in surgical procedures. It is a secure knot that is used to secure and hold sutures in place.

The reef knot, also known as the square knot, is a type of knot that is commonly used for joining two ends of a single line together. It is formed by interlocking the ends of the line in opposite directions, creating a flat, symmetrical knot.

To tie a reef knot, you can follow these steps:

  1. Take the two ends of the line you want to join.
  2. Cross the right end over the left end.
  3. Bring the right end under the left end.
  4. Pass the right end over the left end again.
  5. Pull both ends simultaneously to tighten the knot.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option A:

Half hitch knot:

The half hitch knot is a simple knot that is created by passing the working end of a rope over and around a post or another rope and then through the loop created. It is commonly used for temporary or light-duty applications, such as securing a line to a pole or creating a simple loop. The half hitch knot involves a single turn around an object, while the reef knot involves interlocking turns of two ends.

 

Option C:

Surgeon's knot:

The surgeon's knot is a knot commonly used in surgical procedures and also in various other applications that require a secure knot. It is an extension of the reef knot, designed to be more secure. The surgeon's knot involves tying an additional half hitch before completing the knot, which adds more friction and stability. It is often used to secure sutures or tie ligatures.

 

Option D:

Crossed half hitch knot:

The crossed half hitch knot, also known as the clove hitch knot, is a knot that is made by crossing the working end of a rope over the standing part and then passing it under and over itself to form a hitch. It is commonly used for securing objects to posts or poles and can be easily adjusted or untied. While it may have similarities in terms of crossed elements with the reef knot, the crossed half hitch knot is fundamentally a different knot.

questions.text: What is the drug used for estrogen dependant breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Tamoxifen:

  • Tamoxifen is the preferred hormonal therapy for pre-menopausal patients with estrogen-dependent breast cancer, acting as a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM).
  • It exhibits potent antagonistic effects on breast cancer cells and blood vessels, with a recommended dose of 10 mg twice daily for 5 years.
  • Tamoxifen also displays partial agonistic effects on tissues like the pituitary, bone, uterus, and liver. However, its use is avoided in post-menopausal patients due to the increased risk of endometrial cancer.
  • Tamoxifen functions by preventing estrogen from binding to estrogen receptors on breast cancer cells, thereby inhibiting their growth.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lapatinib: Lapatinib targets HER2-positive breast cancer via tyrosine kinase inhibition.

Option B - Sunitinib: Sunitinib is used in advanced renal cell carcinoma and gastrointestinal stromal tumors, not estrogen-dependent breast cancer.

Option D - Adriamycin: Adriamycin is a chemotherapy agent for various cancers, including breast cancer, but not specifically for estrogen-dependent types.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common surgical approach for a retrosternal goiter?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cervical incision:

  • Cervical incision is the most common surgical approach for retrosternal goiter because the vascular supply of the thyroid primarily comes from vessels in the cervical region.

  • Thyroidectomy via cervical incision allows direct access to the retrosternal goiter while minimizing the risk of damaging important structures in the mediastinum.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mediastinal incision:

  • Mediastinal incision is not commonly preferred for retrosternal goiter because it involves accessing the thoracic cavity, which carries higher risks compared to cervical incision.

  • Direct access to the thyroid gland can be challenging via a mediastinal incision, and there's a higher risk of complications due to the proximity to vital structures in the chest.

Option B - Subxiphoid incision:

  • Subxiphoid incision is not typically used for retrosternal goiter as it involves accessing the thyroid gland through an incision below the sternum.

  • This approach is more commonly utilized for surgeries involving the heart or other structures in the mediastinum, not specifically for thyroidectomy.

Option C - Transaxillary incision:

  • Transaxillary incision involves accessing the thyroid gland through an incision in the axilla (armpit).

  • While this approach may be suitable for certain thyroid surgeries, it is not ideal for retrosternal goiter because it does not provide direct access to the thyroid gland in the cervical region, where the main vascular supply originates.

questions.text: Which of the following steps was done incorrectly by the intern when placing an intercostal drainage tube in the patient?

choices.text: Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube
Inserted above the upper border of the rib
Insertion of the needle, which will be between your ribs on your back

questions.solution:
Option C: Insertion of the needle, which will be between your ribs on your back

  • This step is incorrect. When placing an intercostal drainage tube, the needle should be inserted between the ribs on the patient's side, not on the back. This ensures access to the pleural space for proper drainage.
  • This method is not correct as it may affect drainage.

Other options

Option A: Identified 5th intercostal space anterior to mid axillary line to place the tube

  • This step is generally correct. The 5th intercostal space, anterior to the mid-axillary line, is a common location for placing an intercostal drainage tube.

Option B: Inserted above the upper border of the rib

  • This step is correct. When inserting an intercostal drainage tube, it should be inserted below the upper border of the rib. Placing it above the upper border could lead to improper positioning or potential injury.

Option D: Incised and digitally explored

  • This step is not typically part of the procedure for placing an intercostal drainage tube. The primary goal is to insert the tube into the appropriate intercostal space and position it correctly for drainage, without the need for extensive incisions or digital exploration.

questions.text: What is the size of the given blade used for incision and drainage of a superficial abscess?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B 11:

The size of the blade commonly used for incision and drainage of a superficial abscess is 11.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A 10:

This blade size is larger and may be used for larger incisions or other surgical procedures, but it is not commonly used for superficial abscess drainage.

Option C. 22:

This blade size is typically used for ophthalmic procedures and is not commonly used for superficial abscess incision and drainage.

Option D. 15:

This blade size is often used for making small surgical incisions or for procedures requiring precision, but it is not commonly used for superficial abscess drainage.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. The radiograph of his pelvis is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Posterior dislocation of the hip:

  • In posterior hip dislocation, the femoral head is displaced posteriorly from the acetabulum.
  • It is the most common type of hip dislocation resulting from high-energy trauma, such as a road traffic accident.
  • Mode of injury: Axial force applied to a flexed, adducted,and internally rotated hip.
  • Example: Dashboard injury.
  • 50% of PDH are associated with posterior chip fracture of acetabulum.
    • Plain x-ray won't give any results.
    • A CT scan is the investigation of choice in dislocationwith fractures.
  • Differentiation of PDH and ADH on x-ray
    • In ADH - Head is larger
    • In PDH - Smaller head

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Central dislocation of the hip:

  • This term is not commonly used to describe hip dislocations. Central dislocation usually refers to a type of hip joint dislocation where the femoral head is displaced centrally within the acetabulum. It is a rare condition and not typically seen in traumatic injuries.

Option B - Fracture shaft of femur:

  • This refers to a fracture along the shaft (middle portion) of the femur bone. It does not directly involve the hip joint.

Option D - Anterior dislocation of the hip:

  • This is a type of hip joint dislocation where the femoral head is displaced anteriorly (towards the front) from the acetabulum. It is less common than posterior dislocation but can occur in certain traumatic situations.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a gradually progressing swelling and dull aching pain since 6 months in his lower leg .He is otherwise healthy. The  radiographic image of his leg is shown below. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Brodie's Abscess:

Brodie's abscess is a subacute or chronic bone abscess typically caused by Staphylococcus aureus infection. It often presents with localized pain and swelling. Radiographic findings may reveal a well-defined lytic lesion with a sclerotic border.

  • In children Brodie's abscess is most common in the metaphyseal area.
    • Occurs before epiphyseal closure in a child.
  • In adults - more common in epiphysio-metaphyseal junction
    • Occurs after epiphyseal closure in adults.
  • Most common sites - upper tibia, lower femur.
  • Most common organism - Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Most common age - 2nd decade.
  • Pathophysiology - Low virulence of the organism and good host resistance leads to confirming the infection.
    • Cavity is formed.
    • On aspiration sterile pus is seen - due to good host resistance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Osteosarcoma:

  • Osteosarcoma is a type of malignant bone tumor that commonly affects children and adolescents. It typically presents with pain and swelling, often in the long bones, such as the tibia. Radiographic features may include bone destruction, irregular bone formation, and sunburst appearance.

Option B - Osteoblastoma:

  • Osteoblastoma is a rare benign bone tumor that can cause pain and swelling. It commonly affects the spine and long bones. Radiographic features may show a well-defined, eccentric lytic lesion with variable calcification.

Option D - Ewing's sarcoma:

  • Ewing's sarcoma is a highly malignant bone tumor that primarily affects children and adolescents. It commonly presents with pain, swelling, and a palpable mass. Radiographic features may show a permeative bone destruction, onion skin appearance, and soft tissue involvement.

questions.text: Which organ is the least susceptible to the blast wave in a blast injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A. Gastrointestinal (GI) tract:

The GI tract, including the stomach and intestines, is relatively vulnerable to blast waves. The rapid changes in pressure caused by the blast wave can lead to injury and perforation of the GI tract.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Lungs:

The lungs are highly vulnerable to blast waves. The rapid changes in pressure can cause lung injuries, including pneumothorax, pulmonary contusion, and blast lung injury.

Option C. Liver:

The liver is the least vulnerable organ in this context. While it can be affected by the blast wave, it is relatively more resistant compared to other organs The shock wave generated by the blast can result in liver injury, including contusions, lacerations, and hemorrhage.

Option D. Ear drum:

The ear drum, also known as the tympanic membrane. The ear drum can experience rupture or damage due to the sudden changes in air pressure caused by the blast wave.

questions.text: Which of the following fractures is most prone to non-union?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  A - Proximal Scaphoid:

  • The scaphoid bone is located in the wrist, and fractures in the proximal portion (near the base) of the scaphoid are notorious for their high risk of non-union. Non-union refers to the failure of a fracture to heal properly, resulting in persistent pain, limited function, and potential complications. The blood supply to the proximal scaphoid is relatively poor, making it susceptible to delayed or inadequate healing.

Incorrect Options:

Option  B - Inter-Trochanteric:

  • Inter-trochanteric fractures refer to fractures of the femur in the region between the greater and lesser trochanters. These fractures generally have a better healing potential compared to proximal scaphoid fractures.

Option  C - Distal Radius:

  • Distal radius fractures are common fractures of the forearm near the wrist. While they can be challenging, with appropriate treatment, they usually have a good prognosis and a lower risk of non-union compared to proximal scaphoid fractures.

Option  D - Talar Neck:

  • Talar neck fractures involve the neck of the talus bone in the foot. These fractures can be complex and have various degrees of blood supply compromise. While they carry a risk of complications, including non-union, the proximal scaphoid fracture is generally considered to be at a higher risk of non-union.

questions.text: A male patient comes with a gradually increasing enlargement for the past one and a half years. Upon examination, the swelling demonstrates inconsistency in texture and matches the appearance depicted in the provided image. What is the likely underlying reason for this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C

Pleomorphic adenoma:

Pleomorphic adenoma is a common benign tumor that can occur in the salivary glands, including the parotid gland. It often presents as a slowly growing, painless swelling. The consistency of the tumor can vary depending on its composition.

 

Option B

Dermoid cyst:

Dermoid cysts are benign cystic masses that can occur in various parts of the body. They are typically present since birth and can cause a slowly enlarging swelling. Dermoid cysts can have variable consistency and contain a mixture of different types of tissue.

 

Option D

Sebaceous cyst:

Sebaceous cysts are benign cystic lesions that arise from the sebaceous glands in the skin. They can present as slowly growing swellings with a variable consistency. The cysts contain a thick material called sebum.

 

Option A

Jaw Tumor:

Jaw tumors can present as slowly progressive swellings in the jaw area. There are various types of tumors that can occur in the jaw, including both benign (non-cancerous) and malignant (cancerous) tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the condition known as "painful arc syndrome"?

choices.text: A condition in which joint stiffness lasts for more than 30 minutes in the morning, affecting multiple joints.
A condition characterized by localized, sharp pain at the site of an injury or inflammation.
A condition where pain is experienced during a specific range of motion, typically between 60 and 120 degrees of shoulder abduction.
A condition marked by generalized musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and tender points in various areas of the body.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - A condition where pain is experienced during a specific range of motion, typically between 60 and 120 degrees of shoulder abduction:

  •  Painful arc syndrome, also known as "subacromial impingement," is characterized by pain during a specific range of motion, usually between 60 and 120 degrees of shoulder abduction. This condition often occurs due to compression or impingement of structures in the subacromial space, such as the rotator cuff tendons, as the arm is raised.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - A condition in which joint stiffness lasts for more than 30 minutes in the morning, affecting multiple joints:
