  • This option does not accurately describe "painful arc syndrome." Joint stiffness in the morning for more than 30 minutes is typically associated with conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, not painful arc syndrome.

Option B - A condition characterized by localized, sharp pain at the site of an injury or inflammation:

  • This option describes localized pain at the site of an injury or inflammation, which can be associated with various musculoskeletal or traumatic conditions but is not specific to painful arc syndrome.

Option D - A condition marked by generalized musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and tender points in various areas of the body:

  • This option describes fibromyalgia, a condition characterized by generalized musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and tender points in various areas of the body. It is a different condition unrelated to painful arc syndrome.

questions.text: What is shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B- Sebaceous cyst.

Sebaceous cysts are common benign cystic lesions that arise from the sebaceous glands in the skin. They often appear as slow-growing, painless swellings beneath the skin. Sebaceous cysts contain a thick, cheesy material called sebum and can occur in various areas of the body, including the face, neck, scalp, or trunk. Black-colored punctum is seen in cysts except cysts present in the scalp and scrotum, as shown in the image in the question.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A-Dermoid cyst:

  • A dermoid cyst is a type of benign cystic lesion that typically contains a variety of different types of tissues, such as hair, skin, and sometimes even teeth.
  • These cysts are usually present since birth and can occur in various parts of the body.

Option C- Meningioma:

  • Meningiomas are typically slow-growing tumors that arise from the meninges, the protective layers surrounding the brain and spinal cord. They are usually found within the cranial cavity and are less commonly located near the postauricular area. Meningiomas are not typically associated with the specific appearance of the image provided.

Option D- Post auricular fistula:

  • A postauricular fistula is a small abnormal tract or passage that connects the skin behind the ear to the underlying structures. It can present as a small opening with drainage or discharge. The image provided does not depict a postauricular fistula, as it shows a cystic lesion rather than a fistulous opening.

questions.text: De-gloving injury refers to_____?

choices.text: Skin and subcutaneous fat are stripped from the underlying fascia
Skin, subcutaneous fat and fascia are stripped from tendons
Skin, subcutaneous fat, fascia and tendons are stripped from bone

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Skin and subcutaneous fat are stripped from the underlying fascia:

  •  Injuries where the skin and subcutaneous fat are stripped from the underlying fascia are called degloving injuries.
  • In a de-gloving injury, the trauma or force applied to an area causes the skin and the layer of fat beneath it to separate from the underlying tissues, similar to removing a glove from a hand.
  • This type of injury can result in extensive damage to the blood vessels, nerves, and other structures beneath the skin.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Skin, subcutaneous fat and fascia are stripped from tendons:

  • States that the skin, subcutaneous fat, and fascia are stripped from tendons. While tendon injuries can occur in conjunction with de-gloving injuries, the primary definition of a de-gloving injury does not include the stripping of tendons specifically.

Option C - Skin, subcutaneous fat, fascia and tendons are stripped from bone:

  • Suggests that skin, subcutaneous fat, fascia, and tendons are stripped from bone. This description extends beyond the typical definition of a de-gloving injury, as it involves stripping tissues all the way down to the bone. Although bone can be exposed in severe de-gloving injuries, it is not a necessary component for the injury to be classified as a de-gloving.

Option D - Only skin is stripped off:

  • Implies that only the skin is stripped off. This does not encompass the full extent of a de-gloving injury, as it involves the separation of skin and subcutaneous fat from deeper layers.

questions.text: How to manage a patient of Rheumatoid arthritis with deformity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Methotrexate with anti-TNF:

The addition of anti-TNF drugs like Etanercept/ Infliximab helps stop further structural deformity.

The treatment of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) involves both acute management of active disease and long-term management to control symptoms and prevent joint damage.

Treatment of RA:

  1. Acute Stage Treatment:

    • Corticosteroids: In the acute stage of RA with positive classical signs, corticosteroids may be prescribed temporarily for 1 to 2 weeks to reduce inflammation and pain.

  2. Lab Investigations:

    • Anti-CCP (Anti-Cyclic Citrullinated Peptide): This test is considered the best investigation for RA, as it can be positive in the early stages and has prognostic importance.
    • Rheumatoid Factor (RF): RF is positive in about 60% of RA cases but may also be positive in other conditions such as cryoglobulinemia, Parvo 19 infection, and hepatitis C.

  3. Disease-Modifying Antirheumatic Drugs (DMARDs):

    • Hydroxychloroquine (HCQ): Used to treat mild RA, but may cause ocular side effects such as bull's eye-like maculopathy or hemeralopia.
    • Sulfasalazine: Another DMARD option for RA treatment.
    • Methotrexate: Considered the best DMARD for RA, typically administered at a dose of 7.5mg once a week. Regular monitoring of white blood cell (WBC) count is necessary to check for bone marrow suppression.
    • Leflunomide: An alternative DMARD option for RA treatment, although less commonly used.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Steroids:

  • Steroids may be used as part of the treatment plan in RA to provide short-term relief of symptoms and manage acute flares. However, long-term use of steroids is generally not recommended due to their side effects, and they are not the primary treatment option for managing deformities in RA.

Option B - Methotrexate with steroids:

  • Using MTX with steroids, which can be a combination used in certain cases, especially for short-term symptom control or during a disease flare. However, the long-term management of deformities in RA usually involves the use of DMARDs rather than relying solely on steroids.

Option D - Steroids only after NSAlDs fail:

  • Using steroids only after NSAIDs (nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) fail. While NSAIDs can help manage pain and inflammation in RA, they are not sufficient for controlling the disease or managing deformities. DMARDs, including MTX and biologic agents, are the mainstay of treatment for RA and are typically initiated early in the disease course.

questions.text: A female patient presents with a breast abscess. Under antibiotic cover, an aspiration was attempted which failed to reveal any aspirate. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Incision and drainage + Antibiotics :

  • In some cases, the first attempt at aspiration may not successfully collect any fluid due to various factors such as the location or depth of the abscess, the presence of loculations, or the consistency of the fluid. A second attempt should be made with an incision and drainage + antibiotics.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Incision and Drainage:

  • If the second attempt at aspiration is also unsuccessful in obtaining any aspirate, alternative management options such as incision and drainage or other interventions may be considered.

Option B - Continuing antibiotics only:

  • Continuing antibiotics alone may not be sufficient to treat the abscess and achieve resolution adequately.

Option D - Stop antibiotics as no aspirate was collected:

  • Stopping antibiotics without draining the abscess can lead to persistent infection and potential complications.

questions.text: A 60 year old woman presents with low backache and on a lumbar CT the following is seen. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Osteoporosis:

  • Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by the loss of bone density, leading to weakened and brittle bones. The CT image showing biconcave vertebrae is consistent with the compression fractures commonly seen in osteoporosis. The cod fish appearance refers to the vertebral bodies appearing like the skeletal structure of a fish due to the compression fractures. Osteoporosis is more prevalent in postmenopausal women, making it a likely diagnosis in a 60-year-old woman.

Incorrect Options:

Options A - Spondylolisthesis:

  • Spondylolisthesis is a condition characterized by the forward displacement of one vertebra over the vertebra below it. It typically presents with symptoms such as low back pain, but the CT image described in the question does not show the characteristic findings associated with spondylolisthesis, such as vertebral slippage.

Options B - Discitis:

  • Discitis refers to the inflammation or infection of the intervertebral discs. While discitis can cause low back pain, the CT image showing biconcave vertebrae is not indicative of this condition. Discitis is often associated with other findings on imaging, such as disc space narrowing or endplate erosion, which are not mentioned in the question.

Options D - Pott's spine:

  • Pott's spine, also known as spinal tuberculosis. Additional findings, such as paraspinal abscess or destruction of the vertebral body, are typically seen in Pott's spine, which are not mentioned in the question.

questions.text: Which specific nerve is affected in Frey's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C

Auriculotemporal nerve

  • Frey's syndrome is caused by damage or injury to the auriculotemporal nerve, which is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V). This nerve is responsible for providing sensory innervation to the skin of the temple, external ear, and the parotid gland. When there is damage to this nerve, it can lead to aberrant reinnervation of sweat glands in the affected area, resulting in gustatory sweating during eating or other gustatory stimuli.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B

Oculomotor nerve:

  • The oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) is responsible for the motor control of several eye muscles, including those that control eye movements, pupil constriction, and eyelid elevation. It is not involved in Frey's syndrome.

Option D

Glossopharyngeal nerve:

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is responsible for various functions related to the throat, including the sensation and taste from the posterior third of the tongue, the motor control of some throat muscles, and the regulation of blood pressure. While it does play a role in taste sensation, it is not directly involved in Frey's syndrome.

Option A

Facial Nerve:

  • The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is a mixed nerve responsible for controlling the muscles of facial expression, transmitting taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and providing parasympathetic innervation to the lacrimal and salivary glands.
  • In the case of Frey's syndrome, the facial nerve is not directly involved in the syndrome itself. However, it is associated with the condition due to the proximity and interconnections between the facial nerve and the auriculotemporal nerve.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents to the orthopedician with complaints of painful swelling below the knee joint. An X-Ray was obtained which is given below. Which of the following is the preferred treatment modality for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A - Extended curettage and bone grafting:

  • Given the X-ray image showing a soap bubble appearance indicative of a giant cell tumor (GCT). Extended curettage involves the thorough removal of the tumor along with the surrounding affected tissue, followed by filling the resultant cavity with a bone graft. In the case of giant cell tumors (GCTs), extended curettage is the preferred treatment approach to achieve local control and decrease the risk of recurrence.

Treatment Options:

  • Extended curettage and bone grafting: This is the primary treatment for most GCTs.
  • Denosumab: Denosumab, a monoclonal antibody, is used as a treatment option for unresectable or recurrent GCTs. It helps reduce tumor size and control symptoms.
  • Radiation therapy: Radiation therapy may be used as an adjuvant treatment after surgery or as a palliative option for unresectable or recurrent cases.
  • Surgical stabilization: In cases of significant structural compromise or fractures, surgical stabilization techniques like internal fixation with plates and screws or intramedullary nailing may be employed.
  • Salvage procedures: Extensive or recurrent GCTs may require salvage procedures such as en bloc resection (removal of the tumor and surrounding tissues in one piece) or joint replacement.
  • Adjuvant chemotherapy: Adjuvant chemotherapy is rarely used for GCTs, typically in cases of metastatic disease or extensive unresectable tumors.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Simple Curettage and Bone Grafting: Simple curettage, which involves the removal of the tumor without extensive removal of surrounding tissue, is generally not sufficient for giant cell tumors (GCTs).

Option C - Radiofrequency Ablation: Radiofrequency ablation (RFA) is not typically considered the primary treatment modality for giant cell tumors (GCTs). While it may be used in certain cases as a minimally invasive treatment option, extended curettage is generally preferred to achieve complete tumor removal.

Option D - Radical Excision: Radical excision involves the complete removal of the tumor along with a wide margin of healthy tissue. While radical excision may be necessary for certain aggressive or malignant tumors, it is not the preferred treatment for most giant cell tumors (GCTs)

questions.text: The following images A and B show?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Jersey finger & baseball finger:

  • Jersey finger & baseball finger: Jersey finger is a condition where the flexor tendon is torn or avulsed from its insertion at the DIP joint, usually resulting from forcefully extending the finger while it is flexed.
  • Baseball finger, also known as a mallet fracture, involves a fracture at the DIP joint caused by a sudden forceful impact to the tip of an extended finger.
  • Image A represents jersey finger, and image B represents baseball finger.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mallet finger & Jersey finger:

  • Mallet finger refers to a condition where the extensor tendon is torn at the DIP joint, leading to the inability to extend the finger fully.

Option B - Boxer fracture & march fracture:

  • Boxer fracture typically refers to a fracture of the metacarpal bone in the hand, specifically the neck of the metacarpal, usually resulting from a punch or direct trauma. March fracture refers to a stress fracture of the metatarsal bones in the foot.

Option C - Mallet finger & boxer fracture:

  • Mallet finger involves a tear or avulsion of the extensor tendon at the DIP joint, causing the inability to extend the finger fully. Boxer fracture refers to a fracture of the metacarpal bone in the hand.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding deep vein thrombosis (DVT)?

choices.text: Most common clinical presentation is pain and tenderness in calf
Some cases may directly present as pulmonary thromboembolism

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B

Mostly bilateral

Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) refers to the formation of blood clots in the deep veins, usually in the legs. While DVT can occur bilaterally (affecting both legs), it is not mostly bilateral. In fact, unilateral DVT (affecting only one leg) is more common than bilateral DVT.

 

Option A

Clinical assessment is unreliable:

This statement is true. Clinical assessment alone is not sufficient to definitively diagnose or rule out DVT. While clinical assessment, including symptoms and physical examination findings, can raise suspicion for DVT, imaging tests such as ultrasound or venography are needed for a confirmed diagnosis.

 

Option C

Most common clinical presentation is pain and tenderness in calf:

This statement is true. Pain and tenderness in the calf muscle is a common clinical presentation of DVT. Other common symptoms include swelling, redness, warmth, and dilated superficial veins in the affected leg.

 

Option D

Some cases may directly present as pulmonary thromboembolism:

This statement is true. In some cases, a deep vein thrombus can break loose from its original location and travel through the bloodstream to the lungs, causing a blockage known as pulmonary thromboembolism (PTE). PTE can be a life-threatening condition and is considered a complication of DVT.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the dose-response curve shown in the image below?

choices.text: C is more potent than A
B is more potent than A

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - B is competitive antagonist:

  • In competitive antagonism, as also seen above in the graph that the DRC is shifted to the right whereas in non-competitive antagonism the DRC is flattened.
  • Thus in the above image Drug B is the Competitive antagonist while drug C is the non-competitive antagonist.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - C is competitive antagonist: As explained above C is a non competitive antagonist and not competitive antagonist

Option B - C is more potent than A: A is more potent than C which can be seen the DRC given above as A is more towards left in the DRC making it more potent.

Option C - B is more potent than A: A and B are both equally potent as the maximum effect produced by them is the same.

questions.text: What is the CEAP stage of clinical classification for chronic venous disorders in a truck driver who has dilated, tortuous veins measuring 4 mm in the foot?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

 

Option C C2:

The CEAP classification system consists of various categories to describe the clinical presentation and severity of chronic venous disorders. In this case, the presence of dilated, tortuous veins in the foot with a diameter of 4 mm indicates the presence of varicose veins, which falls under the clinical classification of C2.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A C0:

C0: No visible or palpable signs of venous disease.

 

Option C C2:

C2: Varicose veins are present.

 

Option D C3:

C3: Edema or swelling of the lower extremities is present.

questions.text: Which of the following antiglaucoma medications is unsafe in infants?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Brimonidine:

  • Brimonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used in the treatment of glaucoma. However, it has been associated with serious adverse effects, such as central nervous system depression, hypotension , and apnea in infants. Due to these risks, brimonidine is generally considered unsafe in infants.

Incorrect Options:

Option  A - Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker commonly used in the treatment of glaucoma. While it is generally considered safe and effective for adults and older children, it can be used with caution in infants.

Option  C - Latanoprost: Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog commonly used in the treatment of glaucoma. While it is generally safe and well-tolerated, it is important to use caution and follow appropriate dosage adjustments in infants. However, compared to brimonidine, latanoprost is considered safer in infants.

Option  D - Dorzolamide: Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used in the treatment of glaucoma. It is generally well-tolerated and safe for use in infants.

questions.text: Apparent volume of distribution of a drug is very high (6L/kg). Which of the following is true regarding the distribution of that drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  C - Sequestered in body tissues:

  • A high apparent volume of distribution suggests that the drug is extensively distributed beyond the vascular compartment and is sequestered in body tissues.

  • It indicates that the drug has a tendency to distribute widely throughout the body, beyond the plasma and blood vessels.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option  A - Highly bound to plasma proteins: If a drug is highly bound to plasma proteins, it tends to remain in the bloodstream and has a low apparent volume of distribution. This means that the drug is confined to the vascular compartment and has limited distribution to body tissues.

Option  B - Confined to vascular compartment: If a drug is confined to the vascular compartment, it has limited distribution to body tissues. This implies a low apparent volume of distribution rather than a high one.

Option  D - Both A and B: As explained above, neither option A nor option B is correct.

questions.text: Which phase of a clinical trial is primarily focused on assessing the preliminary efficacy and determining the optimal dose of a drug?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Phase 2

Explanation:

Phases of Clinical Trials:

  • Phase 1: Safety and dosage (Option A)
    • Evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics
    • Typically a small group (20-100) of healthy volunteers or patients
    • Outcome: Data on safe dosage ranges and initial information on how the drug is metabolized and excreted.
  • Phase 2: Efficacy and side effects (Option B)
    • Assess the preliminary efficacy of the drug and further evaluate its safety
    • A larger group (100-300) of patients who have the condition the drug is intended to treat
    • Outcome: Information on the drug’s efficacy, optimal dosing, and short-term side effects
  • Phase 3: Confirmatory efficacy and monitoring of adverse reactions (Option C)
    • Confirm the drug’s efficacy and monitor adverse reactions in a larger and more diverse patient population
    • A large group (several hundred to several thousand) of patients
    • Outcome:
      • Definitive evidence of the drug’s efficacy and safety, which is critical for regulatory approval
      • Data from phase 3 trials are submitted to regulatory agencies like the FDA for drug approval
  • Phase 4: Post market surveillance (Option D)
    • Monitor the long-term effectiveness and safety of the drug after it has been approved for use
    • The general population (anyone using the drug as prescribed)
    • Outcome: Ongoing data collection to ensure the drug’s continued safety and efficacy

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient suffering from alcoholic cirrhosis receives a healthy liver from his biological son. What is this type of transplant known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B

Allograft

In the given scenario, the patient with alcoholic cirrhosis receives a liver transplant from his biological son. This type of transplant is known as an allograft.

An allograft refers to the transplantation of an organ or tissue from one individual (the donor) to another individual (the recipient) who is not genetically identical to the donor. In this case, the recipient received a liver from his biological son, who is not an identical twin. Allografts are the most common type of transplant performed.

 

Incorrect Option

Option A.

Autograft:

An autograft involves the transplantation of tissue from one site to another within the same individual. It refers to a situation where the recipient is also the donor. This is not the case in the given scenario, as the liver is being transplanted from the biological son.

Option C.

Xenograft:

A xenograft involves the transplantation of tissue or organs between different species. For example, transplantation of pig organs into humans. This is not the case in the given scenario, as the liver transplant is occurring between two humans.

Option D.

Isograft:

An isograft refers to the transplantation of organs or tissues between genetically identical individuals. This can occur in the case of identical twins. However, in the given scenario, the recipient and donor are not genetically identical.

questions.text: Which one of the options below is not included in the revised trauma score (RTS)?
questions.solution:
correct Option:

Option C.

Pulse rate

The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a scoring system used to assess the severity of trauma in patients. It consists of three components: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), Systolic Blood Pressure (SBP), and Respiratory Rate (RR). However, Pulse Rate is not a part of the RTS.

 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A.

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS):

The GCS assesses the patient's level of consciousness based on eye-opening, verbal response, and motor response. It is an essential component of the RTS.

Option B.

Systolic Blood Pressure (SBP):

SBP, which measures the pressure exerted on the arterial walls during the contraction phase of the heart, is another component of the RTS. It helps evaluate the patient's circulatory status.

Option D.

Respiratory rate

Respiratory rate, which refers to the number of breaths a person takes per minute, is indeed a part of the Revised Trauma Score (RTS). It is one of the vital signs used to assess the severity of trauma in patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is an oral factor Xa inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Rivaroxaban:

  • Rivaroxaban is an oral factor Xa inhibitor. It works by inhibiting factor Xa, which is an important component in the coagulation cascade. Rivaroxaban is used for various indications, including prevention and treatment of deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and prevention of stroke and systemic embolism in patients with atrial fibrillation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bivalirudin: It is a direct thrombin inhibitor and is administered intravenously. Bivalirudin is primarily used as an anticoagulant during certain cardiac procedures.

Option B - Dabigatran: It is a direct thrombin inhibitor like bivalirudin, but it is available in an oral formulation. Dabigatran is commonly used for stroke prevention in atrial fibrillation and the treatment of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

Option D - Enoxaparin: It is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) that is administered subcutaneously. Enoxaparin acts by enhancing the activity of antithrombin III, thereby inhibiting multiple clotting factors and preventing blood clots.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for diphtheria carrier state?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Erythromycin:

  • Erythromycin is the drug of choice for the diphtheria carrier state. It is effective against the Corynebacterium diphtheriae bacterium responsible for diphtheria. Erythromycin is typically used to treat carriers to prevent the spread of the disease to others, as carriers can still transmit the bacteria even if they do not exhibit symptoms of the disease.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Amoxicillin: Amoxicillin is not the drug of choice for the diphtheria carrier state. While amoxicillin is an antibiotic commonly used to treat bacterial infections, it is not the preferred treatment for diphtheria carriers.

Option C - Rifampicin: Rifampicin is not the drug of choice for the diphtheria carrier state. rifampicin is a broad-spectrum antibiotic used to treat various bacterial infections.

Option D - Tetracycline: Tetracycline is not the drug of choice for the diphtheria carrier state. Although tetracycline is an antibiotic with a broad spectrum of activity against various bacteria, including some Corynebacterium species, it is not the recommended treatment for diphtheria carriers.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of oseltamivir and zanamivir?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Neuraminidase inhibition.:

  • Both oseltamivir and zanamivir are neuraminidase inhibitors. Neuraminidase is an enzyme found on the surface of influenza viruses. By inhibiting neuraminidase, these drugs prevent the release of newly formed viral particles from infected cells, reducing the spread of the virus within the body. This mechanism of action helps to decrease the severity and duration of influenza symptoms and can be effective in treating and preventing influenza infections.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - DNA polymerase inhibition: Oseltamivir and zanamivir do not inhibit DNA polymerase. DNA polymerase is an enzyme involved in DNA replication and is targeted by antiviral drugs used to treat viral infections such as herpes or hepatitis B.

Option  B - Protein synthesis inhibition: Oseltamivir and zanamivir do not inhibit protein synthesis. Protein synthesis inhibitors are antibiotics that target bacterial ribosomes and interfere with the process of protein production.

Option  C - Nucleotide analogue: Oseltamivir and zanamivir are not nucleotide analogues. Nucleotide analogues are compounds that mimic the structure of nucleotides and can be incorporated into viral DNA or RNA during replication, leading to chain termination and inhibition of viral replication.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options is an abortifacient, derived from synthetic PFG2 alpha?
questions.solution:
Correct Option d. Carboprost.

Option D. Carboprost: Carboprost is a synthetic prostaglandin F2 alpha analogue used as an abortifacient. It is primarily used for the termination of pregnancy in cases where other methods have failed or are contraindicated. It is administered intramuscularly and is particularly effective in the second trimester of pregnancy

Incorrect options

Option A. Dinoprost: Dinoprost, also known as prostaglandin F2 alpha, is a naturally occurring prostaglandin used for various medical purposes, including the induction of labor, treatment of postpartum hemorrhage, and control of uterine bleeding. While it is not commonly used as an abortifacient, it can have abortifacient effects in certain circumstances.

Option B. Dinoprostone: Dinoprostone is a synthetic prostaglandin E2 analogue used for cervical ripening, induction of labor, and the termination of pregnancy. It is not specifically used as an abortifacient but can be used for inducing labor or as part of the process for medical abortion.

Option C. Misoprostol: Misoprostol is a synthetic prostaglandin E1 analogue that is commonly used as an abortifacient. It is effective for medical abortion when used alone or in combination with other medications.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes activation of K+-ATP channels?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Nicorandil:

  • Nicorandil is a medication that causes the activation of ATP-sensitive potassium (K+-ATP) channels. It is a hybrid compound that combines nitrate-like properties with potassium channel activation effects. By activating K+-ATP channels, Nicorandil promotes arterial and venous dilation, leading to decreased vascular resistance and increased blood flow. It is primarily used in the treatment of angina pectoris.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Molsidomine: Molsidomine is a nitric oxide donor that primarily works by releasing nitric oxide, leading to vasodilation. However, it does not directly activate K+-ATP channels.

Option C - Isosorbide dinitrate: Isosorbide dinitrate is a nitrate medication that acts as a vasodilator. It primarily works by releasing nitric oxide, which relaxes smooth muscles and dilates blood vessels.

Option D - Nitroglycerin: Nitroglycerin is also a nitrate medication that acts as a vasodilator by releasing nitric oxide.

questions.text: Most effective antiemetic for chemotherapy–induced vomiting is _____________.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Granisetron:

  • Granisetron, along with ondansetron, belongs to a class of medications called 5-HT3 receptor antagonists. These medications are highly effective in preventing and treating chemotherapy-induced vomiting. Granisetron works by blocking serotonin (5-HT3) receptors in the brain and gut, thereby reducing nausea and vomiting. It is frequently used in combination with other antiemetic drugs in chemotherapy regimens.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Domperidone: Domperidone is an antiemetic medication primarily used to treat nausea and vomiting associated with gastrointestinal disorders. It is not considered a first-line treatment for chemotherapy-induced vomiting.

Option B - Tegaserod: Tegaserod is a medication used to treat irritable bowel syndrome with constipation but is not commonly used as an antiemetic for chemotherapy-induced vomiting.

Option D - Doxylamine: Doxylamine is an antihistamine that can be used for the management of morning sickness.

questions.text: Nasal polyps are commonly associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Intrinsic asthma: 

  • Nasal polyps are commonly associated with intrinsic asthma. Intrinsic asthma, also known as non-allergic or non-atopic asthma, is characterized by asthma symptoms that are not triggered by specific allergens. It can be caused by factors such as respiratory infections, irritants, exercise, cold air, stress, or certain medications. Nasal polyps are frequently seen in individuals with intrinsic asthma, suggesting a connection between these two conditions.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are incorrect and are not characteristically associated with nasal polyps.

questions.text: True statement about teduglutide is:

choices.text: It is recommended for patients with colorectal cancer

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - It is a GLP-2 analogue:

  • Teduglutide is a synthetic analogue of glucagon-like peptide-2 (GLP-2). GLP-2 is a naturally occurring hormone that stimulates intestinal growth and enhances nutrient absorption. Teduglutide acts similarly to GLP-2 and is used for the treatment of short bowel syndrome.

Incorrect Option:

Option B - Its half-life is 6-8 hours: The half-life of teduglutide is approximately 3-5 hours, not 6-8 hours.

Option C - It is administered orally: Teduglutide is not administered orally. It is given as a subcutaneous injection.

Option D - It is recommended for patients with colorectal cancer: Teduglutide is not indicated or recommended for the treatment of colorectal cancer. It is specifically used for the treatment of short bowel syndrome, a condition characterized by a significant reduction in functional small intestine length.

questions.text: Why is cisatracurium preferred over atracurium?

choices.text: It has rapid onset of action
It has less depressant action on heart
It has short duration of action
It causes less release of histamine

questions.solution:
Correct Option is d. It causes less release of histamine.

Option D. It causes less release of histamine: Cisatracurium is preferred over atracurium because it causes less release of histamine. Histamine release can lead to adverse effects such as bronchoconstriction, hypotension, and flushing. Cisatracurium is considered a non-histamine-releasing neuromuscular blocking agent, making it a favorable choice in patients who are susceptible to histamine-related reactions.

Incorrect Options

Option A. It has rapid onset of action: Cisatracurium and atracurium have similar onset of action. Both drugs are classified as intermediate-acting neuromuscular blocking agents and have comparable time to onset.

Option B. It has less depressant action on the heart: Cisatracurium and atracurium have similar cardiovascular effects. They do not have significant direct effects on the heart and do not cause substantial cardiovascular depression.

Option C. It has a short duration of action: Cisatracurium and atracurium have similar durations of action. The duration of effect for both drugs is moderate, allowing for adequate muscle relaxation during surgical procedures.

questions.text: All of the following are AIDS defining illnesses except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Oral candidiasis:

  • Oral candidiasis, also known as thrush, is a fungal infection caused by Candida species. While oral candidiasis is commonly seen in individuals with HIV/AIDS, it is not considered an AIDS-defining illness. It is a relatively common opportunistic infection that can occur in people with weakened immune systems, including those with HIV/AIDS, but its presence does not meet the criteria for defining the diagnosis of AIDS.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and C are considered AIDS defining illnesses.

questions.text: Which one of the following drugs inhibits neutrophil recruitment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Colchicine:

  • It is an anti-inflammatory medication that works by disrupting microtubules in neutrophils, which reduces their ability to migrate to sites of inflammation and thus inhibits neutrophil recruitment. It's commonly used to manage gout and can be helpful in some inflammatory conditions.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Montelukast: Montelukast is a leukotriene receptor antagonist used primarily in the management of asthma and allergic rhinitis. While it has anti-inflammatory properties, it doesn't directly inhibit neutrophil recruitment.

Option B - Sodium cromolyn: Sodium cromolyn is a mast cell stabilizer that is used for the prevention and management of asthma, allergic rhinitis, and other allergic conditions. It helps prevent the release of inflammatory mediators, but it does not specifically inhibit neutrophil recruitment.

Option D - Febuxostat: Febuxostat is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor used to treat hyperuricemia and prevent gout. It doesn't have a direct effect on neutrophil recruitment.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia with a blood type O negative presents to the transplant clinic to discuss proceeding with an allogeneic stem cell transplant. Which of the following would be an optimal donor?

choices.text: His HLA twin identical brother who is otherwise healthy and is blood type O+
An HLA identical matched unrelated donor

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - His HLA twin identical brother who is otherwise healthy and is blood type O+:

  • The correct option would be the patient's HLA identical brother who is otherwise healthy and has blood type O+. HLA matching is a crucial factor in determining the compatibility of the donor for an allogeneic stem cell transplant.
  • As long as the HLA types match, the patient can receive stem cells from a donor with a different blood type without significant adverse effects.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - His brother (Incorrect)- HLA- identical twin brother have the best results with allogenic stem cell transplant While an identical twin brother is a perfect genetic match, an allogeneic stem cell transplant refers to receiving stem cells from a donor who is not an identical twin. Therefore, an identical twin brother would not be considered an optimal donor in this case.

Option B - Umbilical cord transplant (Incorrect) Umbilical cord blood can be a source of stem cells for transplantation, but the patient's blood type O negative may limit the availability of compatible cord blood units.

Option D - An HLA identical matched unrelated donor who(Incorrect) The information regarding the blood type of the unrelated donor is not provided. Without knowing the blood type compatibility, it is difficult to determine the suitability of this option.

questions.text: Which of the following fluoroquinolones has maximum bioavailability?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Levofloxacin.:

  • Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that exhibits high oral bioavailability. It is the L-isomer of ofloxacin and has a longer half-life compared to other fluoroquinolones. Due to its excellent bioavailability, it is widely used for various infections.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ciprofloxacin: Ciprofloxacin is a commonly used fluoroquinolone antibiotic. While it has good bioavailability, it is not the fluoroquinolone with the maximum bioavailability.

Option C - Gatifloxacin: Gatifloxacin is another fluoroquinolone antibiotic. While it has good bioavailability, it is not the fluoroquinolone with the maximum bioavailability.

Option D - Norfloxacin: Norfloxacin is an older fluoroquinolone antibiotic. It has lower bioavailability compared to some of the newer fluoroquinolones and is typically used for urinary tract infections.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of triazoles?

choices.text: Interferes with DNA and RNA synthesis
Inhibits epoxidation of squalene in fungi

questions.solution:
Option B - Inhibition of ergosterol synthesis:

  • Triazoles are a class of antifungal medications that work by inhibiting the synthesis of ergosterol, a vital component of the fungal cell membrane. Ergosterol is the fungal equivalent of cholesterol in human cell membranes. Disruption of ergosterol synthesis impairs the integrity and function of the fungal cell membrane, leading to cell death and inhibition of fungal growth.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Interferes with DNA and RNA synthesis: Some antifungal medications, such as nucleoside analogs, do interfere with DNA and RNA synthesis in fungi, but this is not the mechanism of action of triazoles.

Option C - Forms pores in fungal membranes: This is the mechanism of action of polyenes, not triazoles. Polyenes like amphotericin B create pores in fungal membranes, disrupting their integrity.

Option D - Inhibits epoxidation of squalene in fungi: This describes the mechanism of allylamines, another class of antifungal drugs. Allylamines inhibit the conversion of squalene to ergosterol, but this is different from the mechanism of action of triazoles, which directly inhibit ergosterol synthesis.

questions.text: A dermatologist wants to prescribe acitretin to a patient with psoriasis. Which of the following statements is false regarding the drug?

choices.text: It can cause increased sensitivity to sunlight
Female patients should avoid getting pregnant for 6 months after therapy
Acitretin has a half life of about 50 hours

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Female patients should avoid getting pregnant for 6 months after therapy:

  • Female patients of childbearing potential should avoid pregnancy for at least 3 years after stopping acitretin therapy due to its teratogenic effects.
  • Effective contraception should be used during treatment and for an extended period after discontinuation.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Contraindicated in persons with hyperlipidemia: Acitretin is contraindicated in those with hyperlipidemia due to its potential to exacerbate lipid levels, requiring close lipid monitoring during therapy.

Option B - It can cause increased sensitivity to sunlight: Acitretin increases skin sensitivity to sunlight, necessitating sun protection measures like sunscreen and protective clothing to prevent sunburn.

Option D - Acitretin has a half life of about 50 hours: Acitretin has a long half-life of approximately 50 hours, emphasizing the need for extended contraceptive use and pregnancy avoidance post-therapy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV positive man presents with fever for 3 weeks, dry cough an significant weight loss. His chest x-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP):

  • Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (formerly known as Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia) is a fungal infection that commonly affects individuals with weakened immune systems, such as those with HIV/AIDS. The presentation of fever, dry cough, significant weight loss, and chest X-ray findings of diffuse interstitial infiltrates and symmetrical perihilar involvement are highly suggestive of PJP.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and C are incorrect.

questions.text: Which drug's action is prolonged by the administration of cilastatin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Imipenem:

  • Cilastatin inhibits renal enzyme dehydropeptidase I, preventing breakdown of imipenem in renal tubules.
  • This inhibition increases imipenem's half-life and plasma levels, enhancing its effectiveness.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Meropenem: Meropenem is similar to imipenem but not typically co-administered with cilastatin.

Option C - Cefazolin: Cefazolin is unrelated to imipenem and not affected by cilastatin.

Option D - Piperacillin: Piperacillin's action is not extended by cilastatin administration.

questions.text: What is the drug used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from cholinergic crisis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Edrophonium:

  • Edrophonium is a short-acting reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used in the diagnosis of myasthenia gravis (MG) and to differentiate between MG and cholinergic crisis.

  • In myasthenia gravis, there is a deficiency or dysfunction of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle weakness and fatigue. Edrophonium temporarily increases the concentration of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase, the enzyme responsible for its breakdown. If a patient with myasthenia gravis receives edrophonium and experiences a temporary improvement in muscle strength, it suggests a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.

  • On the other hand, in cholinergic crisis, there is an excess of acetylcholine due to overstimulation of cholinergic receptors. Administering edrophonium in cholinergic crisis can worsen symptoms and lead to further muscle weakness and respiratory compromise.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Obidoxime: Obidoxime is an antidote used for the treatment of organophosphate poisoning, not for differentiating myasthenia gravis from cholinergic crisis.

Option C - Donepezil: Donepezil is a long-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease and is not specifically used to differentiate myasthenia gravis from cholinergic crisis.

Option D - Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic medication that blocks the effects of acetylcholine. It is used for the treatment of cholinergic crisis but does not help differentiate myasthenia gravis from cholinergic crisis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Guillain-Barre syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Descending paralysis is seen:

  • Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) is an autoimmune polyradiculopathy causing patchy segmental demyelination of spinal cord and peripheral nerves.
  • Type of paralysisin GBS- Ascending symmetrical paralysis

 

Incorrect options:

Option A - Ascending paralysis: GBS typically presents as ascending paralysis.

Option C - Plasmapheresis is a treatment method: Plasmapheresis, also known as plasma exchange, is one of the treatment options for GBS.

Option D - Demyelinating disorder: GBS is causes patchy segmental demyelination of spinal cord and peripheral nerves.

questions.text: Which of the statements below correctly describes pegylated filgrastim?

choices.text: Duration of action is shorter than normal filgrastim
Added advantage is that it can be taken orally
It should not be administered in sickle cell patients
It is not effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia

questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Pegylated-filgrastim should not be administered in sickle cell patients.

Option C. It should not be administered in sickle cell patients: Pegylated-filgrastim is contraindicated in sickle cell patients. It can potentially stimulate the production of sickled red blood cells, leading to vaso-occlusive crises and worsening of sickle cell disease symptoms.

Incorrect options:

Option A. Duration of action is shorter than normal filgrastim: Pegylated-filgrastim has a longer duration of action compared to normal filgrastim. The addition of polyethylene glycol (PEG) to filgrastim prolongs its half-life, resulting in sustained release and a longer duration of action.

Option B. Added advantage is that it can be taken orally: Pegylated-filgrastim is not available in an oral form. It is typically administered via subcutaneous injection.

Option D. It is not effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia: Pegylated-filgrastim is effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia. It stimulates the production of neutrophils and helps reduce the duration and severity of neutropenia, which is a condition characterized by a low neutrophil count.

questions.text: What is the most effective treatment for idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Splenectomy:

  • Splenectomy is considered the best treatment option for ITP in patients who do not respond to other treatments or who have chronic or recurrent ITP. The spleen is the primary site of platelet destruction in ITP, and removing it can help increase platelet counts and improve symptoms.

Incorrect options:

Option A - IV immunoglobulins: IV immunoglobulins (IVIG) are commonly used in the treatment of ITP, especially in acute cases or when immediate platelet count elevation is required. IVIG works by increasing the platelet count temporarily.

Option B - Steroids: Steroids, such as prednisone, are often used as an initial treatment for acute ITP.

Option D - Blood transfusion: Blood transfusion is not a primary treatment for ITP. May be used in specific cases.

questions.text: The best approach in the treatment of chronic SIADH is _____________:

choices.text: Reducing fluid intake to <500 ml per day

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tolvaptan:

  • Tolvaptan is a selective vasopressin V2 receptor antagonist that helps to increase free water clearance and reduce the excessive water retention seen in SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion). It promotes water excretion without affecting sodium levels. Tolvaptan has been shown to be effective in treating chronic SIADH.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Reducing fluid intake to <500 ml per day: While reducing fluid intake may help manage symptoms of fluid overload in some cases, it is not considered the primary treatment for chronic SIADH. Limiting fluid intake should be done cautiously and under medical supervision to prevent dehydration and electrolyte imbalances. 

Option C - Demeclocycline: Demeclocycline is an antibiotic that has been used in the past for SIADH due to its ability to inhibit the action of antidiuretic hormone. However, it is no longer considered a first-line treatment due to concerns about its side effects, including nephrotoxicity and hepatotoxicity. Other treatment options, such as tolvaptan, have shown better efficacy and safety profiles.

Option D - Fludrocortisone: Fludrocortisone is a synthetic mineralocorticoid that acts on the kidneys to increase sodium reabsorption and fluid retention. It is not recommended as a first-line treatment for SIADH because it may worsen hyponatremia (low sodium levels) and fluid overload.

questions.text: Which cardiac chamber enlargement is seen in the case of mitral stenosis on chest x-ray initially?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Left atrium:

  • Mitral stenosis leads to increased pressure in the left atrium, causing left atrial enlargement. On a chest x-ray, this can be visualized as a bulge or enlargement of the left heart border.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Intravenous mannitol is used in ____________?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Glaucoma:

  • Intravenous mannitol is commonly used as an osmotic diuretic in the treatment of acute episodes of increased intraocular pressure associated with glaucoma. It works by reducing the intraocular fluid volume and lowering intraocular pressure, providing temporary relief and protecting the optic nerve.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pulmonary edema: While mannitol may be used in the management of certain types of pulmonary edema, such as in cases of increased intracranial pressure or cerebral edema. Other interventions, such as diuretics and vasodilators, are typically used in the management of pulmonary edema.

Option B - Congestive cardiac failure: Mannitol is not a standard treatment for congestive heart failure. The primary treatment for congestive heart failure involves medications that help improve cardiac function, reduce fluid retention, and manage symptoms.

Option C - Acute kidney injury with anuria: Mannitol may be used in some cases of acute kidney injury to promote diuresis and maintain urine flow. However, its use in anuric kidney injury is limited, as there is no urine output to enhance. Other interventions, such as fluid management, hemodialysis, or other renal replacement therapies, are typically employed in the treatment of anuric kidney injury.

questions.text: Which of the following carbapenems has increased risk of causing seizures?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Imipenem:

  • Imipenem is a carbapenem antibiotic that has a higher risk of causing seizures compared to other carbapenems. It can lower the seizure threshold, especially at higher doses or in patients with underlying risk factors for seizures.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Meropenem: Meropenem is a carbapenem antibiotic that is generally associated with a lower risk of causing seizures compared to imipenem.

Option C - Etrapenem: Etrapenem is not a commonly used carbapenem. It has similar properties to other carbapenems but is less frequently prescribed.

Option D - Doripenem: Doripenem is a carbapenem antibiotic that is generally associated with a lower risk of causing seizures compared to imipenem

questions.text: Which among the following is incorrect?

choices.text: Components of MELD (model for end stage liver disease) scoring system are creatinine, bilirubin, international normalized ratio (INR), serum sodium (mEq/L)
Components of CTP (Child Turcotte Pugh) score are albumin, bilirubin, INR, ascites and encephalopathy
Components of CTP (child Turcotte Pugh) are creatinine, bilirubin, international normalized ratio (INR)
MELD score is used to assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Components of CTP (Child-Turcotte-Pugh) are creatinine, bilirubin, international normalized ratio (INR):

  • The components of the CTP score are not creatinine, but rather albumin, bilirubin, INR, ascites, and encephalopathy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Components of MELD (Model for End-Stage Liver Disease) scoring system are creatinine, bilirubin, international normalized ratio (INR), serum sodium (mEq/L): The MELD score is a scoring system used to assess the severity of liver disease and predict prognosis. It includes the components mentioned, which are used to calculate the MELD score.

Option B - Components of CTP (Child-Turcotte-Pugh) score are albumin, bilirubin, INR, ascites, encephalopathy: The CTP score is a scoring system used to assess the severity of liver disease and predict prognosis in patients with cirrhosis. The components mentioned are used to calculate the CTP score.

Option D - MELD score is used to assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation: The MELD score is commonly used to assess the severity of liver disease and prioritize patients on the liver transplant waiting list. It helps determine the urgency of transplantation based on the calculated MELD score.

questions.text: Which of the following helps in maintaining the patency of ductus arteriosus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - PGE1:

  • PGE1 (Prostaglandin E1) helps in maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus. It acts as a vasodilator and keeps the ductus arteriosus open, allowing blood to bypass the lungs in fetal circulation. PGE1 is naturally produced in the body and is commonly used as a medication (e.g., alprostadil) to maintain ductal patency in certain congenital heart defects.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - PGF2α : PGF2α (Prostaglandin F2α) is not involved in maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus. Instead, it plays a role in vasoconstriction and contraction of smooth muscle.

Option C - PGH2: PGH2 (Prostaglandin H2) is an intermediate in the biosynthesis of other prostaglandins and is not directly involved in maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus.

Option D - PGI2: While PGI2 (Prostacyclin) is a potent vasodilator and inhibitor of platelet aggregation, it does not specifically play a role in maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: Please select the incorrect statement regarding the bundle of Kent.

choices.text: It is faster than AV nodal pathway
It is slower than AV nodal pathway

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - It is slower than AV nodal pathway:

  • This statement is incorrect. The bundle of Kent is actually faster than the AV nodal pathway.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It is faster than the AV nodal pathway: This statement is correct. The bundle of Kent, being an accessory pathway, can conduct electrical impulses faster than the normal AV nodal pathway.

Option C - Leads to short PR interval: The presence of an accessory pathway, such as the bundle of Kent, can lead to a short PR interval on an electrocardiogram (ECG).

Option D - Leads to prolonged QRS duration: The bundle of Kent can cause a delta wave on the ECG, which is an early ventricular activation, resulting in a widened or prolonged QRS complex.

questions.text: Osborn waves in ECG are seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hypothermia:

  • Osborn waves, also known as J waves or camel humps, are a characteristic ECG finding seen in hypothermia. They appear as positive deflections at the J point, just following the QRS complex. These waves are most prominent in the precordial leads (V2-V6) and can be seen in other leads as well.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: In obesity, there is an increase in the production of which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Insulin:

  • Insulin: Obesity is associated with insulin resistance, a condition in which the body's cells become less responsive to the effects of insulin. In response to insulin resistance, the pancreas produces and releases more insulin to compensate for the decreased effectiveness. This increased insulin production is a characteristic feature of obesity.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Thyroxine (T4)

  • Thyroid hormones, including thyroxine, are involved in regulating metabolism. While obesity can affect thyroid function, it typically does not cause a direct increase in thyroxine production.

Option C - Growth hormone

  • Growth hormone (GH) levels may be altered in obesity, but the relationship is complex. In some cases, obese individuals may have reduced GH secretion or impaired response to GH. However, it is not a consistent finding that GH production is increased in obesity.

Option D - Adiponectin

  • Adiponectin is an adipokine, a hormone secreted by adipose tissue. Its production is generally decreased in obesity, rather than increased. Lower levels of adiponectin are associated with insulin resistance and other metabolic abnormalities seen in obesity.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of this patient from the ECG shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ventricular tachycardia:

  • Ventricular tachycardia is characterized by a rapid heart rate originating from the ventricles, resulting in a wide QRS complex. The absence of P waves suggests that the ventricles are not being activated through the normal atrioventricular conduction pathway.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Normal ECG: This option is incorrect because the ECG presented does not represent a normal rhythm. It shows a rapid heart rate, wide QRS complex, and absence of P waves, which are indicative of an abnormal cardiac rhythm.

Option B - Ventricular fibrillation: ventricular fibrillation typically appears as a chaotic, irregular rhythm with no discernible QRS complexes or P waves. The ECG shown in the question displays a regular rhythm with wide QRS complexes, which is more consistent with ventricular tachycardia.

Option D - Misplaced leads: This option is incorrect The ECG pattern shown is consistent with ventricular tachycardia rather than an artifact caused by lead misplacement.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria would you utilize to evaluate the effectiveness of the malaria surveillance system implemented by the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B:

  • Annual Blood Examination Rate (ABER): The ABER is the percentage of the population at risk of malaria who have undergone blood examination for malaria parasites. It indicates the coverage of the population undergoing diagnostic testing for malaria and is used to assess the efficiency of the surveillance system.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Annual Parasite Index (API): The API is used to measure the incidence or burden of malaria in a population.

Option C - Slide Positivity Rate (SPR): The SPR provides information about the proportion of individuals tested who have confirmed malaria infection.

Option D - Slide Falciparum Rate (SFR): The SFR specifically focuses on the prevalence of P. falciparum infection among tested individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding patients with trigeminal neuralgia?

choices.text: Pain along V2 and V3 division of trigeminal nerve
No objective signs of sensory loss

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Deep-seated Pain:

  • Trigeminal neuralgia does not present with deep-seated pain.
  • The pain in trigeminal neuralgia is repetitive, severe, and very brief (seconds or less). It may be triggered by touch, a cold wind or eating.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A - More common in females: Trigeminal neuralgia is more commonly seen in females, although it can affect both sexes.

Option B - Pain along V2 and V3 division of trigeminal nerve: The lancinating pain of trigeminal neuralgia most commonly involves the second and/or third division of trigeminal nerve.

Option D - No objective signs of sensory loss: Patients with trigeminal neuralgia do not exhibit objective sensory loss in the affected areas. The pain is usually paroxysmal and does not cause long-term sensory deficits.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect in relation to confounding factors?

choices.text: It can be reduced by matching
It is associated individually with both cause and effect
It is distributed equally in both study and control groups
It is associated with the exposure of the study

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - It is distributed equally in both study and control groups:

  • Confounding factors, associated with both exposure and outcome, often differ between study and control groups, leading to biased results.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It can be reduced by matching:

  • Matching can help mitigate confounding effects, but doesn't eliminate them entirely.

Option B - It is associated individually with both cause and effect:

  • Confounding factors are linked to both exposure and outcome but not necessarily independently.

Option D - It is associated with the exposure of the study:

  • Confounding factors are typically unevenly distributed between groups, impacting study validity.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best level of prevention of breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Early Diagnosis and Treatment:

  • Early diagnosis and treatment are key for breast cancer prevention. Detecting it early through methods like mammography improves outcomes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Specific Protection: Specific protection involves reducing risk factors, not early treatment.

Option C - Disability limitation: Disability limitation minimizes disease impact, not prevention.

Option D - Rehabilitation: Rehabilitation enhances life post-diagnosis, not prevention.

questions.text: What is the dosage of vitamin A given for a 2-year-old baby with keratomalacia?

choices.text: 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by same dose after 24 hours
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 1 week
1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 24 hours and after a week
2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks

questions.solution:
Correct Option: D - 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose 24 hours later and after 2 weeks:

  • This regimen ensures rapid replenishment of vitamin A stores, crucial for treating keratomalacia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 2,00,000 IU immediately, followed by same dose after 24 hours:

  • Immediate dose with no follow-up after 2 weeks.

Option B - 1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 1 week:

  • Lower initial dose and no follow-up within 2 weeks.

Option C - 1,00,000 IU immediately, followed by the same dose after 24 hours and after a week:

  • Immediate and follow-up doses but lacks the critical second dose after 2 weeks.

questions.text: What percentage of distribution is represented by one standard deviation in a normal curve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: 

Option A. Option A (68%): In a normal distribution, approximately 68% of the data falls within one standard deviation of the mean. This means that the majority of the observations cluster around the mean, with a smaller proportion extending beyond one standard deviation in either direction.

Incorrect Options

Option B. Option B (34%): In reality, 34% of the data falls within half of one standard deviation from the mean, not the full one standard deviation.

Option C. Option C (99%):It represents a much larger range, which would be three standard deviations. In a normal distribution, about 99.7% of the data falls within three standard deviations of the mean, not within one standard deviation.

OptionD. Option D (95%): This also represents a larger range, which would be two standard deviations. In reality, about 95% of the data falls within two standard deviations of the mean, not within one standard deviation.

questions.text: As per IMNCI guidelines, a diagnosis of pneumonia is made in a 6-month-old infant when the child exhibits rapid breathing with a respiratory rate exceeding:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 50:

  • Option D. 50 breaths per minute: A 6-month-old child is said to have pneumonia if the child has fast breathing with a respiratory rate more than 50 breaths per minute.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B & C are incorrect

questions.text: Which of the following items is included in the concurrent list of the Indian Constitution?

choices.text: Fishing and fisheries beyond territorial waters

questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Adulteration of food:

The inclusion of adulteration of food in the Concurrent List of the Indian Constitution means that both the central government and state governments have the authority to make laws and regulations to address this issue. It recognizes that ensuring food safety and preventing food adulteration is a shared responsibility between the central and state governments.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Fishing and fisheries beyond territorial waters: This falls under the Union List, as the central government has exclusive jurisdiction over matters related to fishing and fisheries beyond territorial waters.

Option C. Regulating labor in mines: This is also in the Union List, as the central government has the authority to regulate labor in mines.

OptionD. Public health and sanitation: This subject is part of the State List, meaning that the state governments have the power to legislate on matters related to public health and sanitation.

questions.text: Except for which of the following, all the mentioned characteristics are associated with Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lead pipe appearance:

Lead pipe appearance: This feature is not typically associated with Crohn's disease. The term "lead pipe appearance" is used to describe the smooth, uniform narrowing of the colon seen in conditions like ulcerative colitis. In Crohn's disease, the involvement can be patchy and may lead to skip lesions or segmental involvement rather than a continuous, uniform appearance.

 

Incorrect Options

Option A - Transmural involvement: This is a characteristic feature of Crohn's disease. It refers to inflammation that extends through all layers of the intestinal wall, including the mucosa, submucosa, muscularis propria, and serosa.

Option C - Rectal sparing: This is a feature seen in Crohn's disease. It refers to the relative sparing of the rectum from inflammation. Crohn's disease often involves the terminal ileum (the last part of the small intestine) and can extend to other parts of the gastrointestinal tract, but the rectum is commonly spared.

Option D - Perianal fistula: Perianal fistulas are frequently associated with Crohn's disease. These abnormal connections between the intestine and the skin around the anus can cause pain, discharge, and recurrent infections.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed form of Guillain-Barre syndrome among the options provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP):

  • Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP) is the most common subtype of GBS seen mostly in adults.
  • It has motor, sensory, and autonomic involvement.

 

Incorrect options

Option A - Acute motor axonal neuropathy (AMAN): This is a subtype of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) characterized by axonal damage to motor nerves. It is less common than AIDP.

Option C - Acute motor sensory axonal neuropathy (AMSAN): This is another subtype of GBS characterized by axonal damage to both motor and sensory nerves. It is less common than AIDP.

Option D - Miller Fisher syndrome (MFS): This is a variant of GBS characterized by a triad of symptoms: ataxia , ophthalmoplegia , and areflexia . It is less common than AIDP.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient was brought to the OPD with complains of fatigability, vomiting, and malaise. Examination revealed occult blood in stools, anemia, and hypertension. The patient was diagnosed to have cushing’s ulcers. What could be the likely reason for cushion’s ulcer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Head injury:

Cushing's ulcers can develop in patients with severe head injuries, particularly those with elevated intracranial pressure. The increased intracranial pressure leads to activation of the vagus nerve, which stimulates the release of gastric acid and increases gastric motility, resulting in the development of gastric ulcers.

 

Incorrect options:

Option A. Burns: Burns are not typically associated with the development of Cushing's ulcers. Gastric ulcers in burn patients are more commonly attributed to other factors such as stress, decreased mucosal blood flow, and altered acid secretion.

Option B. Stress: While stress can contribute to the development of gastric ulcers, it is not specific to Cushing's ulcers. Stress-related ulcers, also known as stress ulcers, can occur in various conditions such as severe illness, trauma, surgery, or critical illness.

Option D. Cell necrosis: Cell necrosis alone is not a direct cause of Cushing's ulcers. The development of gastric ulcers involves complex mechanisms related to the autonomic nervous system and altered acid secretion.

questions.text: Which statement is accurate regarding paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Deficiency of CD55 and CD59:

  • PNH is associated with a deficiency of CD55 (decay-accelerating factor) and CD59 (membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis), which are GPI-anchored proteins that regulate the complement system and protect blood cells from complement-mediated destruction.

 

Incorrect options

Option A - Inherited defect in PIG-A. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is caused by a somatic mutation in the PIG-A gene, which is an acquired defect.

Option B - PNH is characterized by intravascular hemolysis, not extravascular hemolysis.

Option D - PNH is not typically associated with microcytic anemia.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis has been treated with methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids for the past 4 months. However, the disease is still progressing. What would be your recommendation for the further management of this patient?

choices.text: Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Add sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine:

  • When a patient with rheumatoid arthritis shows inadequate response to initial therapy with methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids, the addition of other disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) is often recommended. Sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine are commonly used DMARDs and can be added to the treatment regimen to improve disease control.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A female patient presents with fever, oral ulcer, photosensitivity, and rashes on her face as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Systemic lupus erythematosus:

  • SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organs and systems, including the skin, joints, kidneys, heart, and lungs. The butterfly rash, also known as malar rash, is a hallmark feature of SLE and typically appears on the face over the cheeks and bridge of the nose.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following murmur increases on standing?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - HOCM (Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy):

  • In HOCM, the murmur increases on standing due to decreased preload. This is known as the "standing murmur" phenomenon. HOCM is characterized by the hypertrophy of the left ventricular wall, particularly the septum. This hypertrophy causes obstruction to the outflow of blood from the left ventricle during systole, resulting in a murmur.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C and D are not associated with a murmur that increases on standing.

questions.text: On performing a pulmonary function test, reduction in FEV1/FVC is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Obstructive disease:

  • In obstructive lung diseases, the airways become narrowed or obstructed, making it difficult for air to flow out during expiration.
  • The reduction in the FEV1/FVC ratio is a characteristic finding in obstructive lung diseases.
  • The FEV1 decreases more than the FVC, leading to a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio.
  • This reduction indicates impaired airflow during expiration, resulting in increased residual volume in the lungs.
  • Examples of obstructive lung diseases include asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and bronchiectasis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Restrictive disease:

  • In restrictive lung diseases, the expansion of lung tissue is limited, resulting in reduced lung volumes.
  • Restrictive lung diseases typically do not cause a significant reduction in the FEV1/FVC ratio.
  • Instead, both FEV1 and FVC are proportionally reduced, maintaining a relatively normal FEV1/FVC ratio or even slightly increased.
  • Examples of restrictive lung diseases include pulmonary fibrosis, interstitial lung disease, and chest wall deformities.

Option C - Normal lung function:

  • Reduction in the FEV1/FVC ratio is not characteristic of normal lung function.

Option D - Interstitial lung disease:

  • Interstitial lung disease is a form of restrictive lung disease. FEV1/FVC might be normal or slightly elevated in these patients.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient presents with complaints of bone pain in the hands, difficulty in passing stools, along with history of recurrent renal stones. On investigation, his serum calcium was increased, decreased serum phosphate and X-ray showing subperiosteal resorption of phalanges. In which of the following conditions calcitonin levels are increased?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hyperparathyroidism:

  • Calcitonin is a hormone produced by the parafollicular or C-cells of the thyroid gland. Its primary function is to regulate calcium and phosphate levels in the body.
  • In hyperparathyroidism, there is excessive production of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by the parathyroid glands. This condition leads to increased levels of PTH, which in turn can stimulate the production of calcitonin by the thyroid gland.  

Incorrect Options:

Hyperthyroidism (option A) is characterized by an overactive thyroid gland and is not directly associated with increased calcitonin levels.

Hypoparathyroidism (option B) is a condition where there is an underproduction of parathyroid hormone, leading to decreased levels of PTH and subsequently decreased calcitonin levels.

Cushing's syndrome (option D) is a disorder caused by prolonged exposure to high levels of cortisol hormone, typically due to adrenal gland dysfunction. It is not directly associated with changes in calcitonin levels.

questions.text: Which one of the following is a direct cause of Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS)?

choices.text: Fat embolism syndrome following femur shaft fracture

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pneumonia:

  • Pneumonia is an infection of the lungs that primarily affects the alveoli.
  • Severe pneumonia can cause respiratory distress which directly leads to ARDS.
  • Pneumonia is considered a parenchymal lung disease.
  • Both Pneumonia > Sepsis are the leading causes of ARDS

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Fat embolism syndrome following femur shaft fracture: Fat embolism syndrome occurs when fat globules are released into the bloodstream, typically following long bone fractures. These fat globules can obstruct blood vessels in the lungs, leading to inflammation and lung injury. Fat embolism syndrome can cause ARDS at the blood-lung interface.

Option C - Sepsis: Sepsis is a systemic inflammatory response to infection that can lead to organ dysfunction. In severe cases, sepsis can cause ARDS, as the inflammatory response affects the blood-lung interface and results in lung injury.

Option D - Transfusion-related lung injury: Transfusion-related lung injury (TRALI) occurs when donor antibodies or other components in blood products trigger an immune response, leading to lung injury. TRALI can cause ARDS at the blood-lung interface.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male child developed with sore throat, difficulty in swallowing, and mild fever. On examination, the clinical picture shown below is seen. Which of the following sentences is false regarding the vaccine that could have prevented this condition?

choices.text: It is administered on the anterolateral aspect of the thigh.
A history of anaphylaxis with same vaccineis not a contraindication
The cellular pertussis component in the vaccine is not recommended after 7-years of age
The diphtheria toxoid dose in adults is much lesser than the pediatric dose

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - A history of anaphylaxis with the same vaccine is not a contraindication:

  • False statement, history of anaphylaxis is a contraindication

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It is administered on the anterolateral aspect of the thigh: Administered on anterolateral aspect of thigh, correct site for vaccine administration

Option C - The cellular pertussis component in the vaccine is not recommended after 7 years of age: Cellular pertussis component not recommended after 7 years of age, true statement
